13 bronze coins: 9 sestertii, 4 asses: Domitian - Marcus Aurelius Aurelius (AD 166).
Hoard of 190 denarii found with ceramic vessel: Republic (?) - Hadrian.
The hoard comprised 112 sestertii: Trajan-Septimius Severus (98-196 AD).
The hoard comprised 16 coins with the denominations not given. The hoard was found on the Barre farm, while making repairs to the farmyard.
Unknown number of aurei of the Anoninian house (the number expressed were between 5,000 and 9,000). Only one piece of Antoninus Pius was identified.
23 denarii found with a money-box: Trajan - Marcus Aurelius (AD 175-176)
disposition: Muzeul de Istorie a Județului Vâlcea, Râmnicu Vâlcea, Romania

summary: (90) 27 denarii: 7 republican, 20 imperial: Republic - Marcus Aurelius (AD 161-180). Found in a ceramic vessel.
(c. 600) 300 silver coins: 299 denarii, 1 drachm: Mark Antony - Commodus (AD 180-183).
Around 2,000 denarii found on the surface after the river outflow. Only 8 denarii were known: Trajan 2, Hadrian 1, Faustina I 3, Commodus 2.

A hoard of 291 Roman imperial denarii: Hadrian – Commodus (AD 180-192) and their imitations was found by two treasure hunters in early June 2016 in the Kyiv region. Information about the find and photos of the coins were published by one of the finders on the Ukrainian treasure hunting forum Violity on June 21, 2016. The finder reported that the coins were collected from an area of 3 square meters. The first coins were found at a depth of 10-20 cm, although the pit for their search was dug about 1 m deep. Some coins have traces of bronze oxides. In general, the preservation of coins is good (weak wear). In August 2016, the entire hoard was sold at a Violity auction. The further fate of the coins is unknown.

A hoard of denarii, found while digging sand in a sand-pit, between the Lion Foundry, Kirkintilloch, and Barley Bank houses. 24 coins were first published in 1894, followed by a more complete list in 1911 (42 coins). 5 more coins were found since, giving a total of 47 denarii (Vespasian - Faustina II) that were published.
Hoard of 23 denarii: Trajan - Commodus (AD 188-189); silver weight: 52.27 g.
15 sestertii: Domitian - Commodus (AD 180-192).
322 denarii are issued from Nero to Septimius Severus (AD 193-195).
Some coins, unknown denomination, of Nerva, Trajan and Marcus Aurelius
The hoard comprised 18 denarii, sestertii, dupondii and asses dating to the second century AD. TAF interprets the hoard as the contents of a purse lost when the building was demolished.

The hoard discovered no later than 1900; the total number of coins is unknown. A city dweller with the surname Shapiro bought 44 coins (Vespasian-Commodus; total weight 127.43 g), of which only eight were identified in the Imperial Archaeological Commission (by E. Pridik) and then were returned to the owner.
102 bronze coins found with an amphora and dispersed in the coin trade: Tiberius - Marcus aurelius (AD 161-180).
9 bronze coins from Trajan to Marcus Aurelius, most likely a part of a larger find.
35 bronze coins: medallions and coins: Nero, Vespasian, Titus, Trajan, Hadrian, Antoninus Pius (AD 138-161).
11 denarii: Vespasian - Marcus Aurelius (AD 161-180).

According to Carlier, the hoard filled a hat(!) and is likely to have originally comprised at least 600 pieces.Although originally comprising more than 600 coins, the hoard was quickly dispersed. The forest administration confiscated 98 coins, Carlier bought approximately 300, the brothers Gérin took 40, while Demonteville, the librarian of Douai, took 100 sestertii, 5 or 6 'middle bronze' and 12 silver coins: Tiberius (Divus Augustus) - Commodus) (AD 181-190).
Four aurei (Nero to Antoninus Pius) recorded at 4 different points in time, between 1996 and 2002, clearly forming a hoard. Many other metal-detected finds from site, Roman-post-medieval.
6 sestertii were found at a gravel pit close to Eisenfeld.
Hoard of 320 denarii found with a ceramic vessel: Nerva - Pertinax (AD 193).
200-150 coins found with a ceramic vessel. Only 48 denarii are known today: Nero – Hadrian (AD 125-128).
The hoard comprised Roman gold and silver coins: Galba - Hadrian (AD 117-138).

Hoard consists of 70 Roman denarii (26 studied, 1 solidus): Vespasian - Didius Julianus (AD 193). Together with these coins were found: a solidus of Constantius II (Nicomedia/Cyzicus/Antioch, AD 340-355) as a pendant, two gold pendants slightly different in size, two belt buckles: one silver and one bronze, and a group of 13 silver pendants from a necklace.
Around 200 denarii of which only 8 have provided information on the issuers: Vespasian 1, Trajan 3, Hadrian 2, Antoninus Pius 2.
21 denarii: Galba - Septimius Severus (Julia Domna) (AD 193-196).
disposition: Coin Room, Library of the Romanian Academy, Bucharest, Romania (inv.nos. 14845-14865 - in 1944)

summary: Initially, there were 1,500 aurei. 144 aurei studied: Nero - Marcus Aurelius (AD 161-162). Together were found one gold and two silver ingots.
70 coins: 35 sestertii, 27 dupondii, 8 asses hidden in the wall of a Roman building: Vespasian - Marcus Aurelius (AD 168).
235 denarii found with a ceramic vessel: Vespasian - Clodius Albinus (AD 193-197).

A hoard of at least 105, possibly up to 115, denarii found at the end of December 1930, of which only 105 are still identified in the records of Rabat Museum. Chatelain, the original excavator, listed 114 coins in the find, including two coins of Juba II, one of Nero, one of Galba, nineteen of Vespasian, seven of Titus, twenty-three of Domitian, three of Nerva, forty-eight of Trajan and ten of Hadrian. However it is clear that Chatelain misidentified two of the Republican denarii as coins of Juba II. The next publication of the hoard, by Ruhlmann, came in 1933. This list largely agrees with the records kept by Rabat Museum, but includes ten extra coins, taking the total up to 115, which must now be regarded as lost. The missing coins listed by Ruhlmann are as follows: one Republican denarius, one denarius of Vespasian, two denarii of Domitian, five denarii of Trajan and one Hadrianic denarius. There are no further details concerning the types of these coins, because Ruhlmann only published in detail the nine latest specimens from the find. The whole hoard was contained in a hollow bracelet and was probably buried circa 122.
15 sestertii as a foundation offering: Trajan - Commodus (AD 190-191).

A hoard of at least 595 denarii, ranging from Nerva to Crispina, found in the middle of the 19th century in the fortress of Krani in Cephalonia. The coins were given to the Numismatic Museum by the Phocas-Kosmetatos family (in 1970 and 1972).
Three coins found together by a detectorist and recorded by M. Lyne. Details from HER.
The hoard comprised more than 400 worn coins including issues of Nero, Trajan, Hadrian, Antoninus Pius and Crispina.
Hoard of around 100 denarii from the time of the Antonine dynasty. Only four coins are documented.
The hoard comprised 4 aurei and 132 silver coins, as well as jewellery from the second century AD: Nero - Hadrian (AD 117-138). Associated with Bar Kochba revolt (AD 132-135).

During the excavation of the native British site at Hengistbury Head, over 3000 coins were found lying on the surface and all through the soil. They had evidently been deposited in bundles. Of these over 100 were Roman, the earliest about 91 BC and the latest six coins of Antoninus Pius (138-61 AD). The rest were all British, consisting approximately of 1,300 of the Hengistbury cast type. Of the south-western struck type there were about 1,660. The remainder were various Gaulish, British and Channel Island types with a few new varieties. A coin with EISV on it was the only inscribed specimen.
disposition: British Museum (part); Ashmolean Museum (part); Fitzwilliam Museum (part); Red House Museum, Christchurch (part)

summary: 141 denarii: Republic – Commodus (AD 180-192).
Three Roman bronze coins (Trajan - Marcus Aurelius Caesar) were found together in a field, inside an old foundation wall.

A hoard of at least 160 Roman imperial denarii was found by a treasure hunter in 2009 or 2010 near the village of Baikivka. According to his information, the hoard was partially ploughed, but the main part of it was at a depth of ca. 50 cm together with fragments of a vessel (pot?). The coins had traces of bronze oxides. Photographs of the deposit have not been preserved, but it is known that most of the coins date from the Nerva-Antonine dynasty, including coins of Antoninus Pius and Commodus. The fate of the coins is unknown.

A deliberate deposit from the excavations at Ashwell. E Ghey writes: Group 2002 T215 (5) consisted of items in a 'placed deposit' in context 203. This deposit consisted of two copper alloy units of Tasciovanus, four copper alloy units of Cunobelin, one silver Icenian unit, a pierced dupondius of Claudius, an as of Vespasian and an as of Hadrian. The non-coin objects consisted of second century AD Roman objects (a brooch, mounts, numerous fragments of iron mail armour and implements, a fragment of a pipe-clay figurine) and part of a Bronze Age spearhead, in addition to fragments of pottery, animal bone and cremated bone. The as of Hadrian places deposit (5) in the second century AD at the earliest; a time in which the coin evidence as a whole suggests a reduction in activity at the site.
The hoard comprised 3 Roman Provincial coins: (Cassandrea, Philippi, Koinon of Macedonia), found in grave 589 in Ierissos.
115 denarii: Nero - Marcus Aurelius (AD 167).
disposition: Archaeological Museum, Veliko Tarnovo, Bulgaria; inv.nos. 1617-1730 (115 coins)

summary: 6 bronze coins: Nero - Antoninus Pius (AD 138-161).
180 coins ending with issues of Marcus Aurelius (AD 161-180). Trajan was the other issuer recognized among the coins of this hoard.
(8-900) 52 aurei: Domitian - Marcus Aurelius (AD 172-175).
disposition: Collection Rockox (37 coins), in 17th century; collection Van Gestel (1 coin), in 17th century; collection Christine de Suède (non-identifiable)

summary: The hoard comprised 6 Roman Provincial coins: Dion (2 Trajan, 1 Hadrian), Thessalonica (1 Trajan, 1 pseudo-autonomous Antoninus Pius), found in grave 7 in Sevasti.
The hoard was found in a female burial and contained a box or casket containing 18 Antonine coins, earrings, brooches, a belt buckle and a terracotta figurine in the shape of a small horse.
Hoard of unknown number of bronze coins. 1 coin of Antoninus Pius and 1 of Faustina I (Augusta/Diva) were seen.

3rd century. "Six coins, a small mid-3rd century AD hoard, found in soil (751A), 3 sealed by east wall (763) of Structure Y [a trapezoidal stone-walled enclosure appended to inner wall face of the round]. Another coin found in (728), the surface of Structure Y, & 2 more in overlying soil (785). These 3 coins of similar date & condition, & formed part of scattered hoard.

The hoard (4 coins, Republic - Faustina I/II) was found with around 20 coins in 1772 during the digging of a draw well in front of the castle. - not sure which castle is meant, as there are three of them in Jagsthausen.

Five denarii found at different dates, between 2005 and 007, on the same field using metal detectors: Vespasian, Trajan, Antoninus Pius, Marcus Aurelius (Caesar), Marcus Aurelius (Augustus) (AD 171-172).
disposition: Private collection (4 coins); National Museum of archaeology, Warszaw, Poland (1 coin)

summary: 72 aurei ranging from Vespasian to Antoninus Pius (with Diva Faustina I and M. Aurelius Caesar) found in the vicus of Lousonna within a house. The coins had been divided in two concealments of each 35 coins, hidden in the floor. Two further coins were found nearby.
Three bronze coins in a small vessel: 1 sestertius Trajan, 1 AE Hadrian, 1 AE L. Aelius (AD 137-138).
Two denarii: Antoninus Pius, Marcus Aurelius (Lucius Verus/Divus Lucius Verus) (AD 161-169). Militky considers a misidentification of this hoard with the one Dobřichov-Plaňany (PLAŇANY 1892).
Three coins of Hadrian found in a tomb (1 aureus and 2 denarii), but the information does not look trustworthy and the coins are not preserved.
The hoard comprised 831 bronze coins from the Second Jewish Revolt (AD 132-136).
800 denarii. 274 pieces were studied by V. Haralanov: Nero - Hadrian (AD 117-138).
1600 denarii found in a ceramic vessel - metal detecting - within an ancient settlement. The latest coins are from Antoninus Pius (AD 138-161).
200 aurei: Galba - Marcus Aurelius (AD 161-180).

The hoard comprised 23 sestertii struck for Trajan, Hadrian, and Antoninus Pius. Discovered at a depth of 4 metres when a drainage ditch was being dug during road improvement works to the south of the railway station in Kiesen.
18 denarii were discovered in the vicinity of the village of Raksha. Fifteen were documented: Vespasian - Commodus (AD 192).
In 1853 not far from the Oste river during earthworks three bronze coins (Marcus Aurelius) were found at a depth of 10 feet. Pit holes and other remains indicate a settlement.
The hoard comprised 10 bronze coins: Vespasian - Trajan (AD 103-111). Weight: 68.27 g.
disposition: Soprintendenza per i Beni Archeologici del Veneto, Padova, Italy

summary: 2 denarii found on manor field: C. Porcius Cato, Hadrian (119-122).
disposition: Museum of Moravia, Brno, Czech Republic

summary: The hoard comprised 41 denarii from Vespasian to Septimius Severus.
The hoard comprised an earthenware vessel containing 100 Roman coins including denarii, sestertii and dupondii, nearly all issues of Antoninus Pius, Faustina I and Faustina II.
300 aurei: Nero - Marcus Aurelius (AD 161-180).
The hoard apparently comprised 68 denarii, although the catalogue gives a total of 59 coins.
45 denarii: Vespasian - Commodus (AD 190-191); silver weight: 106.55 g. (41 coins)
disposition: Swedish History Museum, Stockholm (inv.no. 6293); Gotlands Fornsal, Visby, Finland A 1922 (inv.nos. A 2090, A 2091)

summary: A. Marsden writes: "Roman coin hoard of 17 coins, all asses or dupondii of the first or early second century. Many of the coins are corroded and in poor condition but the four coins of Hadrian appear to have seen relatively little circulation when they went into the ground. The earlier ones appear heavily worn. We might suggest a date of loss or deposition around the middle of the second century AD.1) Claudius, as, reverse Minerva advancing right, appears regular, weight 5.93g, AD41-542) Uncertain as or dupondius, perhaps Nero, ?AD64-83) Vespasian, as, reverse probably standing figure, AD69-794-6) Uncertain Flavian, asses or dupondii, AD69-96 (3)7) Hadrian, as, reverse female standing right, AD117-258) Hadrian, as, reverse female seated left holding cornucopia, AD117-38 .9) Hadrian, as, reverse standing figure, AD117-3810) Hadrian, quadrans, reverse probably rostrum, probably RIC II, 623, AD121-211-17) Asses or dupondii, illegible (7)"
68 denarii: Nero - Antoninus Pius (AD 150-151).

A hoard of 161 aurei and 4 denarii was discovered on the site of 29 Klagenfurter Str. in Villach. Four aurei were initially discovered before a supervised excavation at the site uncovered the rest of the coins. Of the 161 aurei, only 100 issues dating from Nero to Septimius Severus have been properly catalogued. The four denarii have all been catalogued: Nero - Septimius Severus (AD 194-197).
disposition: Museum Der Stadt Villach (115 aurei and 4 denarii); private collection (42 aurei)

summary: A Roman coin hoard consisting of 106 denarii (Republic - Commodus) was discovered in 1908 during the renovation of a grinding mill, 2 km south-west of Unterammergau. The hoard was in earthenware jar, that had apparently been placed between rocks. The coins are now lost.

The Cabinet des Médailles de la Bibliothéque Nationale acquired 36 aurei on 17.03.1847 (Reg. C, nos. 1982-2017) and a further 44 on 8.2.1848 (Reg. C, nos. 2117-2160). 79 remain (with one swopped in 1939). The Musée Saint-Jean d'Angers bought 6 aurei on 3.4.1847 and 2 on the 13.06.1847, with fragments of the vase acquired on 04.03.1849 (Reg. I, p. 53-54, no. 209, p. 58, no. 217, p. 74, no. 269). They were stolen in March 1885.
Hoard of more than 200 denarii. Only 10 were documented: Hadrian (Aelius Caesar) - Pertinax (AD 193).
(52) 49 denarii found with a ceramic vessel of Carpic manufacture: Vespasian - Antoninus Pius (Diva Faustina I) (post AD 141).
Over 1,000 denarii: Nero - Commodus (AD 186-191).
Originally 3 denarii (Hadrian, Antoninus Pius, imitation) found within an Iron Age settlement together iron, earthenware, bone artefacts.
The hoard was found in an ancient vessel and comprised between 500 and 600 bronze coins. Very close by, a large glass urn, pottery and three bronze basins were also found.
121 denarii: Vespasian - Septimius Severus (AD 194-195); silver weight: 322.18 g.
64 bronze coins: sestertii, dupondii and asses: Augustus - Marcus Aurelius (AD 177-178).
826 coins found with a ceramic vessel. 763 denarii were: Republic - Marcus Aurelius (AD 167). The hoard was entirely recovered but not published accurate.
Eight sestertii found in Pot Ridings Wood.
12 denarii: Republic – Marcus Aurelius (Commodus Augustus) (AD 178). Some doubts have been expressed as the coins are now in a private collection.

33 denarii (Mark Antony to Antoninus Pius) found by a party of schoolchildren among rubble in a chamber of the prehistoric and Roman mine workings beneath the hill fort at Llanymynech Ogof. The coins were fused together before being separated by a local antiquarian. A piece of black pottery picked up on another occasion close to the site of the discovery may possibly indicate that the hoard has been disturbed at some time.
disposition: National Museums Wales, Cardiff (part); Oswestry Museum (part)

summary: 79 coins: 6 denarii, 45 sestertii, 16 dupondii, 12 asses found with shreds from the ceramic vessel: Galba - Hadrian (AD 117-138).
The hoard comprised 17 silver coins (Vespasian-Hadrian) and 43 bronze coins.

The hoard of 126 gold aurei contained within the fragmentary remains of a small pot was discovered while searching with a metal detector on land near Didcot, Oxfordshire, in April 1995. Coins range from Nero to Marcus Aurelius Caesar.
A hoard of 61 Roman coins to Hadrian and 616 Iron Age bronze coins found some years ago in Southants. It was contained in an earthenware pot which was broken in the course of the discovery.
disposition: British Museum (part); Hunter Coin Cabinet, Glasgow (part); Red House Museum, Christchurch (part)

summary: The hoard comprised approximately 250 sestertii dating to the second century AD and weighing between 5 and 6kg.
Unknown originally number of coins. 52 denarii were found with a hand-made ceramic vessel: Mark Antony – Marcus Aurelius (AD 161-180).
Unknown number of aurei and silver coins found with a ceramic vessel. Only five aurei were seen: Trajan 4, Trajan for Plotina 1.
Around 150 denarii and a drachm. Only 43 coins provide information on issuers: Nero - Antoninus Pius (AD 138-161).

Found in the garden of one of the villagers. Consisted of denarii (quantity unknown), which were in a pot. The coins were taken by villagers. V. Lyaskoronsky in 1926 saw only two denarii from this hoard (Antoninus Pius and Marcus Aurelius). In 1964, L. Pobal examined the probable place of the find, but did not find additional information about the hoard.
Large hoard of silver coins. Only 7 denarii are kept in the museum of Pleven: Republic - Marcus Aurelius (AD 161-180).
disposition: Okrazen Istoriceski Muzej, Pleven, Bulgaria; inv.no. 1452 1-7

summary: A hoard of 18 denarii (Otho-Commodus) found during excavations at Dura Europos, in E4-15.
5 denarii (Vespasian - Hadrian) found together in Rottweil, in the south of the Roman city (Parzelle 969/3, Firma Mahle).
The hoard comprised an unknow number of aurei, at least 12(?), from Vespasian to Hadrian (AD 136).
12 coins: 1 denarius, 11 sestertiiTrajan - Marcus Aurelius (AD 161-180). Found 800 m westward from the hoard Koropie 2008 1. Together were found a bronze brooch and a horn shape bronze ring
disposition: Laboratory of Archeology, Historical Sociology and Cultural Heritage, Faculty of Sociology, St. Petersburg State University, Russia

summary: At least 33 denarii (Vespasian to Marcus Aurelius) found in 1940 by gardeners engaged in converting a tennis court into a vegetable patch. Pye reports that the hoard was contained in a pot with a tile lid, since lost, and that one of the finders removed at least 27 of the coins, none of which were recovered. Four further reports of coins from Corton House appear in the Transactions of the Radnorshire Society over succeeding years; whether these were new discoveries at/near the same site or part of the original find is unclear. The original size of the hoard is, therefore, uncertain, and is likely to have been larger than the 33 denarii detailed here.
A hoard of 138 denarii (Galba - Hadrian), found at Sleddle Mouth, Mallerstang Edge, concealed in a hole in the ground and covered by a flat stone.
disposition: Carlisle Museum and Art Gallery (part); British Museum (part)

summary: 8 denarii found on a field: Vespasian - Marcus Aurelius (Lucilla) (AD 161-180).
70 denarii: Vespasian - Commodus (AD 180-192).
Six aurei Possible part of a larger hoard.
A hoard of an unknown number of denarii. Only 15 coins were documented: Hadrian (Aelius Caesar) - Marcus Aurelius (AD 177-178). Kropotkin suspected that it may be the same hoard as Sosnitsa.
disposition: University Museum, Kyiv, Ukraine (15 coins until 1917)

summary: 14 denarii part of a hoard found on the same field like GANDARVE 1927, 1928, 1928-1931: Vespasian (Domitian Caesar) - Marcus Aurelius (Faustina II) (AD 161-175); silver weight: 22.67 g (8 coins).
Unknown original number of denarii, 69 preserved: Nero - Marcus Aurelius (AD 168); silver weight: 194 g.
The hoard comprised approximately 10 tetradrachms and 35 denarii from the Second Jewish Revolt (AD 132-136).
Coins found in sarcophagus no. 905: 34 gold and silver coins: 3 Aurei: Nero 2, Hadrian 1; 14 denarii: Augustus 12,Uncertain (Augustus?) 2; 1 hemidrachm of Hadrian, and 16 drachms of Gotarzes II.
c. 800 aurei: Hadrian - Commodus (AD 180-192). No further information given.
Four bronze coins, three sestertii and 1 as, were found together in a wall: Domitian, Trajan, Hadrian, Antoninus Pius (AD 138-161)
22 asses: Augustus - Antoninus Pius (AD 145-161) .
The hoard comprised 35 aurei (Nero-Lucius Verus) and 29 silver coins (Nero-Trajan).
Around 40 silver coins. Only 4 denarii of Antoninus Pius are known.
Unknown originally number of coins. 59 bronze coins are known: 51 sestertii, 9 dupondii: Trajan - Commodus (AD 190-191).
The hoard comprised around 200 tetradrachms and 1,000 denarii from the Second Jewish Revolt (AD 132-136).
10 denarii (Vespasian - Marcus Aurelius) found corroded together with a bronze fibula and a clasp. They might have been contained in a purse.
Two denarii: Antoninus Pius, Commodus (AD 183).
A find, comprising one aureus and seven denarii, was made at the south end of site XXVIII. The coins were found loose on the floor of a house of the Antonine period.
Originally 5 denarii, 1 preserved: Hadrian - Commodus (AD 186). Found together with 1 gold finger ring, 3 silver finger rings.
20 denarii, 15 studied: Trajan – Commodus (AD 189).

A very large find of Roman denarii, made in 1858 in the vicinity of Filsum. Around 1960, three further denarii (Domitian Caesar, Commodus) were found on a field, and can probably be connected with the same find.
IARCH record for a hoard of five denarii of Septimius Severus in a small conical lead-alloy container.

The details of the hoard are not well known. Found in 1871 it passed possession multiple times and was eventually split. Originally 387 silver coins were found, and one gold piece, along with several urns. Only 12 pieces are described: Domitian - Marcus Aurelius (Lucilla Augusta).
7 asses: Domitianus - Hadrianus (AD 121-122).

103 denarii (Nero to Antoninus Pius) found near a large stone building and a series of ditches identified by a geophysical survey in 1999 and described as a farmhouse. The site has turned up building debris, pottery, and a series of other metal finds, including at least 46 other denarii that might have come from the coin hoard (Treasure report SS 91 69).
A hoard of 52 denarii (Vespasian - Antoninus Pius) and 1 drachm of Amisus, found during the breaking up of soil in Lausitz. The hoard might have been associated with a series of 7 cremation graves.
Hoard of an unknown number of denarii. Only 9 coins were documented: Vespasian - Commodus (AD 190). One nummus of Constantine I can be considered as an intruder.
disposition: Archaeological Museum Warsaw, Poland (donation R. Turkievich, 1936 )

summary: The hoard comprised '20 coins of which the most recent was an issue of Marcus Aurelius' The hoard was discovered by peat cutters.
8 bronze coins: 5 sestertii, 1 dupondius, 1 as, 1 AE: Hadrian - Commodus (AD 180-192).
Unknown initial number of coins. 183 denarii: Nero - Pescennius Niger (AD 193-194).
50 denarii: Vespasian - Marcus Aurelius (AD 161-180). No information about circumstances.
31 bronze coins: 22 sestertii, 9 dupondii: Trajan - Hadrian
The hoard comprised 2 batches containing 24 bronzes from Trajan to Antoninus Pius for the first and 300 bronzes for the second.
112 bronze coins: 111 sestertii, 1 dupondius: Vespasian - Septimius Severus (AD 195-196).
Seven bronze coins (asses): Trajan – Antoninus Pius (AD 140-144). The coins were placed in a cooking pot with lid together with seven clay lamps, type FORTIS.
HER record of a first century hoard found on Sheringham Beach along with remains of a ceramic container, exposed through cliff erosion. Only 5 coins were examined but the hoard was much larger.
(21) 19 bronze coins: 11 sestertii, 7 dupondii, 1 as: Trajan - Hadrian (AD 134-138).
The hoard comprised 4 tetradrachms, at least 20 denarii, and "a large number of bronze" coins of the Bar Kokhba Revolt (AD 132-135/136).

The hoard comprised 5 sestertii, dupondii or asses from Tiberius to Commodus and was found in association with a key handle, an incense burner, two statues (one being of Mercury) and a statue base. The remains of a Roman building, the function of which was undetermined, was found close by.
Possibble hoard of unknown number of silver and bronze coins found within a cemetery. The only preserved coins are two denarii of Hadrian and Antoninus Pius.
disposition: Coin Room, National History Museum of Latvia, Riga (inv.nos. LNVM NUM - CVVM 120210: 1-2

summary: 149 silver coins: 1 republican denarius, 147 imperial denarii, 1 drachm: Mark Antony - Marcus Aurelius (AD 168)
12 bronze coins: 11 sestertii, 1 dupondius/as found stuch together in a layer of fire: Nero - Hadrian (AD 129-130).
52 denarii: Trajan - Septimius Severus (AD 193-194).
The hoard comprised 9 silver coins of the Second Jewish Revolt (AD 132-136).
16 sestertii: Trajan 13, Hadrian 3 (AD 121-122).
disposition: National History Museum, Sofia, Bulgaria; inv.nos. 13625-13640

summary: 23 denarii, group of single finds, found within a settlement: Hadrian - Commodus (AD 183-184); silver weight: 57.89 g.
The hoard comprises 17 asses from Vespasian to Hadrian (AD 117-138).
12 denarii found with a small ceramic vessel: Titus - Antoninus Pius (AD 143-144).
The hoard comprised a ceramic urn containing 50 corroded, worn, illegible Roman coins, with the exception being two sestertii of Hadrian and Antoninus Pius.
Around 100 hundred Roman bronze coins (sestertii, dupondii/asses): Domitian - Didius Julianus (AD 193)
disposition: Museum of Chambéry, France (partially). private collections: Conte, Faudrain, Fivel etc.

summary: ca. 80 sestertii and dupondii, but not all of them are identified: Trajan - Commodus (AD 180-192).
Hoard of around 50 denarii. 21 coins were brought for examination by the finder: Republic - Marcus Aurelius (AD 161-180).

97 coins: 1 denarius and 96 bronzes found concentrated around an earthenware dish within a level of a building: Republic - Marcus Aurelius (AD 166-167). The coins were found together with a brooch, as well as several pieces of pottery and nails.
55 bronze coins with unknown findspot except for the mention north Portugal
47 denarii: Vespasian - Didius Julianus (AD 193); silver weight: 87.1-137.5 g
8 coins: 7 denarii, 1 sestertius found in a destruction layer caused by fire: Vitellius - Antoninus Pius (AD 159-160).

The hoard comprised several hundred Roman coins (the majority being sestertii) contained in a wooden box. The hoard was found 2 or 300 metres from the conciergerie of the Hypogeum on the left towards the water tower.

During the construction of the protestant Alumneum (Gesandtstraße) in 1900, remains of a hypocaust system were found. Within the debris a group of 8 coins - 7 aurei and 1 denarius - were recovered, ranging from Nero to Antoninus Pius. They might have been stored in a wooden box or leather bag. The hoard's deposition is conjectured to have been linked to the Marcomannic Wars.

The hoard was discovered in 1850 by a private person during a search quarry stones. The coins lay concealed without a discernible container in the wall aperture of a Roman cellar (Quintan- obere prätorische Straße)). The hoard is thought to have comprised 360-370 denarii. 280 of them are now in the collection of antiquities from Nassau, in Wiesbaden. Coins range from Nero to Antoninus Pius.
403 denarii: Tiberius - Marcus Aurelius (AD 167-168); bronze and gold jewelry and bronze tweezers.
92 denarii: Republic - Marcus Aurelius (AD 161-180). Found in a ceramic vessel together with a silver bracelet.
The hoard comprised approximately 2,000 sestertii of the Antonine period.

The hoard comprised 7 aurei terminating in an issue of Trajan dating to AD 106. From 1826 to 1908, 7 Roman aurei were found by chance in the fields, all in the same region (Salzbrunnen and Z'underst Wyler), at a maximum distance of ca. 150 meters. These could be single finds or rather a dispersed hoard? Found in 1826: Nerva; 1859: Nero; 1894: Vespasian; 1896: Trajan; 1899: Nerva; 1907: Galba; 1908: Trajan.
disposition: Kantonsarchäologie Schaffhausen (4 coins); Schweizerisches Landesmuseum Zürich (2 coins); Bernisches Historisches Museum (1 coin)

summary: Unknown originally number of coins. 27 denarii are kept at the Institute of Archaeology in Bucharest: Trajan – Commodus (AD 185).
disposition: Institute of Archaeology ”V. Parvan”, Bucharest, Romania (27 coins).

summary: Hoard of 300 denarii found with a vessel. 130 pieces are known: Antoninus Pius - Marcus Aurelius (AD 161-180).
disposition: At the beginning of the 20th century, in the collection of the industrialist Hertig in Łódź.

summary: 2 Iron Age gold quarter-staters, 18 denarii and 1 quinarius to Antoninus Pius and 6 copper-alloy votive objects.
A hoard of two Antonine sestertii and several items of gold jewellery, found in grave 23 in the western cemetery of Pella.
15 sestertii found in a grave with ceramic objects: Hadrian - Commodus (AD 180-192).

In 1900 the Hanauer museum acquired 44 denarii from an antique dealer in Büdingen, which obviously belonged to a find. The coins were supposedly found in 1899 in Marköbel during the construction of a house. The coins are today no longer present in the Hanauer museum. Coins range from Nero to Marcus Aurelius (Lucius Verus).
29 denarii: Otho - Septimius Severus (AD 193-194).
disposition: Museum of Cultural History Stralsund, Germany (26 coins); Museum Szeczin, Poland (3 coins)

summary: (?) 29 denarii: Republic - M. Aurelius (AD 166-167?)
23 denarii: Vespasian - Antoninus Pius (AD 160-161).
disposition: Museum of Dacian and Roman Civilisation, Deva, Romania

summary: 4 denarii found in the lid from a wooden box (Cassette) found in a princely grave: Hadrian 1, Marcus Aurelius/Lucius Verus 1, uncertain 2. In the same grave was found on the left side of the Skeleton an aureus of Clausiud II (see single gold find WROCŁAW ZAKRZÓW).

The hoard comprised a ceramic vessel containing 85 sestertii, the majority of which were rendered illegible by oxidation. However, those that could be identified range from issues of Hadrian to Commodus.
The hoard comprised 31 bronze coins from Augustus to Marcus Aurelius, not further described.
The hoard comprised 44 coins dated between the 4th-3rd century BCE and the reign of Hadrian (AD 117-138).
18 bronze coins: Augustus - Marcus Aurelius
Around 600 denarii of which only 17 provide information on issuers: Vespasian - Commodus (AD 180-192).
A hoard of denarii, found in a field from 1962 until 2001. FMRD lists 67 coins (Trajan - Pertinax).
Originally 30 denari, 29 preserved: Nerva - Commodus (AD 179-191); silver weight: 78.54 g.
30 bronze coins: Trajan - Marcus Aurelius (AD 161-180). Found 800 m eastward from the hoard Koropie 2008 2
disposition: Laboratory of Archeology, Historical Sociology and Cultural Heritage, Faculty of Sociology, St. Petersburg State University, Russia

summary: Unknown quantity of silver and bronze coins found in a copper vessel. 11 coins in the History Museum in Lom: Trajan - Antoninus Pius (AD 138-161).
Unknown initial number of coins: 28 denarii: Vespasian - Marcus Aurelius (AD 166); silver weight: 54.2-84.4g.
disposition: Regional History Museum, Vratsa, Bulgaria; inv.no. M I 233-250

summary: A find of 8 coins of Faustina II, made in the area of Panagia Vrontou in Salamina.
12 denari: Vespasian - Trajan (AD 114-117).

Galba to Severus. The number of coins in the hoard is estimated and falls somewhere between 1200 and 1500 denarii and 1 drachm of Amisus for Hadrian. Found with a ceramic vessel and few silver ingots.
disposition: Odessa Archaeological Museum (64 denarii; 1 drachm of Amisus)

summary: 9 sestertii: Hadrian - Commodus (AD 181).
Few dozens of denarii of the Antonine dynasty (AD 96-192). Only 10 denarii are known: Trajan, Faustina I, Marcus Aurelius.
Unknown originally number of coins. 50 denarii were sent to the Sankt Petersburg. Among issuers: Vespasiaen, Hadrian, Antoninus Pius, Faustina I, Commodus (AD 180-192).
865 coins: 29 aurei, 833 denarii: Republic - Hadrian (AD 137-138)
20 sestertii, found on a small plate with ashes: Domitian - Commodus (AD 180-187).
53 denarii: Republic - Marcus Aurelius (AD 161-180). Circumstances of discovery are unknown.
33 denarii: Republic - Hadrian (AD 125-128)
disposition: County Museum of Bistrița-Năsăud, Bistrița, Romania; Inv.no. MB 20918-20950

summary: 255 denarii found and sent to the Ministry of Finance. The coins were found with pieces of an urn during the removal of stones from a field.
Unknwon number of denarii found with an iron vessel. Only 14 denarii were identified: Nero - Septimius Severus (Caracalla Caesar) (AD 196-198).

A large hoard of gold coins (ca. 8 kg), found 40 km south of Mardin in 1890. Gnecchi also reports gold ingots, though Regling doubts this. The hoard was dispersed, but 302 aurei (Nero - Marcus Aurelius) have been published by Regling.
The coins were found in a glass urn along with a human cremation. Among issuers Hadrian and Antoninus Pius.
c. 300 sestertii from Hadrian to Marcus Aurelius (AD 161-180). No further information about composition of hoard.
disposition: Archaeological Museum Zagreb, Croatia; dispersed; Ervin Meixner coll.

summary: 368 aurei: Nero to Marcus Aurelius (AD 166).

find_spot_name: CASTELNUOVO VAL DI CECINA - SAN BERNARDINO
summary: 102 coins found with the remains of a textile bag: 94 sestertii, 7 dupondii, 1 as: Galba - Trajan (AD 112-114).
Unknown initial number of coins. 244 denarii: Nero - Marcus Aurelius (AD 161-175)
11 denarii: Trajan - Marcus Aurelius (AD 161-180).
disposition: Museum of Archaeology, Plovdiv, Bulgaria; inv.no. 2206

summary: Unknown number of bronze coins: Augustus - Commodus/Pertinax (AD 193).
1,055 denarii found with a ceramic vessel: Nero – Septimius Severus (AD 193-194).
disposition: History Museum, Piatra Neamț, Romania (1,042 coins; inv.no. C 706); History Museum "lulian Antonescu", Bacău (8 coins); private collections (5 coins)

summary: Unknown originally number of coins. 90 coins are kept in the collection of the National History Museum in Bucharest: Mark Antony – Marcus Aurelius (Lucius Verus) (AD 161-169).
Denarius hoard consisting of 97 denarii found through metal detectoring and excavation. Vespasian to Antoninus Pius.
A hoard of ancient coins, including a tetradrachm of Thassos and a denarius of Faustina I found with a ceramic vessel.

Hoard of 34 bronze sstaters of an autonomous (Agrippia) city and Bosporan kings: Aspurgus, Gepaepyris, Rhescuporis II, Sauromates I, Cotys II, Sauromates II and one issue of the mint of Agrippia Caesarea (Phanagoria).
disposition: Museum of Anapa, Russia (labelled as the "Gunyaevsky Hoard"; inv.nos. AM 10750/1-34)

summary: 40 denarii found in a ceramic vessel. Majority belongs to Hadrian.
4 denarii: Vitellius, Nerva, Trajan, Antoninus Pius (Diva Faustina I) (AD 141-160).
60 denarii: Galba/Vespasian - Marcus Aurelius (AD 161-180).

The find comprised 65 coins of Hadrian and Antoninus Pius, 7 copper-alloy figurines, a stone figurine of Sucellus, some copper-alloy and glass plates, a scythe, some knives, an amphora, moulded glazed cups, bells, an incense burner, a triangular stone pediment and some carbonised cereals.
The hoard comprised 171 aurei and 1 denarius from Nero to Marcus Aurelius.
disposition: União de Bancos Portugueses. Fundação Millenium, Oporto, Romania

summary: Unknown originally number of coins. 43 denarii are kept at the town museum in Piatra Neamț, Romania: Republic – Antoninus Pius (AD 147-148).
disposition: Town museum, Piatra Neamț, Romania (43 coins)

summary: The hoard comprised 15 copper-alloy coins from Hadrian to Commodus and we found next to a skeleton.
7 bronze coins: 2 dupondii, 5 asses: Claudius I - Trajan (AD 101-102)
A hoard of approx. 35 gold coins (Vespasian - Antoninus Pius), scattered within a small space in fire debris of a destructed Roman house, found during work on the canalisation in the Leostrasse.
Around 100 denarii found with a ceramic vessel. 95 coins provide information on issuers: Vespasian - Pertinax (AD 193).
The hoard was found in a ceramic vessel and comprised 722 'bronzes'. It has been suggested that they were sestertii dating from the reign of Hadrian to Commodus. Found close to the brickworks.

HER record of a hoard of 32 Roman copper coins, "chiefly of the Middle Empire" found in 1772 at North End in Turville. Eight of the coins were said in 1797 to be in the possession of Col Innes of Ibstone House, of which there were 2 of Antoninus Pius, 2 "Faustinas", 2 "Vespasians", 1 Trajan and 1 "Aurelius". Source: Thomas Langley 1797 "History and Antiquities of the Hundred of Desborough" p.383.
A hoard of 12 denarii (Vespasian - Hadrian) was found during the archaeological excavation of a building thought to be a granary and comprised of thirteen Denarii coins.
The hoard comprised 4 copper-alloy statues and 2 copper-alloy vessels. One of the copper-alloy vessels contained 6 bronze coins of Marcus Aurelius and Divus Lucius Verus. One coin was lost.
770 denarii found with a ceramic vessel. Among issuers: Trajan, Hadrian, Antoninus Pius.

A hoard of 10 aurei and 120+ denarii, found in 1878 near the Roman fort. The closure date of this hoard is AD 192. However the penultimate coin is an issue of 185 and a seven year gap between the terminal issues is unusual. In the event the hoard is listed as closing with RIC 241, with the caveat that the last coin may be a site find rather than a hoard item (P.J. Casey).

73 denarii (Vespasian to Commodus) found beneath a millstone by workmen removing "a quantity of loose stones and earth" near a lime kiln in a quarry. A pair of spurs was reportedly found at the same time. RCAHMW states that the precise location of the find is unknown "but there is apparently only one lime kiln on the estate" in a place still known as Limekiln Covert.
disposition: In the collection of T Assheton Smith Esq. M.P. (1849)

summary: 918 silver coins found with a ceramic vessel: 916 denarii, 1 drachm, 1mitation denarius: Nero – Septimius Severus (AD 193-194).
10 coins found together in a tomb (purse?): Domitian -Marcus Aurelius (AD 177).
A hoard of 47 denarii (Vespasian - Marcus Aurelius), found in a megalithic grave in an urn also containing ashes. The grave was located 20 m away from the mansion of Fickmühlen.
Hoard of an unknown number of denarii. According to some incriptions the issuers were Antoninus Pius and Marcus Aurelius (ANTONINVS PIVS, ANTONINVS ARMENIACVS). Six or eight denarii were noticed.
Circa 150 coins found with a ceramic vessel. Only 5 sestertii are known: Hadrian 1, Antoninus Pius 1, Faustina I (Diva) 1, 2 uncertain issuer.

A hoard of at least 50 Roman Imperial denarii and a silver and gold buckle were discovered by a treasure hunter no later than 2021, probably in Zhytomyr region. Information about the hoard and general photo of the coins with the buckle were published in one of the groups on Facebook, dedicated to treasure hunting on November 1, 2021. One of the group members (Vasyl Ugrynchuk of Volodarsk in Zhitomyr region) reported that the hoard was discovered by his acquaintances (possibly also from Zhytomyr region). On the photo denarii of Trajan, Hadrian, Antoninus Pius, Marcus Aurelius, Commodus can be recognized. The buckle is quite massive (ca. 5-7 cm), on the clip there is a gold plate with ornamentation. The further fate of the hoard is unknown.
99 denarii: Otho - Commodus (AD 182-183).
disposition: Museo Archeologico Nazionale, Ancona, Italy (inv. nos. 7395/22336 - 7493/22434)

summary: Unknown originally number of coins. Only five denarii are known: Tiberius - Antoninus Pius (Marcus Aurelius Caesar) (AD 145-160).
30-40 denarii. Only 15 were seen: Vespasian – Commodus (AD 180-192). No further details.

Ten Roman imperial denarii were found in the vicinity of ancient Olbia, to the west of Adzhigolskaya Balka, near the villages of Dmitrivka and Ivanivka (the exact location is not known). The coins have been identified by V. Stolba and U. Peter from photographs. The cirent location of the hoard is unknown.
A hoard of 54 bronze coins (Tiberius - Diva Faustina II) found during excavations in the Roman vicus; it was unearthed in stages, in 1983 and then 1986.

The deposit was found under a second century occupation layer in the central part of the Gallo-Roman spring sanctuary and comprised 4 sestertii from Trajan to Antoninus Pius and two asses of Antoninus Pius with a tpq of AD 153 to 154.
The hoard(?) comprised a "cluster" of 7 silver coins - 4 denarii, 1 plated denarius, 1 drachm - deposited during the Second Jewish Revolt (AD 132-136).
Hoard of unknown number of denarii. Only two pieces are known: Trajan, Hadrian.
Six coins found while extracting stone: Antoninus Pius 2, Faustina I 1, Commodus, 1 uncertain. No further information.
150 denarii. 145 coins entered the History Museum in Svishtov: Nero - Antoninus Pius (AD 150); silver weight of c. 275.8-468.2 g.
disposition: History Museum, Svishtov, Bulgaria; inv.nos. 1614-1735 (145 coins)

summary: A hoard of 257 denarii: Republic - Marcus Aurelius (AD 175-176).
disposition: Museum, Dortmund (243 coins); the Ruhr Valley Museum in Schwerte and Fröndenberg (14 coins)

summary: 2 sestertii of Antoninus Pius
(Unknown initial number of coins, 5.76 kg): 367 denarii: Nero - Commodus (AD 180-192).
Originally, 55 denarii, 12 preserved: Trajan - Clodius Albinus (AD 193); silver weight: 32.07 g. Two silver rings were found together.
669 denarii found with a ceramic vessel near a Carpic settlement: Republic – Marcus Aurelius (AD 166-167).
The hoard comprised 26 bronze coins and 3 silver coins dated between the reigns of Vespasian and Hadrian.
The hoard comprised 144 silver and two gold coins dated between 32-31 BC and AD 124-128, buried in a clay juglet.
32 coins: 1 republican denarius, 31 bronze coins: Augustus - Septimius Severus (AD 197-198).
112 denarii: Vespasian - Septimius Severus (AD 194-195).
107 denarii were found in a ceramic vessel together with 6 silver bracelets (3 pairs), a plated silver brooch and glass beads. No further informationn
9 sestertii from Trajan to Marcus Aurelius (AD 177-178).
Leather purse with 10 bronze rings and 11 bronze coins: Trajan - Antoninus Pius. Only one bronze coin of Antoninus Pius is known.
15 of the sestertii from a larger hoard were identified by S. Bottin. The hoard was originally located in Bellaing in error.
160-180 denarii found in a ceramic vessel - metal detecting - within an ancient settlement. The coins are dated to the 1st-2nd centuries AD.

A hoard of 8 complete and 1 halved Roman provincial copper alloy coins (Antioch, Beroea, Laodicea, uncertain) from the reigns of Trajan and Antoninus Pius, found at Assur, iC6V, West, 50 cm below the surface of the hill.
1,446 denarii found during construction activity: Republic - Marcus Aurelius/Commodus (AD 177-192).
disposition: Münzkabinett, Kunsthistorischen Museum, Vienna, Austria (964 coins)

summary: A little more than 20 coins were found (only 11 known and recorded). The coins were found while leveling two tumuli revealing some 'depots' of denarii Trajan - Commodus (AD 181-182).
3 coins, unknown denomination: Trajan, Hadrian and Marcus Aurelius (Caesar) (AD 145-161).
Unknown quantity of bronze coins. Three sestertii: Claudius I, Nero, Marcus Aurelius were offered to the Regional History Museum in Ruse.
disposition: Ruse Regional Museum of History, Bulgaria

summary: Group of six denarii found on the same area of an ancient settlement (?): Mark Antony - Antoninus Pius (AD 138-161/post). Similar structure with RATENICE 2002
Few hundreds, 150 were documented: Republic - Commodus (AD 186-187).
7 denarii: Trajan - Commodus (AD 180). Two other coins, one bronze and one bronze of the 4th century were handed together to the museum.
Originally 66 denarii, 55 preserved: Titus - Commodus (AD 188-189); silver weight: 155.21 g.

The hoard was found at a natural spring and comprised votives (including numerous wooden statuettes) as well as '149 copper coins of Roman emprors'. 79 of these coins were identified. The others were illegible.
The hoard comprised 'a vessel containing 100 sestertii': Antoninus Pius - Marcus Aurelius (AD 161-180).
278 denarii found with an small amphora: Trajan - Septimius Severus (AD 194-195).
disposition: National History Museum of Transylvania, Cluj-Napoca; Town Museum Gherla (20 coins), Romania

summary: The hoard comprised approximately 200 'small Roman bronzes' of the Antonine period, most of which were well preserved. Unfortunately, an acid bath rendered them indecipherable.
A hoard of five bronze coins (Philippi, Koinon of Macedonia, Topirus), found in grave T2 in Lithochori.

Udmarken on Bornholm has yielded three hoards with a total of 217 denarii. All three, A, B, C, have been interpreted as being of either the same hoard or of chronologically identical hoards. A and B were found a week apart in 1853 and C was found in 1857. Udmarken C contains seven of the 217 denarii.
Hoard of 177 denarii found with a ceramic vessel: Trajan - Septimius Severus (AD 197). Together were found two silver rings and one of gold.

Unknown originally number of coins. 10 denarii entered the collection of the Center for the Social Sciences in Craiova: Vitellius 1, Domitian 1, Trajan 1, Hadrian 1, Antoninus Pius 2, Antoninus Pius (Diva Faustina I) 1, Antoninus Pius (Marcus Aurelius Caesar) 2, Marcus Aurelius (Lucius Verus) 1.
disposition: Center for the Social Sciences, Craiova, Romania

summary: The hoard comprised a ceramic vessel containing 840 well-preserved sestertii, of which 808 were identified by Auvray. The composition of this hoard varies slightly in lists compiled by Ledru and Cauvin. L'annuaire l'An VIII mentions coins of Septimius Severus and of Caracalla from the same parish. It is possible that these were also a part of the hoard, although they have not been added to the database record.
22 denarii, part of a hoard: Vespasian - Clodius Albinus (AD 193-197).
103 denari: Vitellius - Septimius Severus (AD 197-198); silver weight: 262.8-420.7 g.
disposition: History Museum, Razgrad, Bulgaria; inv.no. IF, hoard 12 (103 coins).

summary: 1,022 denarii: Republic – Commodus (AD 180-192). The first lot of coins was found in 1943, the second one it was pretended to have been discovered in 1970 at the same place and by the same person. In fact there was just one hoard.
disposition: History Museum, Piatra Neamț, Romania (537 coins)

summary: 12 denarii (Hadrian and Antoninus Pius) found among charcoal, animal bone, and other debris inside the furnace next to Turret 1.

The 16 coins listed here (14 sestertii and two dupondii, ranging from Trajan to Marcus Aurelius) were found in the area of the Dampfziegelei in 1897 and 1898. All coins have the same patina and corrosion, so it could be a hoard. Further particulars about the circumstances of the find are undetermined.
Around 200 denarii. Among them issues of Nero, Vitellius, Vespasian, Titus, Domitian, Trajan and Hadrian.
Over 600 bronze coins found with ceramic vessel. Only 11 pieces are recorded: Vespasian - Marcus Aurelius (Lucilla) (AD 163-164).
disposition: Museu Nacional de Arqueología e Etnología, Lisboa, Portugal

summary: 41 Alexandrian bronze coins: Trajan - Marcus Aurelius (Faustina II) (AD 164-165). Found during excavations .
disposition: Exhibited in London 1902, now in Toronto. Detailed list in Oxford

summary: More than 188 billon provincial coins of Alexandria: Nero - Marcus Aurelius (Lucius Verus) (AD 161-169). 'Found at Avenue of the Sphinxes during clearance excavations.'
The hoard comprised 53 sestertii terminating in issues of Antoninus Pius and 'the young Marcus Aurelius'.
22 denarii found on a cultivated field: Vespasian - Marcus Aurelius (AD 174).
disposition: Gabinet Numizmatyczno-Sfragistyczny, Zakład Narodowy im. Ossolińskich, Wrocław, Poland

summary: Hoard of nine aurei found in a ceramic vessel: Hadrian, Antoninus Pius 3, Antoninus Pius (Diva Faustina I) 1, Marcus Aurelius 4 (AD 177-178).
(50) 25 denarii: Vespasian - Antoninus Pius (AD 138-161). Found together with a silver bracelet.
Around 800 denarii, among them issues of Trajan, Hadrian and Marcus Aurelius.
Two denarii found above ground in 1921, assumed to have derived from a ditch dug at the site.

Over 486 silver and bronze coins found in four ceramic vessels. Found 3 m from KRISTENDORF 1. Vessel a: 38 denarii: Mark Antony 2, Nero 1, Vitellius 1, Vespasian 11, Titus 1, Domitian 4, Nerva 1, Trajan 3, Antoninus Pius 5, Faustina I 4, Marcus Aurelius 1, Faustina II 2, Lucilla 1, Commodus 1. Vessel b: 151 sestertii: Galba 1, Vespasian 1, Titus 2, Domitian 2, Trajan 12, Hadrian 23, Antoninus Pius 28, Faustina I 11, Marcus Aurelius 24, Faustina II 13, Lucius Verus 5, Lucilla 7, Commodus 15, Septimius Severus 5, Julia Damna 1, Caracalla 1. Vessel c: 237 bronze coins: Vespasian 1, Titus 1, Domitian 3, Trajan 13, Hadrian 41, Sabina 2, Antoninus Pius 32, Faustina II 11, Marcus Aurelius 56, Faustina II 34, Lucius Verus 6, Lucilla 8, Commodus 24, Crispina 1, uncertain 4. Vessel d: 60 sestertii: Titus 1, Nerva 1, Trajan 3, Hadrian 5, Sabina 1, Antoninus Pius 13, Faustina I 2, Marcus Aurelius 14, Faustina II 11, Lucilla 2, Commodus 4, Crispina 1, uncertain 2.
9 coins: 1 aureus, 3 denarii, 1 sestertius, 4 asses: Galba - Hadrian (AD 117-138)
More than 800 originally number of coins found with a ceramic vessel. 441 coins: 406 sestertii, 29 dupondii, 5 asses, 1 AE provincial: Vespasian - Commodus (AD 186-187).
disposition: Archaeological Museum, Namur, Belgium (443 coins); Cabinet des Médailles, Bruxelles, Belgium (1 coin).

summary: The hoard (5 bronze coins ranging from Domitian to Faustina I) was found in 1964 northwest of the Jewish cemetery in house pit 27-29 of Ernst-Kahn-straße, in a depth of 30 cm. The coins lay in a varnished pot. The hoard remain in private possession.
35 denarii: Mark Antony - Marcus Aurelius (AD 161-162).
Around 300 denarii possible found with a leather bag. 134 coins provide information on the issuers: Vespasian - Septimius Severus (AD 193-211).
disposition: Archaeological Museum, Krakow (132 coins); private collection, Gnojni (2 coins)

summary: 16 coins: 1 denarius, 15 bronzes were found as "cast bronze core" of 570g.
The hoard comprised of 27 aurei from Nero to Hadrian. 26 are identified.

A hoard of 5+ Roman provincial coins (Thessalonica: 1; Amphipolis: 4, Marcus Aurelius and Commodus), found in a grave in Amphipolis (Grave 1) in 1953. Archives in the Ephorate mention 18 further coins, but these could not be traced any more.
The hoard comprised 118 sestertii found with a ceramic vessel: Domitian-Commodus (90-183 AD). Most of the coins are kept in a private collection (Antonio Egger).
disposition: Museo Civico di Bassano (26 coins); Museo Bottacin di Padova (6 coins); private collection Egger family (86 coins).

summary: 13 silver coins: 10 denari, 3 cistophori: Domitian - Septimius Severus (AD 193-194). Found with traces of a textile bag.
Originally, 1,500 denarii and a drachm found with a clay vessel. 1,391 coins preserved: Nero - Septimius Severus (AD 193-194); silver weight: 3,924.6 g. (1.391 coins).
The hoard was found in April 1841, in an ceramic vessel under a stone. It comprised 140 sestertii, dupondii and 1 as, all from the antonine dynasty.
Three denarii (Nerva - Faustina II), found with others on a field in Halsmühlen.

In 1867 a hoard of denarii was discovered in a sand hill on the left bank of the Oste river two miles from the estuary. The six preserved coins run from Vespasian to Commodus. It is to be assumed that the hoard was composed of more specimens.

The circumstances of discovery and the composition of the hoard were judged to be suspect. De Vesly questioned whether this hoard might actually have been stolen and assembled as a hoard. However, there is nothing to support this hypothesis. Found by a workman in a quarry in the Duclair forest: Nero - Hadrian (AD 125-128). Two or four coins are missing.

In 1925 a hoard comprising 1081 bronze coins, originally included in a pottery vessel, was found after agricoltural works. Coins inlcuded in this hoard returned to the finders and went missing, except for 1 sestertius of Didia Clara now kept in the Museum Bottacin in Padua. Only a brief report on the coins included in the hoard is now available.
26 sestertii: Trajan - Septimius Severus (AD 195).
The hoard comprised 'more than 500 coins of uncertain denomination and type' but including issues from Vespasian to Commodus (AD 180-192).
38 bronze coins found in a small sewer found as one block: Vespasian - Commodus (AD
Some aurei. Only five are presented from Nero to Antoninus Pius (Marcus Aurelius Caesar).
(49) 48 denarii: 35 republican, 13 imperial: Republic - Trajan (AD 101/102) .
Hoard of 17 denarii (Mark Antony - Augustus) and 29 sestertii (Nerva - Hadrian) (AD 117-138).
A hoard of 48 denarii, ranging from Vespasian to Commodus, discovered in the fortress of Gaṙni in 1955.
Hoard of circa 100 denarii. 18 coins were documented: Antoninus Pius - Commodus (AD 180-192). Weight: 29.86.

A hoard of 197 denarii (Mark Antony to Trajan), found in a 'rude earthen vessel', while ploughing a field in 1874 near Lavenham Lodge. Of these, 184 were examined and 183 published, the others were dispersed.
12 bronze coins found stuck together, in a barrow: 5 dupondii, 7 asses: Hadrian - Antoninus Pius (AD 160-161).
disposition: National History and Archaeology Museum, Constanța, Romania (inv.nos. 81602-81613)

summary: This hoard was found in three ceramic pots and contained more than 4000 silver coins from which H. Ceka has published a total of about 3900 Roman Imperial coins in 1958. According to the publication of the hoard, which refers to the inquiry held by the Albanian Institutions at the time of the discovery, the hoard was constituted by silver coins and gold jewelry (rings, necklaces) but the latter was dispersed immediately after the discovery. Also, more than 100 coins were dispersed after the discovery. The coins are mostly Denarius dating from Nero to Marcus Aurelius (54-175 AD). Based on the numismatic data (there is no archaeological excavation that can help at the precision of the hoard's burying date), it should have been buried around or short after 170 AD.
disposition: The hoard is actually part of the collection of the Coin Cabinet, Institute of Archaeology, Albania

summary: 180 sestertii, for 109 the issuers are known: Vespasian - Marcus Aurelius (AD 161-180).
disposition: Kärntner Landsmannschaft, Klagenfurt (95 coins); 5 in Prfratbesitz; Museum St. Veit an der Glan (12 coins); 5 private collection, Austria

summary: Coin hoard consisting of 54 Roman sestertii (Domitian - Commodus) was discovered in 1922 while excavating an old lime tree. The coins were stratified in three layered rolls. They have been lost.
3 coins, of which one aureus of Trajan (AD 114-117).
The hoard comprised 86 denarii from Mark Antony to Antoninus Pius (AD 143).

A small hoard of 12 Roman Imperial denarii: Trajan - Commodus (AD 180-192) was discovered by a treasure hunter in early summer 2020. According to the finder the coins were found in a “small area” and represent “the contents of a purse”. The further fate of the coins is unknown: Trajan (1), Antoninus Pius (4), Marcus Aurelius (4), Commodus (1), unknown (2).
Over 600 denarii found while digging up a grave. Only 6 pieces provide information on the issuers: Trajan - Commodus (AD 179-180).
Around 100 denarii found with a ceramic vessel. Only 29 coins were recovered and sherds from the vessel: Vespasian – Commodus (Divus Marcus Aurelius ) (AD 180).
(200) 17 sestertii: Trajan - Marcus Aurelius (AD 11-180).
The hoard comprised approximately 100 aurei from Nero to Hadrian. Only 7 were examined: Nero, Vespasian, Trajan 2, Hadrian 3.
disposition: Museo Arqueológico Provincial de Oviedo, Spain (7 coins)

summary: A hoard of 200-300 mainly gold coins (Claudius - Hadrian), found while digging peat in Gustorf in 1838/1839. Several finders are reported. Some coins were bought by the Berlin Münzkabinett (16 gold, 2 silver and 3 bronze coins).
Hoard discovered on the surface and during the archaeological investigations: Trajan – Septimius Severus (Clodius Albinus Caesar) (AD 193).
disposition: History Museum, Târgu Neamț (23 coins); History Museum, Piatra Neamț (7 coins); private collections (6 coins)

summary: 35 sestertii, 707.80 g, found on a field ranging from Vespasian/Titus to Commodus (AD 186).
11 denarii found in a purse (vanished): Mark Antony - Hadrian (AD 125-128)
disposition: Centrul de Studii de Istorie și Arheologie, Timișoara, Romania; inv.no. 237/2005

summary: 65 Roman silver coins found a small urn or earthern vessel, while removing the root of a tree near the house of Mr. Burke, at Beaconsfield. The coins ranged from Vespasian to Faustina.
(c. 400) 3 denarii: Nero - Hadrian (AD 117-138).
disposition: Archaeological Museum Charleroi, Belgium 13 coins, only 5 retrieved)

summary: The hoard comprised 116 silver coins: 111 denarii, 1 denarius serratus, 2 quinarii, 2 drachms: Republic - Antoninus Pius (AD 157-158). Found in a ceramic vessel with a terra sigillata bowl serving as a lid.
6 Roman imperial bronze coins. The latest one is a sestertius of Antoninus Pius: Gaius - Antoninus Pius (AD 138-161).
A bronze jug containing 160 aurei, found on site 29 in Corbridge. Two bronze coins were found filling the narrow neck of the jug, where they had been placed, to act as a stopper to the narrow neck.
A hoard of 5 denarii (Vitellius - Lucilla), found while digging peat not far from Nauen. A connection with the hoard of BUCHOW-KARPZOW (ID 17335) has been postulated.
Five denarii: Vespasian, Hadrian, Antoninus Pius, Marcus Aurelius, Marcus Aurelius (Faustina II Augusta) (AD 172-173).
Forty-eight Roman denarii were found with a ceramic vessel in the rubble of a Sarmatian house in 1995 in the area of ​​an Avar burial ground in Hetényegyháza.
5 or 6 silver denarii. The coins were originally corroded together. Three coins were separated, leaving a stack of either 2 or 3 denarii.
37 denarii: Antoninus Pius - Marcus Aurelius (AD 161-180). No details on the structure.
215 denarii: Nero to Marcus Aurelius (AD 166).

Two denarii of Antoninus Pius, the first 'found on the Laleston by-pass road behind (SE. of) the Mackworth Inn', the second 'found during road widening on the Cardiff-Swansea road, near the A.A. Box west of Laleston'. One might suspect that both coins came from the same hoard, scattered by workmen somewhere near Laleston.
14 denarii: Domitian - Marcus Aurelius (Commodus Augustus) (AD 177); silver weight: 38.41 g.
27 denarii: Vespasian - Marcus Aurelius (AD 161-180).
Hoard of 340 denarii were found with a bronze cauldron. Together was a silver ring.
disposition: The State Hermitage Museum, St. Petersburg, Russia

summary: Treasure numbers associated with this hoard: 2013 T096. Other PAS records associated with this hoard: DEV-269707
47 de denarii with very poor information on the contents: Hadrian - Marcus Aurelius (AD 161-180).
36 denarii found in the military amphitheater: Mark Antony - Marcus Aurelius (AD 166).
disposition: Museum Carnuntinum, Bad-Deutsch Altenburg, Austria (29 coins); 7 coins lost

summary: 76 gold coins found in the nineties: Nero - Marcus Aurelius (AD
5 denarii: Trajan - Antoninus Pius (AD 145-161) found during excavations.
disposition: Muzeul Dunării de Jos, Călărași, Romania; inv.nos. 46511-46514, 46518

summary: 287 bronze coins: Augustus - Marcus Aurelius/Commodus for Crispina (Augusta) (AD 178-183).
Unknown initial number of denarii. 11 denarii provided information on the issuers: Trajan - Commodus (AD 183-184).
disposition: Zasadniczej Szkoły Zawodowej w Krasniku Fabrycznym, Poland (1 coin)

summary: Approx. 200 Roman silver coins found by chance as a waggon had crushed the jar that contained them. One of the accounts relating to this find gives a list of emperors: Nero, Vespasian, Titus, Domitian, Nerva, Trajan, Hadrian, the two Antonines, Faustina and L. Aelius Verus.
The hoard comprised 31 sestertii, stacked one on top of the other, suggesting that they may have originally been packed in a tube or similar which has not survived: Nerva - Commodus (AD 189).
17 denarii and 1 aureus: Gaius - Hadrian (AD 121-123).
14 denarii: Claudius I – Marcus Aurelius (Lucilla) (AD 161-180).
disposition: National museum, Prague, Czech Republic (11 coins)

summary: The hoard was discovered near the village in 2011. Consisted of 13 denarii (Trajan-Pertinax). The circumstances of the find and the place of the coins storage are unknown.
Circa 150 bronze coins. Only 2 sestertii and 2 dupondii of Antoninus Pius and Marcus Aurelius were seen.
2 denarii of Trajan and Hadrian.
26 denarii found in three separate finds (1921, 1924, and 1946): Hadrian - Septimius Severus (AD 194).

28 bronze coins found near a skeleton: 27 provincial coins minted on Cyprus (uncertain mint under Augustus and Tiberius; Koinon of Cyprus for Claudius, Vespasian, and Trajan) and 1 sestertius of Trajan (AD 114-117).

The hoard comprised at least 227 silver coins: 119 Nabatean denarii, 14 provincial tetradrachms of Antioch, 5 didrachms reattributed to Antioch (Trajan), 5 tridrachms and 33 drachms of Trjan reattributed to an Arabian mint, and 51 imperial denarii, down to AD 122.
disposition: Israel Antiquities Authority (108), Ecole Biblique, Amman Museum

summary: Unknown originally number of coins. 26 denarii are known at the moment: Nero – Marcus Aurelius (AD 169-170).

The hoard comprised a ceramic vessel containing approximately 350 sestertii of which 250 were too worn to identify. Hahn compiled a catalogue of 107 examples which is given here. A news article mentions a sestertius of Severus Alexander which is not included in Hahn's catalogue which may or may not be part of the hoard.

The hoard comprised a total of 1,133 coins, including 1,031 sestertii, 68 dupondii, 26 asses, 3 dupondii or asses and 5 imitations: Gaius - Commodus (AD 188-189). They were found during the excavation of building C in a Gallo-Roman vicus.
83 denarii: Nero - Hadrian (AD 117-138).
The hoard comprised 13 provincial tetradrachms dated between AD 60-61 and AD 107-110.
Two denarii found on a field: Antoninus Pius, Commodus (AD 185).
Around 700 denarii found with a ceramic vessel, of which 167 provided information on the issuers: Nero - Marcus Aurelius (Lucius Verus) (AD 161-169).
disposition: Museum of History, Lwow, Poland; private collection

summary: 84 silver coins found with a ceramic vessel; Trajan - Marcus Aurelius (AD 166); weight: 281 g.
disposition: Muzeului de Istorie și Arheologie, Piatra-Neamț, Romania

summary: 37 sestertii found during rescue excavations. 32 coins were found in a ceramic jug and 5 next to it: Vespasian - Commodus (Divus Marcus Aurelius) (AD 180).
A hoard of 121 denarii (Nero - Marcus Aurelius), found at the edge of the gravel pit northeast of Schwepnitz, approx. 0.3 km east of the Schwepnitz - Gottschdorf road.
The hoard comprised 53 copper-alloy coins from Trajan to Marcus Aurelius (AD 161-180).
Mr. I.L. Faingold may have inherited a hoard of 100 denarii from his father. 44 coins were documented: Galba - Commodus (AD 190).
disposition: University Museum, Kyiv, Ukraine (44 coins until 1917)

summary: 74 denarii: Vespasian – Commodus (AD 180-192).
228 denarii: Vitellius - Marcus Aurelius/Commodus (Crispina) (AD 177-191).
Hoard of 500 coins of the Bosporan kings: Ininthimeus, Rhescuporis IV and V.
322 coins found in a ceramic vessel: 1 aureus, 302 denarii, 18 bronze pieces. Only 242 coins were recovered: Vespasian to Antoninus Pius (AD 138-161).
Hoard of didrachms and drachms of the 1st and 2nd centuries AD. 8 coins have been purchased by the local museum in Zugdidi: 5 didrachms Trajan, 2 didrachms Hadrian, 1 drachm Trajan.
Unknown number of denarii found in two small ceramic vessels placed 100 m from each other. 38 pieces are known from one of the vessels: Republic - Marcus Aurelius (AD 163-164).
disposition: Ruse Regional Museum of History, Bulgaria; inv.no. 1600 44-81

summary: 514 imperial bronze coins: Nerva - Commodus (AD 180-192).
disposition: Collection J. Marcello, Soprintendenza Archeologica di Padova, Italy

summary: 51 denarii: 16 republican, 35 imperial: Republic - Hadrian (AD 119-122). Together was found a Dacian silver bracelet.

A cultic area with two temples was excavated southwest of the intersection of Groß-Umstädter straße/Aschaffenburger straße. One of the two temples had a quadratic cella, corresponding to the Gallo-Roman type. A small hoard of 5 bronze coins (Trajan to Antoninus Pius) and a complete set of cultic vessels was found in its immediate vicinity.
Circa 300 denarii were discovered while plowing. Denarii of Antoninus Pius and Commodus were mentioned.
About 40 AR denarii found during construction of Bowers Fold redevelopment in 1963. The hoard was unreported and dispersed, two coins of Hadrian bought by Doncaster Museum.

47 denarii ranging from Nero to Hadrian (1 Nero, 3 Vespasian, 4 Titus, 6 Domitian, 3 Nerva, 20 Trajan, 10 Hadrian) were given to the Historisches Museum in Olten by the Schmid family in 1901/1902, next to 13 other Roman coins. Records say that all of these belonged to a find made in the vicinity of Matzendorf in 1841, but probably only the denarii are part of a hoard. No further details of the discovery are known.
It comprised c. 500 denarii found with a vessel:Domitian - Commodus (AD 180-192).
Unknown originally number of coins. Only five coins are recorded. Uncertain whether they were found together.
disposition: Museu de Martins Sarmento, Guimarães. Portugal

summary: A farmer in 1864 found over 60 specimens of Roman silver coins during plowing on a small hill in the vicinity of Erfurt. 29 coins were described (Trajan - Marcus Aurelius).
4 denarii up to Commodus found in an arm purse.
The hoard comprised 9 aurei found near the 'Caserne' of Autun. The aurei dated from Vespasian to Faustina I, and may be just a small part of a more important hoard.
514 denarii found in a ceramic vessel: Augustus - Antoninus Pius (AD 138-161).
410 denarii: Galba - Marcus Aurelius/Commodus (AD 161-192).
disposition: Museum of Archaeology, Plovdiv, Bulgaria; inv.no. 2519

summary: "In 1847 a small pot containing 8 Roman coins - a silver denarius of Trajan and 7 bronze coins, including one of Trajan - was found in cutting through a hedge or earth bank on the boundary between the parishes of Upton and Withiel Florey. Two of the coins are in the Spencer G Perceval collection" (Pastscape)
175 silver coins: 173 denarii, 1 quinarius and 1 drachm: Republic - Marcus Aurelius (AD 161-180).
disposition: Stadtmuseum, Neunkirchen (165 coins), private collection? (10 coins), Austria; lost (unknown no.)

summary: The hoard comprised 4 coins including one earlier coin of Thasos (2nd c. BC) and two Roman Provincial coins: Philippoi (1 imperial period), Topeiros (1 Antoninus Pius) and a further 1 unidentified coin, found in grave T11 in Lithochori.
The hoard comprised 9 figurines, 1 patera and 7 bronze coins from Vespasian to Commodus.
The deposit was found at the major Gallo-Roman spring sanctuary site at comprised three asses from Hadrian to Marcus Aurelius with a tpq of AD 164.

In 1962 an excavator found a jar with 7 aurei, 1346 denarii (Nero - Marcus Aurelius), and 4 Lycian drachms (Domitian - Trajan), while building the foundations of the new building for the paper mill factory at Stockstadt.
disposition: The majority of the find was sent to Aschaffenburg Municipal Museum

summary: The hoard comprised 4 sestertii ranging from Trajan to Faustina II. They were recovered during the excavation of a inhumation burial (tomb 2/1957) in the necropolis and were interpreted as the contents of a purse. Only 2 coins preserved, but descriptions of all of them exist.
disposition: Ufficio dei beni culturali, Bellinzona (2 coins); lost (2 coins)

summary: A hoard of 10 aurei (Domitian - Antoninus Pius), found in the 1880s in Trier, in a small earthenware container; it was published in 1928 as part of the collection of Dr. Leopold Seligmann.
21 bronze coins (Vespasian-Hadrian) published in am auction catalogue without details on the circumstances of discovery.
(c. 260) 77 sestertii: Vespasian - Marcus Aurelius (Lucius Verus) (AD 163-164)
408 denari found by metal detecting: Nero - Hadrian. No further detail.

2nd century. Hoard of 8 coins recovered with a frag. of a bronze vessel, possibly its original container. The coins all exclusively 2nd C terminating with issue of Crispina (AD 177-183), though hoard may have been deposited in 3rd C AD.Rudling, D. 1982. The Romano-British farm on Bullock Down. In P. Drewett (ed.) The Archaeology of Bullock Down, Eastbourne, East Sussex.
Five denarii found together: Vespasian – Antoninus Pius (AD 138-161).
The hoard comprised 60 silver coins and some bronzes, including one of Faustina I.

A hoard of at least 259 Roman imperial denarii was found by treasure hunters in 2016 in Cherkasy region. On October 4, 2016, a video of the process of sondage at the site where the hoard was found by seven treasure hunters was published on YouTube, on the “Sokrovische nacii” (“Treasure of the Nation”) channel. A few days earlier, another group of treasure hunters found a batch of denarii - 192 specimens - on the surface (up to 15 cm deep in an area of about 10x10 m) of a ploughed field. Then, on October 4, on this place was made several sondages (approx. 2-3x1 m), in which, at a depth of 40-50 cm was found another 67 coins (each of the seven treasure hunters took as many coins as they found). According to the assumption of one of the treasure hunters there may be more coins at this place. The video footage shows coins with traces of patina, among which can be distinguished denarii of Hadrian (incl. for Sabina), Antoninus Pius (incl. for Faustina I), Marcus Aurelius (incl. for Faustina II), Commodus. The further fate of the coins is unknown.
Several hundred Roman silver coins (coins of Galba - Antoninus Pius / Marcus Aurelius are mentioned), found during building working in Minden, in or before 1844. The coins were lost.
14 denarii: Domitian 3; Nerva 3; Trajan 6; uncertain (Domitian or Trajan) 1; Hadrian 1 (AD 117-138).
(460) 452 denarii found with a ceramic vessel: M. Antony - Marcus aurelius (AD 176-180).
A hoard of ca. 300 denarii, found in 1842, during peat digging, close to the so-called 'Römerbrücke' in the Bourtanger Moor. The coins are now lost, except for two.
Five aurei found in grave no. 6: Nero, Galba, Hadrian, Antoninus Pius, Commodus (AD 180-192). Together were found 11 drachms of Gotarze and 3 denarii of Augustus.

A hoard found in Barton Wood, consisting of nearly a gallon measure of Roman brass coins. The coins, from being originally deposited in a box, had become so corroded, that they were unable easily to be separated, and in the attempt to effect this separation by a strong liquid the coins were rendered nearly illegible. Some were, however, rescued for the Newport Museum, and include an Augustus, a Trajan, two of Antoninus Pius, two of Lucius Verus, and two of Faustina, wife of Marcus Aurelius.
(c. 550) 165 denarii found with a ceramic vessel: Nero - Commodus (AD 181-191).
3,728 denarii: Republic - M. Aurelius (AD 166-167)
disposition: Archaeological Museum, Veliko Tarnovo, Bulgaria; inv.nos. 2599-3353 (3626 coins)

summary: During excavations on the site of the ancient town of Lyka, a hoard of 7 provincial coins of the Koinon of Macedonia (Hadrian - Faustina II) was found in trench II, in a very burnt layer, near a cencer and in the same depth with it and nearby silver votive plaques with relief representation. These have been interpreted as remnants of a ritual act, a "sealed group" of votive offerings in honour of a deity.
Report in BM file with information from Suffolk county Council on a group of 7 or 8 coins, only three readily identifiable. Details of the latter only were received.
The hoard comprised 11 bronze coins dated between 175-164 BC and AD 117-138.
Six denarii found together on a floor of a Roman edifice from the Dacian kingdom capital of Sarmizegetusa Regia Republic - Trajan (AD 101-102).
disposition: Muzeul Civilizației Dacice și Romane, Deva, Romania

summary: The hoard comprised 16 denarii dated between AD 98/99 and AD 128/129.
73 bronze coins: Vespasian - Commodus (AD 180-192).
52 aurei ranging from Nero (AD 63/66) to Marcus Aurelius (AD 164), found at the Stephansgasse, in the foundations of a stone building. This hoard could be connected with the Marcomannic wars.
Five denarii (Vespasian - Commodus Caesar), found together on the premises of the Pipinsburg (a megalithic hillfort of Viking times), close to Sievern.

The denarii (Vespasian - Trajan) were found together with a bronze brooch in the main building of a villa rusticate, located between Altdorf and Jülich-Kirchberg, on the site of the Inden open pit mining site (Braunkohletagebau Inden).

A hoard of denarii was found approx. 0.7 km northwest of Ausleben, on the Ausleber Hoch (alt. 135 m) in a probable neolithic grave mound. 142 coins (Otho-Commodus) were described, but the total amount of coins is unknown.
Hoard of circa 60 denarii: Nero - Commodus (AD 180-192). Only 18 denarii were documented.
2 denarii - Antoninus Pius for Diva Faustina I and Marcus Aurelius found together with 4 gold bracteates.
Two denarii found together: Hadrian, Marcus Aurelius.
70 denarii: 69 Rome issues, 1 imitation: Trajan - Commodus (AD 187-188). Together, it was found a ring made of a silver-coloured metal.
5 denarii from Vespasian (Domitian) to Antoninus Pius (M. Aurelius). Part of a larger hoard, details unknown.
Unknown number of denarii. There is information on four coins: Hadrian, Antoninus Pius, Marcus Aurelius (Caesar), Faustina I/II (AD 138-180).
236 aurei and denarii from the time of Marcus Aurelius (AD 161-180).
The hoard was found in a ceramic vessel hidden under a stone and comprised 3 coins including a sestertius of Nerva, a denarius of Trajan and an as of Hadrian.
Unknown originally number of coins. 86 bronze coins: Tiberius - Hadrian (AD 119-120).
disposition: Museo Arqueológico Provincial de Orense, Spain; private collections of M. Taborda and X. Taborda

summary: 2500-3000 denarii. 250 pieces were bought by the National Museum in Sofia: Vespasian - Marcus Aurelius (AD 161-180).
666 coins: 665 denarii, 1 drachm: Nero – Antoninus Pius (AD 140).
Penhallurick (2009, 245 no. 251) records a metal detector find of 9 sestertii found in an area of about 50 square metres in the same field. Considered to be part of a scattered hoard.
The hoard comprised a large number of Roman coins which were shared out between the finders. Fournier compiled a list, suggesting that 39 were of Nerva (and Trajan?) and 42 of Hadrian.
Initially 368 denarii, nowadays, 367: Vitellius - Septimius Severus (AD 193-194); silver weight: 1009.47 g.
disposition: The National Historical Museum, Stockholm (inv.no. 10155/1-167, 169-368); Stockholm Numismatic Institute, Stockholm (inv.no. 179)

summary: 14 copper coins, reported as dated between possibly 69 and 117 AD, but inter alia Vespasian, Domitian, Hadrian, so 69-138 in any case.
13 denarii from a discovery in the surroundings of the city: Vespasian - Marcus Aurelius (AD 177-178).
14 bronze coins: 10 dupondii, 4 asses: Tiberius - Marcus Aurelius (Lucilla) (AD 164-169).

A hoard of 111 Roman imperial denarii was found by five treasure hunters in 2013 in Chernivtsi region. Information about the find and photos of some of the coins of the hoard were published by one of the finders on January 20, 2014 on the Ukrainian treasure hunter forum Violity. According to the finder, the hoard was found late at night, but there is no more detailed information about the further circumstances of the find. Judging by the information from the treasure hunter, the bulk of the coins in the hoard were denarii of Vespasian, Trajan and Hadrian, although there was also a coin of Galba, several denarii of Nerva, and 10-12 coins of Antoninus Pius and Faustina (I or II). In the photographs posted with the hoard information, there are images of 26 whole and five fragments of denarii (Vespasian, Terva, Trajan, Hadrian, Antoninus Pius) – these were probably some of the coins that the informant found. The further fate of the coins in the hoard is unknown.
Three denarii found on a field: Trajan 1, Lucilla 1, Faustina II/Lucilla 1
Several hundred denarii found with an iron jar. Only six provided data on the issuers: Hadrian - Commodus.
The hoard comprised 22 denarii overstruck by the Bar Kokhba administration (AD 132-136).
Unknown number of silver coins. One denarius of Trajan and one of Hadrian are kept in the museum in Ruse.
disposition: Ruse Regional Museum of History, Bulgaria; inv.no. 9, 553

summary: Around 418 silver coins: 416 denarii, 2 drachms: Nero - Marcus Aurelius (Lucilla) (AD 164-180).
disposition: Muzeum, Koszalinie; Muzeum Zamojskie, Zamość; private collections, Poland

summary: 11 denarii found on the same field: Caesar – Vespasian (AD 69-79).
30 denarii: Republic - Marcus Aurelius (AD 161-180), latest coin, AD 156-157.
disposition: Rijksmuseum van Oudheden Leiden, Netherlands; inv.no. 17379

summary: 12 denarii entered the collection of the Pedagogic High-School in Iași: Vitellius – Hadrian (AD 125-128). Part of the hoards Strunga I and II.
271 denarii found with a ceramic vessel. 268 handed to the National Museum in Bucharest: Nero - Marcus Aurelius. One denarius may depict Julia Domna?
disposition: National Museum of History, Bucharest, Romania; Museum of History and Archaeology, Piatra Neamț, Romania (the vessel)

summary: Originally 312 denarii, 299 preserved: Nero - Septimius Severus (AD 193-194); silver weight: 758.24 g. (299 coins).
