115 denarii: Vespasian - Septimius Severus (AD 193-194); silver weight: 354 g
Five denarii (Vespasian - Antoninus Pius), found while digging for peat in the vicinity of the Buchow-Karpzow estate, probably only part of a larger find.
(ca. 600) 569 denarii: Mark Antony - Commodus (AD 180-192)
disposition: National Archaeological Institute with Museum, Sofia, Bulgaria; inv. no. ХХХІІІ - 398 coins

summary: A hoard of 150 denarii found in a ceramic vessel, covered by another ceramic vessel: Trajan - Septimius Severus (AD 193).
The hoard comprised 65 bronze coins dated between 294-283 BC and AD 117-138.

Six (or more?) Roman gold coins found on a field. First, three were found by labourers in 1845: Domitian (1 coin) and Hadrian (2 coins). Then came a report that "two years ago" two aurei of Vespasian had been found in the same field, and probably more, thrown out by the labourers as brass items. In 1860 another gold coin found in the same field was reported. - The 3 aurei found in 1845 were described in detail and documented in sealing wax (lost) and later copied in drawings (preserved).
188 bronze coins fund in a ceramic vessel: 151 sestertii, 16 dupondii, 4 dupondii/asses, 17 asses: Domitian - Marcus Aurelius (AD 177).
160 denarii, 80 recovered: 41 republican, 39 imperial: Republic - Trajan (AD 102-103).
disposition: National Museum of Union, Alba Iulia, Romania

summary: 157 denarii were found but details were only provided for 37 coins: Vespasian - Hadrian (AD 117-138)
disposition: Archaeological Museum in Zagreb (37 coins); dispersed

summary: Two denarii: Trajan, Marcus Aurelius.

11 AR denarii to AD 122. Latest coin is type of Hadrian-Fortuna referring to the departure of the emperor on his great expedition, AD 121-5. RIC assigns date range of AD 119-122.Addenda of 3 AR denarii to 117 in 2014 included here.
11 denarii: Vespasian – Commodus (Divus Marcus Aurelius ) (AD 181).
Unknown number of denarii. 933 denarii are kept in the museum collection in Silistra: Nero - M. Aurelius (AD 162-163).
52 denarii: Vespasian - Commodus (AD 186-187); silver weight: 135.15 g.
Unknown originally number of coins. Only 11 denarii are known: Vespasian 2, Titus 1, Nerva 2, Trajan 3, Hadrian 3.
Two denarii of Hadrian (AD 134-138).
In 1857/8 at least 11 denarii ranging from Vespasian to Hadrian were found during building work in the basement of a house.
771 denarii: Nero - Marcus Aurelius (AD 179-180); Septimius Severus coin is an intruder. There were two ceramic vessels buried at 2 m one from the other at the same depth of 0.25 m.
disposition: National Museum of History Bucharest; Museum of History and Archaeology Piatra Neamț (Romania)

summary: 47 denarii. Only 5 coins are kept in the Museum of Assen: Hadrian - Marcus Aurelius (AD 176)
Circa 500 denarii, of which 264 were brought after 1873 to the National Hungarian Museum in Budapest. 168 coins were identified: Nero – Antoninus Pius (Diva Faustina I) (AD 141-161).
11 denarii found with a cooking pot: Vespasian - Hadrian (AD 134-135)
12 denarii found with a ceramic vessel: Vespasian - Hadrian (AD 125-127).
34 coins found by Caspar Reuvens in 1828: 2 denarii, 3 sestertii, 15 asses, 6 dupondii, 6 dupondius/as, others unclear: Nerva - Hadrian (AD 117-138).
The hoard comprised a vessel containing several hundred bronze coins from Trajan to Antoninus Pius.

A hoard of approximately 100 sestertii, dupondii and asses (Augustus - Commodus), found 500 m east of the village of Allaman, while digging the ground to install phone cables. 58 coins are preserved today (= ca. 60% of the hoard). The coins were heavily worn.
disposition: Musée cantonal d'archéologie et d'histoire, Monnaies et Médailles, Lausanne

summary: 28 antoniniani (radiates): Gordian III - Valerian I (AD 258-259); silver weight: 35.0g.
212 coins were preserved. They comprise radiates, Reform radiates of Aurelian and 3 denarii of Severina
disposition: Museu da Região Flaviense, Chaves, Portugal

summary: On the basis of their condition and inventory numbers the coins perhaps also belong to the complex of the Keplerstraße hoard, see CHRE ID 3713.
8 provincial bronze coins: Caracalla - Gordian III (AD 238-244)
disposition: History Museum, Lovech, Bulgaria; inv.no. 1482 (8 coins)

summary: The hoard comprised two separate parcels of coins concealed within a cist constructed with five bricks and covered with a silver embossed leaf. The first parcel comprised nearly 700 sestertii dating from Galba to Severus Alexander. The second parcel, wrapped in fragments of linen, comprised denarii and radiates from Trajan to Volusian.

The hoard comprised a mass of coins which were concreted together. It is estimated that there were as many as 5,000. However, only 130 examples were cleaned. These were found to be of the emperors Gallienus and Probus.
2,648 antoniniani (radiates) in a lump of over 5 kg: Trebonianus Gallus - Aurelian (AD 270-275).
disposition: Landesmuseum, Klagenfurt; Münzkabinett, Kunsthistorischen Museum, Vienna, Austria (16 coins)

summary: In a cavern, without precise location, found during blast operations. Ca. 80 coins, mainly from the 3rd c. AD: Postumus (Gallic Empire, 260–269), Gallienus (253–268), Salonina (wife of Gallienus), Claudius II (268–270), Victorinus (269–270) and Aurelian (270–275) among other emperors of the 3rd c. AD. Later reports mention coins of Trajan, Decius (= Trajan Decius?) and Diocletian. Only two coins are preserved. There were more coin finds reported from the same region, Mollis-Bodenwald, in the 1820's and ca. 1831, but no coins are preserved (cf. Diaz Tabernero et al., Münzfunde GL, pp. 19-22, 72-73, nos 16-17).
disposition: Historisches Museum, Bern; Historischer Verein des Kantons Glarus

summary: Unknown number of coins found with a vessel in a wall. The land owner had 9 antoniniani (radiates): Trajan Decius - Postumus.
45 bronze coins: 44 sestertii, 1 dupondius: found together in an edifice hypotetically identified as of collegium augustales: Domitian 0- Maximinus I THrax (AD 236-238).
disposition: Museo Arqueológico Municipal de Cartagena, Spain

summary: Small hoard of 15 ant. of Gallienus to Tetricus II, from 'Dover General Deposits', reported on by Peter Curnow & Richard Reece, all show evidence of wear, majority clipped.Reece, R. 2012. The Roman coins. In B. Philp The Discovery and Excavation of the Roman Shore-fort at Dover, Kent. Kent Archaeological Monographs 11. Kent Archaeol. Rescue Unit, pp. 108.

A set of 206 coins (Claudius II - Gallic Empire), dug out during dredging work in the Mosel river, ca.100m below the Kaiser Wilhelm bridge on the western edge of the narrow island. The coins were soldered together in a clump. The 8 coins listed under ID 16853 (FMRD 3011,3) belong probably to the sam find.
7 antoniniani (radiates) and 1 imitation: Claudius II - Tetricus I (AD 271-274).
The hoard comprised between 600 and 700 antoniniani (radiates) from Gallienus to Tetricus I. Hobbs estimates a silver weight of between 210.9g and 874.1g.
The hoard comprised 160 Roman bronze and billon coins from Severus Alexander to Aurelian (AD 270-275).
The hoard comprised 10 denarii from Hadrian to Otacilla Severa and 179 antoniniani (radiates) from Caracalla to Valerian I.
The hoard comprised a small casket or box containing silver and copper-alloy coins from Vespasian, Antoninus Pius and Trebonianus Gallus.
77 coins: 11 denarii, 39 antoniniani (radiates), 12 AR, 10 sestertii 5 AE: Tiberius - Postumus (AD 266-267); silver weight: 31.3-136.1 g.
32 silver coins: 24 antoniniani (radiates), 8 denarii: Caracalla - Trebonianus Gallus (AD 251-253).
The hoard comprised 132 denarii and antoniniani (radiates) of Marcus Aurelius to Valerian I and Gallienus (AD 253-260).

The hoard comprised two separate deposits. The first contained 28 sestertii, dupondii and asses from Trajan to Postumus. The second contained 622 radiates from Philip I to Victorinus with a tpq of AD 270. The circumstances of discovery means that a clear relationship between the two hoards cannot be established with any certainty.

A hoard of 381 silver coins (denarii and antoniniani ranging from Geta to Postumus) and 1 provincial coin, found in a vessel surrounded by fire rubble in a building located in front of the SE corner of the Roman fort. The coins had been contained in a bag made of hemp. A large number of ornaments had been placed on top to the vessel.

The hoard comprised a ceramic vessel containing between 4,000 and 5,000 radiates, some of which were issues of Gallienus' The hoard was found under a tree, not far from the route to Grosley, in the Château-Simon woodland, close to Gouttières
9 kg of silver and billon coins of the 3rd century AD. 2,504 coins have been noticed: Caracalla - Postumus (AD 268).
16 denarii and 4 radiates, ranging from Diva Faustina to Philip I

Hoard found in a cooking pot (not preserved) during construction work for the Nordostbahn railway track. It comprised an unknown number of antoniniani, of which 204 (possibly the greater part) are preserved in public collection, ranging from Trebonianus Gallus to Claudius II. - After the publication in 1992, at least another 6 coins from this hoard were recorded, in a private collection in Diessenhofen. The sherds of the pot are described in the 1893 publication. Four Gallienus coins were also subjected to chemical analysis at the same time, pp. 11-12: "Derselbe hat drei Stücke auf ihre Zusammensetzung quantitativ und qualitativ, das vierte nur qualitativ untersucht und folgendes gefunden: I. 6 Theile Zinn, 94 Theile Kupfer; II. 30 Th. Silber, 0,3 Th. Gold, 69,7 Th. Kupfer; III. 18 Th. Antimon, 82 Th. Kupfer; IV. Kupfer, Antimon und wenig Bismuth."
disposition: Thurgauisches Historisches Museum, Frauenfeld (158 coins); Museum Allerheiligen, Schaffhausen (40 coins); Schweizerisches Landesmuseum Zürich (6 coins); private (6 coins)

summary: A hoard of 1,545 coins (270 tetradrachms, 1 bronze, 1,274 antoniniani down to Claudius II, AD 270), found during the excavations at Capharnaeum.
165 coins (163 denarii, 2 antoniniani (radiates), ranging from Domitian to Alexander Severus), found with 2 silver bracelets ca. 3 km east of the Römerstraße. The coins were destroyed during the war.
disposition: Staatliche Münzsammlung München (lost during WWII; one bracelet survived)

summary: (750) 639 silver coins: Septimius Severus - Trebonianus Gallus (AD 251-253); silver weight: 937.5 g.
disposition: Museum of History, Silistra, Bulgaria; inv.nos. 468-1108 (641 coins)

summary: Four burned antoniniani (radiates). Only one coin, antoninianus (radiate) of Gordian III (AD 241-243) was identified.

A hoard of 1925 denarii (Republic - Severus Alexander), found during levelling operations in the area of Bell's Meadow, in Falkirk, ca. 400 m NW of the Antonine Wall, in a vessel of red earthenware. A piece of cloth had been used to protect the mouth of the vessel. A few coins were lost, but all others passed into the hands of the Crown Authorities as treasure-trove. In all, 1925 coins, comprising 1923 denarii, one drachm of Lycia, and one bronze core of a plated denarius, were examined and published in 1934 by G. MacDonald. A new list, based on visual examination of the preserved coins, is given by Robertson, Studia Paulo Naster Oblata (1982). The latter recorded only 1917 coins. The missing coins were 2 denarii of Vespasian, 1 of Domitian, 2 of Trajan, 1 of Antoninus Pius, 1 of Diva Faustina I, and one of Septimius Severus. Recent studies have shown that 3 of the denarii attributed by Sir George Macdonald to Caracalla should be assigned to Elagabalus.
disposition: NMAS, Edinburgh (pot, cloth frag. and most of the 1925 coins)

summary: The hoard comprised 12 coins of Gallienus and Tetricus I.
25 coins found in small ceramic pitcher: 2 denarii, 18 antoniniani, 4 provincial bronze medallions, 1 provincial bronze coin: Severus Alexander - Trajan Decius (AD 249-251).

10 antoniniani (radiates): Gordian III 4, Philip I 5, Trebonianus Gallus (Volusianus Augustus) 1 (AD 251-253). Weight coins: 35.74 g. Found together with two silver bracelets and two Anchor type silver brooches and one bronze ring. Weight jewelry: 186.83 g.
The hoard comprised nearly 1,500 antoniniani (radiates) of Gallienus to Probus, with coins of Probus being the most numerous. Only one coin of Gallienus' sole reign was described (RIC 599).
The hoard comprised 400 silver coins to Gordian III or Gallienus with a tpq of AD 244/268.
Unknown originally number of coins. 31 pieces: 2 denarii, 29 antoniniani (radiates): Commodus - Gallienus-Postumus (AD 260-269).
Unknown number of denarii and antoniniani. 30 pieces were seen by V. Haralanov: Vespasian - Elagabalus (AD 218-222).
5 antoniniani (radiates) and 1 imitation.
67 silver coins: 21 antoniniani (radiates), 46 denarii: Vespasian - Philip I (AD 247-249).
disposition: National Archaeological Institute with Museum, Sofia, Bulgaria

summary: The hoard comprised originally ca. 2,400 coins (2,384 coins were mentioned in 1960), of which a small proportion has been lost. The coins were found in a copper-alloy vessel. 2 denarii and 2,302 radiates (incl. 7 imitations) ranging from Valerian and Gallienus to Diocletian have now been published. Tpq is AD 293.

The hoard comprise a pot of at least 2,721 coins, found while unrooting a tree. The hoard contained also a silver ring with a engraved gem setting. Coins range from Gordian III to Carinus. Of the 2,555 coins known to Vischer, 5 (Gordian III, Gallienus (2), Severina, Aurelian) are denarii, the others are radiates.
disposition: Archäologie Baselland; Historisches Museum Basel; Solothurn

summary: Unknown initial number of imperial and provincial bronze coins. 240 pieces entered the museum collection in Dalgopol: Septimius Severus - Philip I (AD 244-249). Mints: Marcianopolis, Mesembria, Tomis.

18 silver coins: 4 denarii, 14 antoniniani (radiates) found with ceramic vessel: Trajan - Claudius II (AD 268-270). Together were found jewelry: 2 silver bracelets, 1 gold pendant, 3 gold rings, 1 gold earring and fragments of silver earrings.
disposition: Museo di Antichità di Torino, Italy

summary: Unknown initial number of coins. 20 silver coins: 19 antoniniani, 1 denarius: Elagabalus - Philip I (AD 244-247); silver weight of 25.1-49.1 g.
One aureus of Tacitus, one gold barbarous imitation of an aureus, 4 drachms Hadrian, 1 denarius Septimius Severus were found in a grave together with jewelry.
1,739 antoniniani (radiates): Philip I - Aurelian (AD 270-275); silver weight: c. 541.0-2499.0 g.
Few hundreds of provincial bronze coins. 92 entered the museum collection in Sofia: Septimius Severus - Gordian III (AD 238-244).
disposition: National History Museum, Sofia, Bulgaria; inv. nos. 26923-27020 (92 coins)

summary: The hoard was hidden amongst a pile of Roman tiles and comprised more than 2,000 sestertii. TAF suggests that the large bronze of Gallienus should in fact be identified as a medallion.
On an area of 3 sqm were found 22 silver coins: 2 denarii, 20 antoniniani of Philip I, beside a bronze lamp.
34 sestertii: Trajan - Philip I (AD 244-249).
8 coins found in a cave: Antoninus Pius - Quintillus (Divus Claudius II); silver weight: 4.1-13.9g.
The hoard comprised 110 denarii: Vespasian-Severus Alexander (AD 222-235 AD).
The hoard comprised 1 denarius of Severus Alexander and 277 radiates from Gordian III to Gallienus' joint reign with a tpq of 258 to 259.

A hoard of 10 denarii (Septimius Severus - Alexander Severus) discovered during groundwork for the continuation of Harthauser Street into wooded area in southern Harlaching. The coins lay close to the remains of a skeleton.
(1430) 976 denarii: Nero - Severus Alexander (AD 222-228). Found together with silverware and jewelry.
disposition: National Archaeological Institute with Museum, Sofia, Bulgaria (976 coins)

summary: The hoard was found in an amphora and comprised 63 coins of Elagabalus to Valerian I and Gallienus (AD 253-260).
About 200 silver coins found in a ceramic vessel. 49 pieces entered museum collection in Sofia: Trajan - Valerian I and Gallienus/Gallienus (sole) (AD 253-268).
disposition: National Archaeological Institute with Museum, Sofia, Bulgaria; inv. no. LXVIII

summary: The hoard was found during the excavation of the courtyard of House L in Insula 27 at Colonia Ulpia Traiana. It comprised 5 denarii of Maximinus dating to AD 235-236. The excavation archives provide no further details about the circumstances of discovery.
(220) 175 silver coins: Antoninus Pius - Severus Alexander (AD 222-235) + silver vessel; silver weight: 309.9-499.3g+
19 antoniniani (radiates) of the period Valerian I and Gallienus (AD 258-259); silver weight: 5.6-13.4 g.
The hoard comprised 15 coins (2 denarii and 13 Provincial issues: Thessalonica, Amphipolis, Stobi, Cassandrea, Koinon of Macedonia), found in sarcophagus 1 in Ierissos.
Group of 5 coins discovered in an ancient cellar: 4 double sestertii of Postumus, 1 imitation of antoninianus (radiate) of Victorinus (AD 269-271).

The hoard comprised a gold necklace and 20 copper-alloy coins from Commodus and Caracalla. The archive report questions whether this deposit represents a horad but does not provide any further explanation.
unknown initial number of coins. 154 silver coins: Septimius Severus - Trajan Decius (AD 249-251).
disposition: Archaeological Museum, Veliko Tarnovo, Bulgaria; inv.nos. 2447-2561 (154 coins) - stolen

summary: The hoard was found in a container beneath an altar to the goddess Fontana and comprised numerous bronze and brass issues which were deposited in the Gabinete de Numismática de la Biblioteca Nacional Portugesa. The coins appear to be the offerings of devotees. Only four of the coins have been described and these were in a poor state of preservation.
disposition: Gabinete de Numismática de la Biblioteca Nacional Portugesa., Lisboa.

summary: (c.700) 601 bronze coins: 598 sestertii (+ imitations), 2 dupondii, 1 as: Vespasian - Postumus (AD 262).
disposition: Cabinet des Médailles, Bruxelles, Belgium (37 coins); in 1959, 13 private collectors: 564 coins

summary: Unknown initial number of coins. 81 antoniniani (radiates) are available: Trebonianus Gallus - Claudius II (AD 268-270); silver weight: 18.5-80.3 g.
disposition: Regional Museum of History, Burgas, Bulgaria; inv.no. XVII, XXXIV; History Museum, Sliven, Bulgaria (3 coins); History Museum, Yambol, Bulgaria; inv.no. 1066 /0-12/

summary: 49 coins: 3 silver and 46 provincial bronze coins entered the museum collection in Shumen: Vespasian - Philip I (AD 244-249).
disposition: Regional History Museum, Shumen, Bulgaria; inv. no. 2100-2148 (49 coins)

summary: Unknown number of coins found in a ceramic vessel. 103 coins entered museum collection in Stara Zagora: 5 denarii, 96 antoniniani, 2 provincial bronzes: Septimius Severus - Philip I (AD 247-249).
disposition: Regional Museum of History, Stara Zagora, Bulgaria; inv.no. 4318-4327

summary: Unknown number of provincial bronze coins. 12 coin entered the museum collection in Svishtov: Antoninus Pius - Gordian III (AD 238-244).
26 antoniniani (radiates): Gordian III - Gallienus (AD 254). With silver jewelry.
106 antoniniani (radiates): Gallienus (sole) - Carinus (AD 283-284).
disposition: Narodni muzej, Numizmatični cabinet, Ljubljana, Slovenia

summary: 24 antoniniani (radiates) and 42 imitations found in the basement of a Roman villa: Gallienus - Maximian I (AD 285-291).

The hoard was found in the foundations of a 15th century house and comprised a small deposit of 3rd century coins. J. Chappée told Blanchet there were 10 coins: Victorinus 2, Tetricus I 3, Tetricus II 5.

This find can only be traced on paper, as it is only available as a manuscript by Christian Friedrich Hoffmann. It is stated that Hoffmann led excavations in the fort in the years 1791, 1800, 1804 and 1813-1815. His extensive manuscript was found in the Princely Wied archive in Neuwied in 1811. In 1991 the content was revised in Frankfurt am Main. Hoffmann describes 256 coins that are said to have been found “in a yellow metal chalice”. Thanks to Hoffmann's detailed description, almost all coins could be assigned. These are 213 denarii and 43 antoniniani (radiate). Most date from the reigns of Septimius Severus, Elagabalus, and Severus Alexander. The final coin, minted in AD 259.
Large hoard found while ploughing. Only 13 antoniniani identified: Caracalla 7, Philip I 6.
The hoard comprised 4000 coins with emperors from Severus Alexander to Postumus represented. The hoard was found by a farmworker.
3503 radiates to Probus, in a pot. Full identifications of all the coins of Probus is unavailable. Unpublished?

Probably, over 1,000-1,500 silver coins because of the container: a bucket. Only 45 are recovered: Nero - Severus Alexander (AD 231-235). The latest coins is a plated ”barbarous” imitation of a Commodus denarius. Most of the coins were sold in batches of 100 pieces each, at the fair in the nearby commune of Puiești. According to the authors, this hoard is the very same with the ones of Tutova, Cetățuia and Băcești. (see Munteanu, L. and Popușoi, E., The Roman coin hoard from Iezer, p. 3)
disposition: Museum “Vasile Pârvan”, Bârlad, Romania (inv. nos. VPMB B/317-368)

summary: The hoard is composed of 10 poorly preserved Antonine bronzes. It was found during three archaeological(?) surveys of Noires-Terres in the Bois-en-Ardres in February 1980, at the end of 1981 and in early 1982) and interpreted as the remains of a dispersed hoard, as they were all found in the same place.

On the site of the Romano-British settlement at Camerton, near Bath, a small hoard of barbarous radiates, mostly minimi, was found just outside the wall of a small Roman building. It would appear to have been deposited there after the construction of the wall, which was not earlier than mid-third century. With the exception of the piece of larger module, and some scraps of the more usual imitations, the coins of the hoard are radiate minimi of average diameter of 8 mm.
A hoard of 120+ Syrian tetradrachms dating from Caracalla to Trebonianus Gallus.
The hoard comprised an earthenware vessel containing 700 silver and billon coins (denarii and antoniniani (radiates): Severus Alexander - MArius (AD 269).
More than 1000 silver coins (Trajan - Postumus), found while establishing a water ditch on a field. The composition of the hoard is difficult to reconstruct, see FMRD for details.

10 radiates (Gallienus to Carausius) found along with fragments of a possible bronze container by a farm worker ploughing a field near Plas Nanteos. The coins entered the collection of a local antiquarian and were sold upon his death. No further information is available.

The hoard comprised 6,010 antoniniani (radiates) and one as from Severus Alexander to Probus. In 1967, a further 7 antoniniani (radiates) of Tetricus I were recovered from the same findspot and are assumed to be part of the same hoard. Hobbs estimates a silver weight of between 1084.4 or 15626.3g.
Indeterminable total number of coins found by remains of an important Roman villa. Among issuers: Gallienus, Tetricus I

A hoard of 64 provincial AE coins of Ionia, Lydia, Caria, Thrace, Macedonia and Cilicia, dating from Antoninus Pius to Salonina. See also Klose, Smyrna, p. 123 (2 specimens, and not 1 as mentioned in Noe).
150 coins: 140 sestertii, 10 antoniniani (radiates): Vespasian - Trebonianus Gallus/Gallienus (AD 251-268). A silver patera and a lead weight were discovered together with these coins.
Unknown number of bronze coins. 90 pieces entered the museum collection in Pazardzhik: Antoninus Pius - Philip I (AD 244-249).
disposition: Regional History, Museum, Pazardhzik, Bulgaria; inv.nos. 2145-2230

summary: 800 silver coins: Nerva - Elagabalus (AD 218-222). No further Information.
Unknown number of silver coins found in a ceramic vessel. 138 were examined and 18 entered the museum collection in Dalgopol: Titus - Philip I (AD 244-249).
disposition: History Museum, Dalgopol, Bulgaria; inv.no. N. 0026/1-18 (18 coins)

summary: 50 antoniniani (radiates) of Tetricus I and II were found in association with the jaw bone of a skeleton in a lead coffin, suggesting that they had been placed inside the mouth of the corpse. The coins were characterised be being excessively thin and were therefore thought to be minimi.
The hoard comprised 292 denarii from Domitian to Maximinus (AD 238).
Nine antoniniani (radiates): Gordian III - Claudius II (AD 268-270).
The hoard includes 6 denari and 8 antoniniani (radiates) from Trajan to Philip I (AD 103-247) kept in a private collection.

Hoard 8 was found on 18 Nov. 1932 and hoard 9 on 22 Jan. 1933. Both were under the floor of the same room, just west of the South-West Tower of the Citadel and certainly part of the same deposit. it comprised 2,821 coins and 11 illegible ones, including one AE of Seleucus III, one tetradrachm of Philip Philadelphus, 2 denarii (Severus Alexander) and 2,817 provincial bronze coins from a large variety of mints (Domitian - Decius).
The hoard comprised 2 radiates and 17 Provincial coins (Thessalonica, Edessa and Koinon of Macedonia), found in Koufalia.
6.6 kg of coins, 2110 or 2400? antoniniani (radiates): Trebonianus Gallus - Claudius II/Postumus (AD 268-270) silver weight: 570.7-2636.5 g.
11 provincial bronze coins minted in Hadrianopolis found in the dirt when digging a sewer: Gordian III (AD 238-244).
disposition: Regional Museum of History, Kardzhali, Bulgaria; inv.nos. 618, 624, 628, 632, 635, 639, 642, 645, 648, 654, 657, 684, 694

summary: The hoard comprised a ceramic vessel containing 2,400 denarii with the latest coin being of Severus Alexander (or according to Blanchet, Gordian III).
The hoard comprised a vessel containing 3,000 antoniniani (radiates) of Tetricus I described as being small in size and therefore likely to be barbarous.
The hoard comprised 93 silver coins dated between AD 211-218.
39 silver coins found with a ceramic vessel: 31 denarii, 8 antoniniani (radiates): Antoninus Pius - Philip I (AD 244-249). Found together with a brooch and a silver ring.
The coins which were found in a water tank were interpreted as a small purse hoard as they were all grouped together: Marcus Aurelius - Tetricus I (AD 271-274).
Unknown initial number of silver coins. 300 coins have been examined by Dr. Haralanov: Septimius Severus - Philip I (AD 244-249).
(ca. 2000) 489 denarii and antoniniani: Nero - Maximinus I Thrax (AD 235-238); silver weight: c. 2,801.7-6,258.3 g.

3,000 to 5,000 silver coins, ranging from Augustus to Severus Alexander, found while digging gravel close to the Jever castle, on the city moat. 2,200 coins were melted down, the rest dispersed. Zedelius published 564 coins attributed to the hoard.
disposition: Oldenburgisches Landesmuseum (part); Schloßmuseum Jever (part); Ostfriesisches Landesmuseum, Emden (part); Münster museum (part)

summary: The hoard was found in a cemetery and comprised 339 antoniniani (radiates) from Valerian I to Diocletian (AD 293).
54 silver coins: 26 antoniniani, 28 denarii: Commodus - Philip I (AD 244-249); silver weight: 72.6-130.1 g.
disposition: National Archaeological Institute with Museum, Sofia, Bulgaria; inv. no. CCXX

summary: The coins (168 antoniniani ranging from Philip to Carinus) were found between Schwenningen and Dürrheim in a peat field, soldered together and seemingly packed in rolls. The coins were given to the Rottweiler museum, but were not kept separately which makes a secure attribution of given coins to the hoard difficult.
117 coins entered museum collection Yambol: Septimius Severus - Philip I (AD 244-249).
disposition: Regional Museum of History, Yambol, Bulgaria; inv.no. 2409/0-65/, 2435/0-40/, 2547/0-7/, 2663/0-3/

summary: The hoard comprised 215 radiates from Gordian III to Gallienus with a tpq of AD 268.
disposition: Brodsko Posavlje Museum, Slavonski Brod, Croatia

summary: 134 silver coins: 6 denarii, 128 antoniniani: Hadrian - Valerian I and Gallienus (AD 259-260); silver weight: 166.1-340.8 g.

A hoard found in 1865 under a mound of quarry stone in the middle of the locality. It comprised perhaps 800 denarii, dating from Trajan to Maximinus I. 765 (the catalogue is numbered to 766, but no. 677 is omitted) of these are recored in in detail by FMRD. The coins were in a pot, next to which a bracelet and a fibula were also found.
1,267 denarii and antoniniani (radiates) ranging from Trajan to Philip I (AD 247-248) found with two ceramic vessels.
(700-800) denarii and antoniniani. 251 coins are kept in the museum in Isperih: Galba - Valerian I/Gallienus (AD 253-268).

The hoard comprised a broken ceramic vessel containing approximately 900 coins of which 200 were dispersed. They included issues of Trajan, Plotina, Hadrian, Sabina, Antoninus Pius, Faustina I and II, Marcus Aurelius, Lucius Verus, Lucilla, Commodus, Crispina, Clodius Albinus and Julia Domna. The cataloguer mentioned these coins in particular: one of Diva Faustina, 2 coins of Divus Antoninus Pius (RIC 1262/1265 and 1274) and one of Commodus with a quadriga on the reverse.
Around 300 silver coins of which 168 were documented: antoniniani, denarii: Septimius Severus - Valerian I and Gallienus (AD 258-259).
24 provincial bronze coins entered the museum collection in Shumen: Septimius Severus - Gordian III (AD 238-244).
disposition: Regional History Museum, Shumen, Bulgaria; inv. no. 1676-1699 (24 coins)

summary: The hoard comprised about 600 bronzes of Postumus.
The hoard comprised 16 antoniniani (radiates) dated between the reigns of Caracalla and Elagabalus.

Four coins (Syracuse, Augustus, Tiberius for Agrippa and Severus Alexander), allegedly found in the bed of the River Weser at low tide, at 'der Tiefer'. FMRD has listed this find under Bremen-Mahndorf, but doubts that it is genuine.
The hoard comprised a ceramic container, the characteristics of which are unknown which contained 667 sestertii, one dupondius from Vespasian to Gordian III and one Provincial bronze of Hadrian.
disposition: Museo Arqueologico Provincial de Alicante, Spain

summary: The hoard comprised 9,000 antoniniani (radiates) (35kg) found in a terracotta vessel: Valerian I - Dioletian/Maximian I (AD 284-293). L. Dancoisne bought 1000 of the more interesting and better conserved coins, which may not be representative of the whole assemblage. Found whilst digging in garden; silver weight: 1621.1-11249.1 g+.
2826 bronze coins: 2 imperial, 2824 provincial bronze coins were found in a ceramic vessel: Hadrian - Trajan Decius (AD 249-251).
25 coins: 1 denarius, 12 antoniniani (radiates), 2 quadrantes, 10 unknown denomination: Claudius II - Tetricus I (AD 271-274).

35 coins (3 sestertii, 9 radiates and 23 Provincial coins from Athens. The Athenian coins range from the time of Augustus to Gallienus), that were part of a larger find made in the region of Corinth (?). Its composition is similar to the hoards from Eleusis.
The hoard comprised some broken vessels containing approximately 4,000 bronze coins which were thought to have mostly been sestertii.
27 silver coins discovered while ploughing: 14 denarii, 13 antoniniani: Titus - Philip I (AD 244-249).
disposition: Museum of History, Pazardzik, Bulgaria; inv.nos. 2093-2118

summary: The hoard was found north of the village, in three ceramic vessels. It comprised c. 500 bronze coins. 180 sestertii, dupondii and asses from Vespasian to Maximinus I Thrax (AD 235-238).
Hoard of 99 electrum and silver stateri of the Bosporan Kings, Cotys III and Sauromates III (AD 232-233).

The hoard was found in a funerary casket with an ornate lid decorated with a red marble plaque. The casket contained cremated bone, two small amphorae, a glass vessel, a copper-alloy spatula and 7 dupondii and asses from Tiberius to Severus Alexander.
Three coins of Postumus were found in the basement area of the hypocaust heating room inside the main building of a villa rustica located north-east of Niederzier, in the 'München Busch' wooded area.

The hoard was found in a well in a Gallo-Roman villa and comprised two vessels containing a little more than 900 radiates of Elagabalus, Philip, Herennia Etruscilla and Postumus. More than 600 pieces were issues of Postumus.
Unknown quantity of coins. 3,693 antoniniani entered the museum collection in Plovdiv. No further information.
disposition: Museum of Archaeology, Plovdiv, Bulgaria; inv. no. 2644; 3,693 coins

summary: 30 coins: 2 sestertii, 28 antoniniani (radiates): Severus Alexander - Postumus (AD 260-269).
The hoard comprised 9 bronze coins dated to the reign of Severus Alexander (AD 222-235).
Unknown initial number of coins. 313 silver coins went to the Museum of History in Silistra, Bulgaria: Caracalla - Trebonianus Gallus (AD 251-253).
disposition: Museum of History, Silistra, Bulgaria (313 coins); inv.nos. 5584-5896

summary: 33 coins: 1 denarius, 32 antoniniani (radiate) found in the house known as the 'House of Domitian's Diploma': Severus Alexander - Quintillus (Divus Claudius II) (AD 270).

On the eastern exterior of the late Roman NO-tower of the cathedral in Trier, a shaft for the protection of the tower foundation was laid out during maintenance work in 1980. The hoard was dug out in a depth of 5.20m. The 43 coins were soldered together in spherically formed clumps. The coins were originally preserved in a leather bag and lay on an antique stone floor.

The hoard comprised a bronze vessel containing 821 antoniniani (radiates). The catalogue made by Blanchet is not accurate. Aubin published a lot of 21 radiates in 1981 which probably came from the hoard. However, it is not clear whether these are additions or whether they were included in the original numbers. The hoard was found by a farmer. Silver: 821 coins; Silver weight: 222.6-1025.3 g.
disposition: Musée d'Archéologie Nationale, Saint-Germain-en-Laye, France (copper-alloy vessel, inv.no. 50253)

summary: Over 747 billon tetradrachms of Alexandria: Vespasian - Gallienus (sole) (AD 262-263) found in a pile on the floor of an underground room during excavations of a house.
disposition: 744 in Ann Arbor, the rest in various Egyptian museums

summary: The coins (9 sestertii, Marcus Aurelius to Gordian III) were found during building work on the premises of Neckarhalde.

The hoard comprised both coins and other objects, including numerous items of personal adornment in precious metals as well as tableware and other vessels. One of the vessels contained approximately 395 denarii and radiates from Septimius Severus to Saloninus (and Valerian II?) while in the hoard as a whole, there were approximately 1080 bronze coins, nearly all sestertii, but with the exception of 12 dupondii and asses. The bronze coins range in date from Domitian (1 example) through to Trajan Decius. Testenoire-Lafayette noted that issues of Gordian III were particularly prominent in the hoard, that Severus Alexander was also well-represented and that issues of Gallienus and his family made up a large proportion of the radiates in the hoard. The hoard was found when the landowner, M. Charles demolished well-built foundations in his field which were hindering cultivation. Silver: c.395 coins;
disposition: Societé de la Diana, Montbrison, France

summary: 170 bronze coins: 83 official, 87 provincial of Alexandria (Domitian - Maximian I). During excavations in this region, where many Roman settlements are known, this lot was presented to de Looz by the mayor of Hannut.
Unknown number of coins. 5 antoniniani are in the museum collection in Székesfehérvár: Gordian III, Philip I, Trajan Decius (AD 249-251).
A big vessel full of Roman imperial coins, bronzes and antoniniani (radiates): Marcus Aurelius - Valerian and Gallienus/Gallienus (sole) (AD 253-268).
Hoard of 12-15 kilos of coins - 5,500 pieces - found with a ceramic vessel. Only 270 were recovered: Trebonianus Gallus (Volusian Augustus) - Cludius II (AD 268-270).
3 coins: 1 antoninianus Aurelian, 3 provincial bronzes of Faustina II.
disposition: Regional History Museum, Kyustendil, Bulgaria; inv. no. 1289-1317

summary: 1610 antoniniani and fragments of a ceramic vessel with lid: Gallienus - Probus (AD 276-282). The coins were minted in Siscia, Sirmium, Serdica and other mints. The majority of the coins belong to Gallienus and Claudius II. Due to poor condition of reservation 157 coins could not be identified; silver weight: 244.1-1686.4 g.
disposition: Regional History Museum, Kyustendil, Bulgaria; inv. nos. 2731-4172, 4319-4414; 1,538 coins

summary: The hoard comprised 'a lot of 62 double sestertii of Postumus (AD 260-268). They were sold to a dealer in Rouen who claimed they had been found in Eu.
The hoard comprised '20 denarii [actually, antoniniani (radiates)] of Gordian III, Philip I, Trebonianus Gallus, Volusian (?), Gallienus and Postumus.
Around 20 provincial bronze coins are known. Seven pieces were documented: Septimius Severus - Severus Alexander (AD 222-235).
1,892 bronze coins found in a ceramic vessel: Vespasian - Postumus (AD 260-261).
(195) 180 silver coins: Marcus Aurelius - Philip I (AD 244-249); silver weight: 245.1-503.7 g.
The coins (at least 5) were found in 1830 on the premises of Proitzschenberg, near the 'Lehmmauer'.

The hoard comprised 26 coins, mostly large bronzes. 13 coins were broken. The others bear the portraits of Antoninus Pius, Faustina I, Marcus Aurelius, Faustina II, Lucilla. The 4 bronze coins of Postumus are cast and middle size (AD 264-265?).
disposition: Musée Saint-Jean, Angers, France (Reg. II, p. 184, no. 453 bis.)

summary: The hoard comprised a small red ceramic vessel with a lid containing approximately 150 coins of the second and third century AD. It was probably a hoard of denarii and antoniniani (radiates).

The hoard comprised 300 'minimi' which were very difficult to identify. One article suggests that it was possible to read the names 'Tetricus, Antoninus, Aticus, Constantinus etc' on some examples. Mandin confirmed that the hoard was of barbarous radiates, probably of Tetricus.

The hoard comprised 372 coins that were fused together in a single lump. They comprised 1 denarius and 371 antoniniani (radiates) from Valerian I to Victorinus. The mint distribution is given in TAF (Rome: 210; Cologne: 93; Trier: 24) but not related to issues of particular emperors. Hobbs estimates a silver weight of 100g to 111.0g.
Unknown number of silver coins found in a ceramic vessel. 117 entered the museum collection in Sliven: 84 antoniniani, 33 denarii: Commodus - Philip I (AD 244-249); silver weight: 157.2-281.4 g.
1,937 antoniniani (radiates): Elagabalus - Probus (AD 276-282).
disposition: Musées Royaux d'Art et d'Histoire - Koninklijk Musea voor Kunst en Geschiedenis (Brussels)

summary: "Few hundreds" Roman coins found in a field. Only 33 coins provided some information and some of them have been entered to the level of the coin. The precision is not certain.
24 provincial bronze coins: Caracalla - Maximinus I Thrax (AD 235-238).
disposition: Muzeul de Istorie Națională și Arheologie, Constanța, Romania; inv.nos. 67360-67382

summary: "A considerable large quantity" of coins of "middle bronzes", all of Postumus (AD 260-268). Four

A hoard was found in Chassenon at some time in the nineteenth century AD and comprised 10 coins from Maximinus I Thrax to Aemilian. Some of the coins were kept by the family and can be identified by M. Dhénin. Hobbs estimates a silver weight of 12.6-22.9 g.
90 silver coins: 23 denarii, 67 antoniniani: Antoninus Pius - Philip I (AD 244-249); silver weight: 125.5-252.4 g.
Unknown number of coins. 4 coins in the museum of Lovech: Septimius Severus, Julia Domna, Severus Alexander, Philip II.

391 silver coins: 287 denarii from Vespasian to Gordian III; 101 antoniniani from Gordian III to Philip I; 3 bronze coins: 1 sestertius, 1 provincial, 1 unidentified (AD 244-249); silver weight: 437.2-913.2 g.
11 provincial bronzes issued in Rhesaena by Trajan Decius and his family, found in destruction deposits of Room 9J.
30 silver coins, denarii and antoniniani. 12 pieces were recovered: 5 antoniniani, 7 denarii: Septimius Severus - Philip I (AD 244-249); silver weight: 39.0-70.0 g.
1,126 billon Alexandrian tetradrachms, 2 Ptolemaic bronze coins: Ptolemaic dynasty - Aurelian (AD 270-275). 'Acquired in Egypt by Dattari, who sold it to Milne and Currelly'.
disposition: Partly in Oxford, partly in Toronto. Detailed list in Oxford

summary: (250) 121 denarii found within an ancient settlement: Republic - Gordian III (AD 238-244)
Discovered at a place with Roman structures. Some doubts whether it is actually a hoard. 8 antoniniani (radiates): Gordian III - Victorinus (AD 269-271).
1,049 bronze coins found in three ceramic vessels placed one next to the other: 1,045 sestertii, 3 dupondii, 1 as: Nero - Philip I (AD 244-249).
disposition: Cabinet des médailles de la Bibliothèque Nationale de France

summary: The hoard comprised 'a large quantity of 3rd century coins, of which 39 were given by M. Richard to the Musée de Laval (Mayenne): Severus Alexander - Postumus (AD 260-269); silver weight: 12.5-46.8g. Three coins, Severus Alexander, Maximinus I Thrax and Saloninus are lost.
The hoard comprised a vessel containing approximately 150 third century antoniniani (radiates.) The hoard was discovered by a farmer while cutting back an oak tree.

Details from HER: 2 coins: 1 of Claudius II Gothicus (AD 268-270), Providentia type; & a local copy (c. AD 270) of Pax Aug type of Tetricus II, with radiate head on obverse.Present location unknown.YAJ 1975, 46: 4.

Unknown number of coins. Few coins are mention in the collection of Reydet de la Vulpillière, which indicate a large diversity of coins, denarii, antoninaini, sestertii, from Republic to Tacitus (AD 276)
13 antoniniani (radiates) of Gallienus and Claudius II part of a larger hoard?
disposition: Museu Nacional de Arqueologia, Lisboa, Portugal

summary: 369 bronze coins: 368 sestertii, 1 as: Nero - Postumus (AD 260-261).

During the excavation of Roman fort at Reculver, a rectangular sunken room, poss. the strong room of the principia & sacellum, was excav., 23 ft 10 in. long & 20 ft wide. It had a thin skin floor of white mortar, covered in a deposit 6-12 in. deep of loam, mortar, painted wall plaster & domestic refuse, incl. pottery. It also produced frags. of 2 stone inscriptions from commemorative tablets, 6 iron arrowheads, & 21 coins of Antoninus Pius to Constantine II, with 14 from period AD 260-293. The rubble layer above contained mortaria, roof tile & box tile frags, & may represent collapsed roof, & this layer produced another 4 coins of Postumus of AD 268.Philp, B. 2005. The Excavation of the Roman Fort at Reculver, Kent. Kent Monographs 10. Kent Archaeol. Rescue Unit, pp. 44-45
25 provincial bronze coins found in a ceramic vessel: Caracalla - Philip I (AD 244-249).

The hoard comprised 67 Provincial coins mostly from local mints (Thessalonica, Macedonian Koinon) of the time of Gordian III, found in a Roman farmhouse located in a field southeast of the provincial road, west of Afytos.
The hoard comprises of 67 silver coins, 34 denarii, 33 antoniniani (radiates), from Commodus to Trajan Decius with a tpq of AD 249-251.
Circa 95 antoniniani (radiates). Dembski 1977 gives the evidence for 89: Trebonianus Gallus - Aurelian (AD 270-275); silver weight: 26.6-117.8g.
Hoard of circa 4,000 coins. 400 coins entered the collection of Gh. Georgescu-Corabia, including issues of Pupienus, Gordian III and Philip I.
170 provincial coins: Nicopolis ad Istrum 77, Marcianopolis 69, Hadrianopolis 6, Odessos 4, Anchialus 9, Philippopolis 1, Pautalia 1: Caracalla - Gordian III (AD 238-244).
The hoard comprised c. 3/4000 antoniniani (radiates) ending with coins of Tetricus I (AD 271-274).
Group record for a hoard of six silver coins.
195 silver coins: 102 denarii, 93 antoniniani: Commodus - Philip (AD 246); silver weight: 232.3-420.8 g.
disposition: County Museum Gorj, Tg. Jiu, Romania; Ion Luben collection, Bucharest (3 coins)

summary: ca. 50 antoniniani (radiates), but only 28 coins are identified: Valerian I - Quintillus (AD 270).

The hoard comprised 'a lot of bronze and billon coins, of which 83 coins were recovered and give by M. Timbaud to the Musée de Rouen…'it is likely to represent a hoard or a portion of a hoard'; Antoninian dynasty - ; silver weight: 17.6-151.6g.
disposition: Musée des Antiquités de Rouen, France. Museum Inventory III, p. 61, no. 2157 (donated 17.5.1909)

summary: A hoard of 52 bronze antoniniani (Gallienus - Tetricus) found in the quarry of Weisenau in 1910.
113 coins: Claudius I - Trajan Decius (AD 249-251). No information on the denominations or other issuers.
43 coins, part of a larger hoard: Republic - Severus Alexander (AD 222-235).
4,128 coins found in two vessels: 3 denarii, 4,125 antoniniani (radiates): Caracalla - Trebonianus Gallus (AD 252).
140 silver coins: 26 denarii, 114 antoniniani: Septimius Severus to Trajan Decius (AD 249-251); silver weight: 175.6-362.9 g.
Unknown number of provincial bronze coins. 20 pieces entered the museum collection in Shumen: Septimius Severus - Gordian III (AD 238-244).
disposition: Regional History Museum, Shumen, Bulgaria; inv. no. 825-844 (20 coins)

summary: 942 coins: 1 aureus (Caracalla) mounted in a necklace, 939 silver coins, denarii and antoniniani: Vespasian to Philip I, and 2 bronze coins (missing today). The hoard comprised gold (600 g) as well and silver jewellery (400 g), a shallow silver dish and a silver salt box.
(3000) 2,873 denarii and antoniniani: Nero - Philip I (AD 244-249)
disposition: Magyar Nemzeti Múzeum, Budapest, Hungary (6 coins), in 1865

summary: Unknown number of antoniniani, among, those of Aurelian and Severina.
disposition: Regional History Museum, Vratsa, Bulgaria (2 coins)

summary: The hoard comprised 49 sestertii from Trajan to Philip I and 2 Provincial bronzes from Patras (Caracalla).
140 provincial bronze coins, possible kept in a leather bag. 110 pieces entered the museum collection in Dalgopol: Septimius Severus - Philip I (AD 244-249)
disposition: History Museum, Dalgopol, Bulgaria; inv.no. N. 00518/1-110

summary: 100 silver coins were discovered. 24 have been seen: 9 antoniniani, 15 denarii: Caracalla - Philip I (AD 244-249).

The hoard comprised almost 600 antoniniani (radiates) or imitations. Sauvage examined two lots of 120 and 12 pieces, some of which were acquired by the Musée de Boulogne. A further lot was found in the Musée de Boulogne by Seillier and Leclercq. The rest of the hoard probably comprised barbarous radiates which the museum decided not to acquire: Valerian I and Gallienus (Valerian I) - Tacitus (AD 275-276).
Unknown number of coins found in a ceramic vessel on the area of an a ancient settlement. 85 provincial bronze coins entered the museum collection in Plovdiv: Antoninus Pius - Philip I (AD 244-249).
disposition: Museum of Archaeology, Plovdiv, Bulgaria; inv.no. 2237

summary: The hoard comprised a copper-alloy vase containing 73 antoniniani (radiates) (or 60 according to Blanchet) from Gallienus to Probus.
500 sestertii found in a ceramic vessel: Vespasian - Severus alexander (AD 226).
Roman Provincial coins: Thessalonica (1 Elagabalus, 1 Gordian III, 1 Otacilia Severa), Pella (2 Gordian III, 1 Otacilia Severa), found in a grave.
Hoard of 80 bronze staters of the Bosporan king, Rhescuporis V (AD 242-277).

The finders show to Abbe Moreau c. 6,700 antoniniani (radiates). The workers discovered the hoard in three vessels and shared the coins. V. Huguenot studied few coins of this hoard, from Antoninus Pius (probably Elagabalus) to Postumus (AD 260-269).
1120 silver coins: 711 denarii, 409 antoniniani: Hadrian - Valerian I (AD 254-255); silver weight: 1401.3-2899.5 g.
disposition: County Museum Râmnicu Vâlcea, Romania (779 coins); County Museum Giurgiu, Romania (344 coins); Silviu Istrate Puerece Collection, Sibiu, Romania (4 coins)

summary: The hoard comprised a ceramic vessel containing 460 silver coins. Auvray mentions Gordian III, Philip, Trajan Decius, Volusian, Trebonianus Gallus and Valerian. In 1834, Pesche compiled a more complete catalogue. His source (although he does not acknowledge it) appears to be a manuscript held by the Sociétè d'Agriculture which describes Roman coins found in the city of Le Mans and its environs. Pesche adds to his catalogue coins of Marcus Aurelius, Faustina II, Lucius Verus, Lucilla and Pupienus. It is not clear whether these coins are part of the hoard. Silver: c.460 (1, 173) coins; silver weight: c. 576.7-1295.1g.

The hoard comprised a black ceramic jug containing 8,500 coins (22kg). A list of types that would interest collectors was produced. Fillon notes that coins of Gallienus, Victorinus, Tetricus I and Claudius II made up the majority of the hoard and that were about 20 coins of Aurelian. There was a radiate of Victorinus with a IOVI CONSERVATORI reverse copying an issue of Aurelian in that it reproduced the officina mark P for Milan. The hoard was found by a farmer in his field. The vessel was kept in the Collection de Rouchebrune. Fillon bought the coins for the Soc. Antiq. Ouest.
Unknown number of coins from Gordian III, Philip I, Philip II, Trajan Decius, Etruscilla, Trebonianus Gallus, Valerian I, Gallienus and Salinina. 4 coins were donated to the Musée Château d'Annecy.
disposition: Musée Château d'Annecy, France; 4 coins, inv.no. 1055-1057-

summary: Roman coin hoard found in a pot during clay digging. 55 coins are preserved today with two further coins only known by their description, but the hoard might have comprised more coins. The coins range from Titus to Trajan Decius and were both bronze (48 sestertii and 1 dupondius) and silver (3 denarii and 5 antoniniani).
A hoard of 8 Roman Provincial coins from the mints of Thessalonica, Edessa, Pella and the Macedonian Koinon from the period AD 222-235, found in grave 52 in the western cemetery of Pella.
Large hoard of silver coins. Only 5 pieces are known: Aurelian 2, Tacitus 1, Probus 2; silver weight: 1.0-1.4g.
5 denarii found with a bronze item in a well: Trajan/Hadrian - Caracalla/Elagabalus. (201-222).
(896) 890 silver coins: Septimius Severus - Trebonianus Gallus (Ad 251-253).

A hoard of 358 tetradrachms (Septimius Severus - Philip II), denarii (Crispina - Gordian III) and antoniniani (Julia Donna - Trebonianus Gallus) from Dura Europos, found in a common-ware jar near the citadel.
The hoard comprised approximately 500 Roman billon coins (radiates), with the most recent being issues of Diocletian and Maximian.
61 silver coins found in a Roman villa: 22 denarii, 39 antoniniani: Septimius Severus - Trajan Decius (AD 249-251); silver weight: 100.8-168.5 g.
The hoard comprised 8,864 antoniniani (radiates) Valerian I - Carinus (tpq AD 283, Numerian). Silver weight: 1596.1-6470.3 g.
(300) 194 Ant: Gordian III - Valerianus I or Gallienus (sole reign ?) Gordian III 52
52 denarii, 51 antoniniani (radiates), 1 quinarius: Trajan - Philip I (AD 244-249).

A hoard of more than 212 coins (Valerian I - Postumus) came into view in 1969 on Saarstrasse 135 during building work; it was dispersed. The RLMT bought 91 coins, 121 further coins were seen in private collections.

The hoard comprised a greyware vessel containing 9 aurei, some gold jewellery and a jet amulet. Gold: 9 coins; Gold weight: 45.4-46.0g. The entire hoard was acquired by Dr. E. Poncet for his private collection.

Hoard of 223 coins: 6 aurei, 217 denarii and antoniniani (radiates): Severus Alexander - Postumus (AD 260-269); gold weight: 27.1-30.0g.; silver weight: 59.8-315.7g. Together was found a ring (metal not specified).
246 denarii found while ploughing: Hadrian - Septimius Severus (AD 202)
The hoard comprised 19 antoniniani (radiates) dated between AD 255-257 and AD 271-272.
The hoard comprised approximately 1,200 radiates of 'the epoque of Postumus and some contemporary official and ursurper emperors.'
The hoard was found inside a textile bag placed within a ceramic vessel and comprised approximately 300 silver coins, apparently all antoniniani (radiates). The hoard has a tpq of AD 261.
331 coins : 322 sestertii, 1 dupondius and 8 uncertain sestertii: Galba - Severus Alexander (AD 232).
The hoard comprised a ceramic vessel holding approximately 300 'small bronzes' (radiates): Elagabalus - Postumus (AD 263).

There are two different notes regarding hoards found in this area in the 1880s. The author argues that the notes relate to the same hoard. A) A bronze vase containing silver coins of the third century AD was found in Sardoal. 12 of these coins were acquired by the Ethnographic Museum. B) The Ethnographic Museum in Abrantes acquired 190 silver coins dating to the third century AD, which formed part of a hoard found in Sardoal in the 1880s.
disposition: Museu Nacional de Arqueologia, Lisboa, Portugal

summary: The hoard was found in a stone conduit at a mineral water source and comprised 67 Roman bronze and billon coins from Claudius I to Tetricus I.
The hoard comprised silver denarii and radiates from Septimius Severus to Gallienus with a tpq of AD 254.
(6-700) 23 coins silver coins: Marcus Aurelius - Valerian I (AD 253-260).
(2000) 167 silver coins: Trajan - Trajan Decius (AD 249-251); silver weight: 39.3-79.5 g.
1 denarius, 33 antoniniani (radiates), 16 sesterti, 16 antoniniani (radiates) fragments, 4 nummi: Hadrian - Gordian III (AD 238-244).

HER record of a scattered hoard of 117 coins from Gallienus to Tetricus "with one very clipped denarius" and further finds from area. As far as it is possible to ascertain, this is not part of the other hoards recorded from the parish.

of 4,033 pieces, 3296 were recorded at the British Museum: 592 denarii, Domitian-Gordian III; 2704 antoniniani, Caracalla-Trajan Decius, including 2 “Divi”. The other were all antoniniani of Gordian III, Philip I, Philip II and Trajan Decius.
17 antoniniani (radiates) found while building a house: Valerian I and Gallienus (Gallienus) - Probus (AD 276-282).

A hoard of 11 coins (denarii and bronze coins ranging from Hadrian to Alexander Severus) was found in 1965 in a walled Roman stone cellar, west of the Jewish cemetery. It lay concealed without a container under the threshold to the cellar.
Hoard of 493 silver coins found in a ceramic vessel: 492 antoniniani (radiates), 1 denarius: Septimius Severus (Caracalla Augustus) - Aurelian (AD 270-275); silver weight: 134.9-1281.3 g.
A hoard of 3 Roman Provincial coins minted at Thessalonica (2 of Elagabalus, 1 Gordian III), found in grave 35 in the western cemetery of Pella. The grave also contained numerous other artefacts.
An Antoninianus of Gordian III, discovered along with 10 other similar coins in 1909 during the construction of the Baumgartenbridge over the Havel-Schielow lake.
Hoard of denarii and antoniniani found in a ceramic vessel. 78 pieces entered the museum collection in Plovdiv: Severus Alexander - Probus (AD 276-282).
disposition: Museum of Archaeology, Plovdiv, Bulgaria; inv.no. 2072

summary: 37 sestertii: Hadrian - Elagabalus (AD 221-222).

A hoard of 24 provincial coins (ranging from Antoninus Pius to Geta) and 5 antoniniani (Gallienus) were found in a small pocket behind the stage of the theatre in Corinth, at the level of the marble pavement.
An urn of antoniniani (radiates) found between Sizzano and Fara. Only two coins are known of Philip I and Claudius II, as being donated to the museum in Fara.
disposition: Museo dal Sig. Luigi Spagnolini di Fara (on the May 10, 1886; donation record no. 723 (3)

summary: 74 (FMRO VI/1), around 60 bronze coins (Dembski 1977) were found in a Roman well. No certainty whether these coins belonged to a hoard or they were single finds as votive offerings. The coins minted segment: Tiberius - Numerian.
25 provincial bronze coins found in a ceramic vessel: Antoninus Pius - Severus Alerxander (AD 222-235). Mints: Nicopolis ad Istrum, Marcianopolis
The hoard comprised a vessel filled with 76 antoniniani (radiates) from Balbinus to Postumus (AD 260-269).

According to Liger, the hoard comprised a black ceramic vessel containing 62 coins of the Early Empire. However, according to Barbe, there were 15 coins discovered in the vessel including one of Claudius II. TAF notes that Liger often exaggerated his descriptions of hoards.
3 coins: Hadrian dupondius, Septimius Severus denarius, Gordian III dupondius (AD 238-244).

6,263 denarii and antoniniani (radiates): Rome (4,921); Viminiacum (4); Milan (340), Ticinum (6); Cologne (44); Trier (38); Lyon (2); Siscia (216); Sirmium (2); Antioch (2); Cyzicus (12); uncertain (4); imitations (1,068): Gordian III - Diocletian (AD 287-289). Found during the laying of electrical cables.

A small hoard of 30 coins, ranging from Gallienus to Diocletian, discovered on the site of a Romano-British villa, on a rough stone pathway next to a building. The building had been in use from the middle of the third century, and was demolished soon after 367.

Mints: Rome (332); Nicomedia (11: Elagabalus); Antioch (6: 1 Caracalla and 5 Gordian III); 3 copies of Gordian III. Silver: 139, 213 coins; Silver weight: 462.0-912.5g The hoard was found during levelling works at a sawmill.
Hoard of circa 100 antoniniani (radiates), only 7 were recovered, period of AD 260-275; silver weight: c. 28.0-124.0 g.

(100) 75 silver coins found with a ceramic vessel: 44 denarii, 29 antoniniani: Septimius Severus - Philip I (AD 244-247); silver weight: 101.7-155.2 g; together with irregular pieces of gold (13.5 g) found in a vessel
disposition: Museum of Roman and Dacian Civilisation Deva, Romania (73 coins, gold pieces, and the 3 sherds), Museum of Petroșani, Romania (2 coins)

summary: 157 antoniniani (radiates): Gordian III - Postumus (AD 260-269); silver weight: 43.5-370.6 g.
disposition: Collection Huybrigts, Tongeren, Belgium, in 1902; destroyed by fire in 1914

summary: Unknown originally number of coins. Only 38 sestertii were recovered: Domitian - Valerian I (AD 253-260).
2,000 denarii and antoniniani. 872 coins in the Regional History Museum in Vratsa: Vespasian - Philip I (AD 244-249).
disposition: Regional History Museum, Vratsa, Bulgaria; inv. nos. M III 5335-6194 (860 coins); inv.nos. 8407-8418 (12 coins)

summary: 1,680 silver coins: 1085 denarii, 595 antoniniani: Commodus - Valerian I (Gallienus (AD 254); silver weight: 2151.6-3837.1 g.
Four radiates foundfused together.

The hoard was recovered from the site of a Gallo-Roman vicus during illegal excavations and comprised a denarius of Septimius Severus and 561 sestertii from Vespasian to Septimius Severus (ad 193-211).

The hoard comprised 1,094 antoniniani (radiates) including issues of Valerian I, Gallienus, Postumus, Marius, Victorinus, Claudius II, Divus Claudius II, Quintillus, Tetricus I, Tetricus II and Aurelian. Silver weight: 208.4-798.1 g.
The hoard comprised 31 sestertii from Vespasian to Commodus, 1 dupondius of Caracalla and 281 denarii and antoniniani (radiates). Hobbs estimates a silver weight of 351.8g to 729.5g

A hoard of 500 silver coins (Mark Antony - Caracalla) found in a beaker on a new housing site, to be known as Clarney Place. The find was made 400 yards from the Darfield 1947 (Darfield I) hoard, but their depositions do not seem to be related. Carson and Corder published the hoard in 1948, but the catalogue does not align exactly to the coin summary. Trajan, Hadrian, Septimius Severus and Caracalla all have one fewer specimens in the catalogue compared to the summary, while the reverse is true for Otho. Since it is agreed that the hoard numbered 500, the summary has been regarded as the correct description of the hoard's contents.
45 silver coins: Republic - Severus Alexander (AD 222-235).
199 Roman imperial large bronze coins found with a ceramic vessel: Hadrian - Valerian I and Gallienus/ Gallienus (sole) (AD 253-268).Possible part of the same hoard as Capoterra 1928a.
(1900) 1898 silver coins: Septimius Severus - Valerian I and Gallienus (AD 256-257); silver weight: 1324.4-2705.9 g.
disposition: Regional History Museum, Pleven, Bulgaria; inv. no. 923 1-248

summary: 15 radiates (Gallienus to the Tetrici) from a larger hoard of unknown size discovered while ploughing a field somewhere outside Fishguard. No further details are available.
Circa 500 coins, among which: 468 sestertii, 2 dupondii/asses: Titus - Philip I (AD 244-249).
11 antoniniani of Philip I found in a small ceramic vessel (AD 244-249)
1,602 silver coins: denarii, quinarii, antoniniani (radiates), drachm: Trajan - Trajan Decius (AD 249-251).
56 denarii: Mark Antony - Caracalla (AD 214); silver weight: 87.8-167.0g.
disposition: Voralberg Museum, Bregenz, (initial 51 coins, in 1977 46); Private collection, Innsbruck (1 coin), Austria

summary: The hoard comprised a small earthenware vessel containing 100 'small bronzes' (radiates) of which 86 were identified by the finder: Valerian I and Gallienus/ Gallienus (sole) for Gallienus - Tetricus I (Ad 271-274).
6 uncertain imperial coins (Vespasian-Aurelian).

The hoard comprised 202 antoniniani (radiates), placed inside a sandstone altar and found in association with a variety of objects in copper-alloy, iron and ceramic. The latest coin is an issue of Postumus dating to AD 266.
539 denarii and 538 antoniniani (radiates): Trajan - Postumus (AD 260-269).

74 coins found with a Roman bronze jug: Vespasian - Valerian I (AD 256-257). Together were found: an Almgren 157 fibula, five bracelets, a pendant and two silver ingots on silver. The discovery has been interpreted as a silver craftsman hoard.
disposition: Muzeul Județean de Istorie și Arheologie Prahova, ploiești, Romania (inv.nos. 72696-72766)

summary: 32 coins: 23 sestertii, 7 dupondii and 2 antoniniani (radiates): Titus - Postumus (AD 260-268).
Uknown number of silver Roman coins. 1 denarius of Severus Alexander and 2 coins of Gordian III are known.
(235?) 232 silver coins found with a ceramic vessel: Septimius Severus – Aurelian (AD 270-275).
disposition: Union National Museum, Alba Iulia, Romania (Inv.no. 1787-3408)

summary: The hoard comprised 36 silver coins - antoniniani (radiates) - of Gordian III to Postumus and 6 copper-alloy coins from Trajan to Faustina II.
131 billon Alexandrian tetradrachms: Nero - Valerian I and Gallienus (AD 258-259). Purchased by Currelly and Frost from "native diggers".
disposition: 'Selection in Oxford, where there is also a handwritten list (Milne); some of the rest are probably in Toronto.'

summary: A hoard of 15,000 - 20,000 coins, found ploughing a field at Riby Wold Farm on the east side of Lincolnshire Wolds, some 4-5 miles north-east of Caistor. The coins are all antoniniani, ranging from Gordian III to Probus, AD 281. Included were many coins of Gallienus, and of emperors from the Gallic Empire.
disposition: Lincoln City and County Museum (part: pot and 24 coins); Ashmoleum Museum (part)

summary: 11 coins: 1 aureus, 9 denarii, 1 bronze: Marcus Aurelius - Elagabalus (AD 218-222); gold weight: 7.1-7.2 g; silver weight: 17.2-22.6 g.

Found during construction work, partially supervised by an archaeologist, in the ruins of a Roman rural building; 15 sestertii, Antoninus Pius to Philipp I, found together with shards possibly of a container. The hoard has been interpreted as a 'Bauopfer' or foundation deposit.
23 antoniniani (radiates): Claudius II - Tetricus I (AD 271-274; silver weight: 0.4-0.6g.
The hoard comprised 32 coins, including 2 denarii and 30 antoniniani (radiates) from Julia Maesa to Postumus. It is suggested that they were originally stored in a box.
76 billon tetradrachms of Alexandria: Nero - Gallinus (sole) (AD 262-263) found in a disintegrated cloth bag at floor level in room during excavations of a house.

The hoard comprised two vessels containing 3,080 coins. Cousin mentions 3,074 coins, but the list of reverses that he gives has a total of 3,071 and the total by emperor is 3,084. He also described reverse types but does not match them with their obverses. The last coins are 115 SAECVLI FELICITAS issues of Postumus (Elmer 593). It was found within 7 or 8 metres of Hoard ÉTAPLES 1840 1 during archaeological excavations directed by L. Cousin.
The hoard comprised 3 Roman Provincial coins: Thessalonica (1 pseudo-autonomous, 1 Commodus, 1 Alexander Severus), found in a grave in the west cemetery of Thessalonica (area of Ramona).
94 antoniniani (radiates): Valerian and Gallienus/Gallienus (sole) - Tacitus (AD 275-276).
Hoard of 32 coins found with ceramic vessel: 21 denarii, 11 sestertii: Trajan - Severus alexander (AD 222-235).
The hoard comprised a red ceramic vessel containing 4,066 radiates of Postumus, Macrianus, Tetricus I, Tetricus II, Victorinus, Gallienus, Claudius II, Aurelian and Tacitus.
An unpublished hoard of 3 provincial coins (Dium, Thessalonica and the Koinon of Macedonia) and 4 blanks, from a building within the city.
Denarius hoard consisting of 114 denarii found through metal detectoring and excavation. Otho to Caracalla. 119 fragments in total.
Unknown number of silver coins. Dr. Harlanov examined 23 pieces: Trajan - Elagabalus (AD 218-219); silver weight: 41.3-66.1 g.
2,596 denarii (among: 1 plated, 47 'barbarous'): Republic - Caracalla (AD 214).
The hoard comprised 'some 500 denarii and antoniniani (radiates) of which only 20 were examined' Found at the ancient port in unknown circumstances.
162 billon Alexandrian tetradrachms: Claudius I - Trebonianus Gallus (AD 252-253). 'Purchased by Currelly and Frost from "native diggers".'
229 antoniniani (radiates): Valerian I and Gallienus - Diocletian (AD 284-293).
disposition: Museum of Pavia, Coin Room (inv.nos. 4.54, 4.59, 4.82, 4.101-4.866 not always in sequential order)

summary: 24 silver coins found in a stone quarry: Septimius Severus - Trajan Decius (AD 249-251)
disposition: Archaeological Museum, Veliko Tarnovo, Bulgaria; inv. nos. 2424-2446 (24 coins)

summary: The hoard comprised 773 aurei - 18 coins were already missing in 1874 - from Claudius I to Septimius Severus (Geta Caesar) with a tpq of AD 205-207 and was found in association with a staircase, presumably part of a Roman building or cellar. There are at least 3 different catalogues giving different totals of coins and it is likely that on discovery several coins were retained by the workmen who discovered the find. The Cabinet des Médailles acquired 15 coins from the hoard, for which RIC level data is available. Hobbs estimates a gold weight of approximately 8520.6 to 9239.4g.
874 antoniniani (radiates) found in a ceramic vessel: Valerian I and Gallienus/Gallienus (sole) - Aurelian (AD 270-275).

A hoard of ca. 2400 silver coins, most of them ranging from Septimius Severus to Gallienus, was unearthed in house no. 45 in 1902. 700 specimens arrived in the Kempten Heimatmuseum, several others in private ownership. The provenance of the coins in the Kempten museum can't be ascertained any more, but FMRD publishes a list of 21 coins with RIC references, and a summary list of 363 coins that probably came from this hoard.

The hoard comprised a vessel containing 94 bronze coins, of which 82 were examined. They included 2 sestertii and 80 double sestertii of Postumus, mostly LAETITIA AVG, VICTORIA AVG and FIDES MILITVM reverse types. Tpq AD 266-267
Circa 150 antoniniani (radiates). 77 coins, including 24 copies. Together was found a small bronze hatchet: Gallienus - Tetricus I (AD 271-274); silver weight: c.35.0-156.5g.
disposition: Musée des Antiquités de Rouen (collection Thaurin), France (77 coins). Hoards file in the Archives of the Museum (no inv.nos)

summary: The hoard comprised a vessel containing 13kg of Roman coins (between 4500 and 4600 coins). Breuillac studied 2300 'small bronzes and billon coins' dating from Valerian to Aurelian, although Allard also notes a coin of Philip I. The hoard was found in a ditch close to the ruins of the Château de Curzay; silver weight: c. 1216.0-5624.1g.
The hoard comprised 16 radiates from Aurelian to Probus, found on the Agora in Athens beneath the post-Herulian wall, lost during the construction of that wall.

There were 914 antoniniani (radiates) in the hoard. The obverse details for each coin were not recorded and it is not possible to assign the coins to mints. Although Mira (1995-7, 137) gives the total number of coins as 914, only 905 are accounted for in the catalogue.
48 antoniani found as a roll in a destruction layer at the eastern gate of the Roman fort: Claudius II - Carinus (AD 283-284).
16 gold staters of the Bosporan kings: Sauromates II, Rhescuporis III.

559 denarii - 1,607.31 g found with a ceramic vessel: Nero - Septimius Severus (AD 193-211). ToOn the same field were found a rectangular bronze pendants and one of gold and a brooch. Uncertain whether these artefacts are connected to the hoard.
(884/894?) bronze coins - "mostly sestertii": 648 sestertii, 8 dupondii/asses, 1 provincial: Domitian - Trebonianus Gallus (AD 251-253).
The hoard comprised 14 antoniniani (radiates) dated between AD 260/1 and 270.
disposition: The University of Michigan Kelsey Museum of Ancient and Mediaeval Archaeology

summary: Seven imitations of silver denominations; silver weight: 151.4-695.3 g.
79 denarii and antoniniani were found with a ceramic vessel: Caracalla - Philip I (AD 244-249).

The hoard comprised a black ceramic vessel containing a hoard of coins and jewellery. The jewellery included a gold necklace, 3 gold intaglio finger rings, a gold and silver intaglio finger ring and an iron finger ring with silver decoration. The number of coins in the hoard is not known with any certainty. Pérot claims there were 100 sestertii and 150 denarii, whereas Clément catalogued 92 coins, including 67 bronzes (mostly sestertii) and 25 denarii (and radiates?). There were some identification errors with 1 sestertius and 2 denarii attributed to Antoninus Pius, when in fact they were issues of Caracalla.
The hoard comprised 24 antoniniani: Gallienus (sole)-Claudius II (Divus) (AD 270 AD).
disposition: Museo Civico Bottacin di Padova, Italy (inv.nos. 24174-24196)

summary: The hoard was found during the course of a rescue excavation and comprised 8 antoniniani (radiates) from Gordian III to Valerian and Gallienus.
A hoard of 276 tetradrachms (Caracalla - Trebonianus Gallus) from Dura Europos, found in room 2 of B. 8, east of the Agora.
The hoard comprised approximately 1,400 radiates from Gallienus to Tacitus Hobbs estimates a silver weight of between 337g and 1084g.
30 provincial bronze coins minted in the 3rd century AD found by metal detecting within the area of an ancient settlement.
A hoard of 119 antoniniani (radiates) was found with a ceramic vessel: Caracalla - Trajan Decius (AD 249-251). Together were found a silver anchor type brooch and a glass vessel.
339 denarii: Vespasian - Maximinus I Thrax (AD 236-238).
Circa 30 silver coins were found with a ceramic vessel. 10 antoniniani (radiates) were identified: Gordian III - Valerian I (Gallienus) (AD 254-255).

In 1978, Mr. Charles Pire, a coin dealer from Brussels, bought about 500 pieces from a lot of 972 coins found in the region of Amiens. It consisted generally of about fifteen antoniniani (radiates) of Gallienus and Salonina, a dozen of Postumus, a hundred of Victorinus, around 20 of Claudius II, about 300 of Tetricus I and II from the mints of Trier and Cologne. Other 30 pieces consisted of imitations of Tetricus I, large module. 235 coins are presented in detail: Trebonianus Gallus - Tetricus I (AD 271-273); silver weight: 185.7-1213.9 g.
disposition: Private collections: Ms. A. Wattecamps; Mr. S. Genvier; Mr. J.-M. Doyen; Mr. Pire

summary: An unknown number of silver coins: 1 denarius, 16 antoniniani (radiates): Septimius Severus - Philip I (AD 244-249).
disposition: Museum of Archaeology, Plovdiv, Bulgaria; inv.no. 2631

summary: NMR record of a small radiate hoard of 8 coins found whilst building a house in Keighley in the late nineteenth century.
500 silver coins: Marcus Aurelius - Philip I (AD 244-249); silver weight: c. 625.6-1298.9 g.
disposition: Museum of Archaeology, Plovdiv, Bulgaria; inv. no. 1918

summary: Unknown originally number of coins. Only eight silver coins are known: 5 antoniniani (radiates), 3 denarii: Caracalla – Gallienus (sole).
Hoard of over 5,000 antoniniani (radiates) and imitations: Gallienus - Aurelian (AD 270-275).
The hoard comprised 'a block of between 200 and 400 radiates.': Gordian III - Postumus (AD 260-269.

Between 25,000-30,000 coins found in two bronze vessels: 8 or 10 aurei from Hadrian to Severus Alexander; 5 bronze coins (Septimius Severus, Severus Alexander, Philip II, Postumus); 1 bronze medallion of Severus Alexander (with Julia Mamaea); 25,000-30,000 silver and billon coins from Claudius (I/II?) to Postumus; gold weight: c. 64.8 g; Silver: c.25-30,000 coins; Silver weight: c.7427.6-71498.9. Together were found jewelry: 30 gold and silver rings; two or three pairs of gold earrings; a pair of bracelets, two styla, 30 silver spoons; a gold necklace (?).

A hoard of ca. 677 provincial coins, ranging from Commodus Caesar to the joint reign of Valerian and Gallienus (AD 253-60), found in the sanctuary of Apollo Smintheion. Coins were mainly minted in Alexandria Troas (665 coins), but also in Parium (6 coins) and Abydus (1 coin). Çizmeli connects the deposition of this hoard with the invasions of the Goths in Asia Minor.
disposition: Laboratoire du Musée des Civilisations Anatoliennes, Ankara, Turkey

summary: 7 denarii: Trajan 1, Marcus Aurelius 1, Severus Alexander 1, uncertain 4.
27 coins. 26 denarii. One possible barbarian imitation: Septimus Severus- Severus Alexander (ca. AD 235.)

1200-1300 bronze coins, found in a vessel south of the Roman fort, together with a silver ring. The coins were dispersed. 25 of them were described, and 11 further coins are still preserved in the museum Landshut (therefore, 36 are listed in FMRD, ranging from Vespasian to Severus Alexander).
1,020 coins; 9 aurei Vespasian to Plautilla. Gold: 9 coins; Gold weight: 64.0-64.7g; Silver: 1011 coins; Silver weight: 1851.2-2920.7g

The hoard comprised one bronze vessel containing 7150 radiates from Tetricus I, Tetricus II, Valerian, Gallienus, Claudius Gothicus, Aurelianus and Probus. It must be linked to the treasure LA VINEUSE II
Ritual deposit. Found during a metal detectorists' illegal survey. 2 antoniniani, Gordian III and Philip the Arab.
At least 1,772 antoniniani (radiates) found with a copper alloy jug: Claudius II - Diocletian-Maximian I (AD 287-288).
(169) 137 coins: 5 denarii, 1 antoninianus (radiate), 1 as: Domitian - Gordian III (AD 241-243); silver weight: 10.0-16.2 g
disposition: Archaeological Museum, Namur, Belgium (137, maybe 169 coins)

summary: Silver: (c.3500) 1100 silver coins: Augustus - Philip I (AD 244-249); silver weight: c.4377.3-12562.7 g.
disposition: Musée Curtius, Liège, Belgium (3 coins); Collection L. Renard-Grenson, Liège, Belgium (147 coins)

summary: 750 silver coins found in a ceramic vessel. 726 pieces studied: 502 antoniniani, 224 denarii: Hadrian - Philip I (AD 244-249); silver weight: c. 940.4-2135.9 g. Found together with bronze statuettes of horses.
disposition: Museum of Archaeology, Plovdiv, Bulgaria; inv. no. 2525; History Museum, Kardzhali, Bulgaria;

summary: 313 antoniniani (radiates): Gordian III - Gallienus (sole) (AD 260-268).
32 coins found scattered on an area of 3sqm: Gallienus (sole) - Aurelian (AD 270-275).
339 antoniniani (radiates): Valerian I and Gallienus - Tetricus I (AD 271-274). Silver: 254, 85 coins; silver weight: 69.6-316.5g.
It is unclear whether this is a complete hoard or belongs to other coin finds (not recorded).

A hoard of ca. 2000 bronze coins was discovered in 1902 in Eleusis, a few metres east of the peribolos wall of the sanctuary, in the garden of a coffeehouse belonging to Georgios B. Adam. The hoard was divided into two lots, which were said to have been approximately equal in size. One of these was dispersed. The other, consisting of 972 specimens, was examined and catalogued by Svoronos 1904. It included 958 provincial coins from Athens (time of the Antonines and Gallienus), 1 provincial coin from Thessalonica, 1 from Argos and 12 sestertii (Hadrian à Gordian III).
The coins were found in a cremation burial, mixed in with the cremated bone and ash. The coins comprised an as of Vespasian and 12 sestertii ranging from Domitian to Philip I.
The hoard comprised 1,500 Roman coins from Vespasian to Philip I (AD 244-249).
Five denarii found together: Augustus - Elagabalus (AD 218-222).
43 denarii: Republic - Septimius Severus (AD 206-210). Found together jewels and dices embedded in a wall.
Unknown initial number of antoniniani. 8 pieces entered the museum collection in Sofia: Gordian III 1, Philip I 1, Otacilia Severa 1, Trajan Decius 5.
disposition: National History Museum, Sofia, Bulgaria; inv.nos. 21422-21429 (8 coins)

summary: 126 sestertii: Domitian - Severus Alexander (AD 222-235).
Unknown originally number of coins. Estimations are around 150 coins. 102 denarii are documented: Antoninus Pius (M. Aurelius Caesar) - Severus Alexander (AD 222-235).

A narrow-necked jar with 2000 bronze coins (antoniniani, Gallienus - Tetricus) of mostly good condition were found to the left of the road going towards Reimsbach ('auf der Hirtenwiese'), along a Roman road. Only 78 coins were examined.
The hoard comprised 4,000 sestertii from Augustus to Valerian I and Gallienus (AD 253-268).
disposition: Some of the coins were in the possession of colonel de Tourville (in 1846)

summary: Two radiate minimi (8 and 7 mm, 0.40 and 0.34 g., one with head to left, and one from dies too big for the flan), found with 'about seven others' and a coin of Victorinus (Elmer 743, slightly worn) were discovered on the 13th tee of Pyle and Kenfig golf-course, before 1955. There were also some fragments of pottery.
disposition: National Museum of Wales (part); Grosvernor Museum (part)

summary: It comprised c. 400 silver coins. Only 149 are now recorded: 148 antoniniani (radiates), 1 denarius: Septimus Severus - Valerian I and Gallienus/Gallienus (sole).
Three denarii were found in a ceramic vessel: Julia Domna 1, Severus Alexander 1, Julia Mamaea 1 (AD 222-235).
disposition: Museum of Archaeology, Plovdiv, Bulgaria; inv.no. 2724

summary: 56 coins found in a ceramic vessel: 21 silver coins, 35 provincial bronzes: Septimius Severus - Philip I (AD 244-249).
disposition: Museum of Archaeology, Plovdiv, Bulgaria; inv. no. 2070

summary: It comprised 93 sestertii found with a ceramic vessel. Only 88 are now recorded: Trajan - Philip I (AD 244-249).
The hoard comprised 327 sestertii and 3 dupondii from Galba to Severus Alexander with a tpq of AD 233.
123 sestertii, ranging from Caracalla to Valerian I.
A small set of coins that were glued together to form a small cylinder were found next to a corpse.
At 3 m from the findspot of MORCHAIN 1, 7 coins: 1 double sestertius, 2 sestertii, 3 asses, 1 antoninianus (radiate): Titus, Hadrian, Faustina I, Marcus Aurelius, Faustina II, Postumus (AD 264-265).
52 coins: 1 denarius, 31 antoniniani (radiates), 5 antoniniani (radiates) imitations, 12 sestertii, 1 dupondius, 2 unknown denomination: Vespasian - Tetricus I (AD 271-274).

Funerary find. 'A large number of coins finds' between large Stone blocks. Near the place were found human bones and funerary inventory. The 30 coins analyzed revealed antoniani of Gallienus, Salonina, Postumus and Claudius II (AD 268-270). No further Information.
disposition: Society of Natural History Savoie (30 coins)

summary: 141 silver coins: 3 denarii, 138 antoniniani: Septimius Severus - Valerian I and Gallienus (AD 253-259); silver weight: 178.1-367.1 g.
33 antoniniani (radiates): Gallienus to Aurelianus (AD 270-275).
disposition: Museo Arch. Reg. "P. Orsi", Siracusa, Italy
