summary: The hoard comprised an unknown number of Roman coins of which 13 were kept and including issues of Trajan to Postumus.
Unknown original number of coins. Only 10 pieces were recovered: 8 denarii, 1 antoninianus (radiate), 1 plated denarius: Trajan - Gordian III (AD 241-243).
1,839 coins: 1,834 billon Alexandrian tetradrachms, 5 Ptolemaic bronze coins: Ptolemaic dynasty - Aurelian (AD 270-275). "Acquired in Egypt by Dattari, who sold it to Milne and Currelly'.
disposition: Partly in Oxford, partly in Toronto. Detailed list in Oxford

summary: The hoard comprised 43 tetradrachms and 95 radiates dating to the third century AD.
Over 191 antoniniani (radiates) found in a ceramic vessel: 1 Aurelian, 190 Probus (AD 276-282).
1,898 coins: 2 denarii, 1,895 antoniniani (radiates), 1 nummus: Valerian I - Tetrarchy I (AD 296-297).
disposition: Musée d'Archéologie de Jura, Lons-le-Saunier, France

summary: The hoard comprised 14 sestertii from Antoninus Pius to Trajan Decius. The hoard was found in the north eastern corner of the Big Northern Room of a Roman building situated near the southern part of the wall in the eastern part of the lower city. It has been interpreted as an 'Emergency Hoard' with a Tpq of AD 249 (?) [RIC IV 107a]. Judging from the wear of the coins, it was desposited soon after the middle of the third century AD.
344 denarii found with ceramic vessel: Nero-Septimius Severus (AD 202); silver weight: 629.0-1075.4g

25 antoniniani (hoard or purse) bought in 1938 from a drunken labouring man who claimed to have found them in the Dünnern river bed. Coins range from Aurelian to Carinus: 15 Aurelian, 9 Probus, 1 Carinus. 22 coins out of the 25 are clearly identified/preserved today (15 Aurelian and 7 Probus).
The hoard comprised 18 antoniniani (radiates) from trebonianus Gallus for Volusian to Postumus with the most recent issue a SAECVLI FELICITAS reverse type (Elmer 593).

43 coins (1 Iron Age silver unit, 42 denarii and antoniniani ranging up to Gordian III) discovered in 1922 in a cave in the cliff above the East Wood, Ashover. A silver ring was found at the same place, in a niche between two large stones.
17 provincial bronze coins of Caracalla found in a ceramic vessel: Serdica 13, Deultum 2, Philippopolis 1, Pautalia 1.
A hoard of three provincial coins, found in a grave in Amphipolis.
242 antoniniani: Philip I - Postumus (AD 260-269).

Found during excavations in the Roman villa rustica of Hüttwilen-Stutheien, in the north-western corner of room VIII. A group of 5 coins, 2 sestertii (Trajan, Hadrian) and 3 antoniniani (Gordian III). Possibly a purse.
8 silver coins: 2 denarii, 6 antoniniani: Maximinus I Thrax - Trajan Decius (Etruscilla) (AD 249-251).
Circa 400 coins of which 87 were studied: Gallienus (sole) - Tetrarchy(AD 299).

Unknown originally number of coins. 119 silver coins: 89 antoniniani (radiates), 27 denarii and 3 uncertain silver denomination: Vespasian - Trajan Decius (AD 251). Hobbs estimates a silver weight of 149.4-301.7 g.
The hoard comprised 50 to 60 'copper or bronze coins' found with a ceramic vessel. The better preserved pieces included sestertii of Valerian I and Salonina.

The hoard comprised a broken ceramic vessel containing 33 aurei, one gold necklace, two bracelets and one gold ingot. The aurei range in date from Marcus Aurelius as Caesar to Diocletian. Hobbs estimates a gold weight of c. 171.6-221.5g.

In 1890, during railway excavations on the Shipley estate, an earthenware jar, filled with a large mass of corroded coins was found. These to the number of a thousand or more were quickly dispersed. Out of a casual collection of nineteen, may be read the names of Claudius, Aurelianus, Gallienus, Tacitus, Victorinus and Tetricus while others bear the names of Vespasian and Clodius. Cockayne added Postumus, Tetricus II and Constantine to the list of emperors included; G. Bailey, in Antiquary, XXII (1890), 187, added Probus.
8 coins: 5 double sestertii, 2 sestertii, 1 dupondius: Antoninus Pius - Postumus (AD 261-269).
The hoard comprised 94 provincial bronze coins dated between AD 49/50 and 252/3.

The hoard was found in a ceramic vessel and comprised 368 coins including denarii and sestertii from Trajan to Marcus Aurelius and Provincial bronzes of the Koinon of Thessaly from Marcus Aurelius to Maximinus I. It was accompanied by some pieces of gold jewellery.
disposition: Éphorie des antiquités préhistoriques et classiques de Larissa

summary: 1,745 coins: 1,742 antoniniani (radiates), 3 denarii: Gallienus - Diocletian (AD 285); silver weight: 318.0-439.9 g.
Over 2,897 antoniniani (radiates): Treboninaus Gallus - Claudius II (AD 268-270).
disposition: Landesmuseum Joanneum, Graz, Austria (for restoration work - in 1977)

summary: The hoard was found placed on a masonry slab and comprised a sestertius of Hadrian and 21 double sestertii of Postumus, including 4 imitations.
The hoard comprised a tinned copper-alloy vessel containing several hundred antoniniani (radiates) of Tetricus I (AD 271-274).
Unknown initial number of coins. 12 antoniniani are kept in the local museum of Sevlievo: Gordian III - Trajan Decius (AD 249-251).
5 antoniniani (radiates) of Gallienus (sole) (AD 260-268), most likely, part of other hoards found here (e.g. Dalheim II). Was found in a jug that was destroyed by a plow.
A scattered hoard of 23 radiates (Salonina to Victorinus) found within the remains of an enclosed Romano-British farmstead.

37 provincial bronze coins minted in Marcianopolis 22, Anchialus 7, Hadrianopolis 6, Nicopolis ad Istrum 1 and Serdica 1. Y. Youroukova published five coins of Gordian III and one of Tranquillina, minted in Hadrianopolis.

This hoard comprised 522 coins: 7 denarii, 515 antoniniani (radiates): Septimius Severus - Postumus (AD 260-263). Beside were discovered: 7 gold rings, 6 silver rings, 1 silvered bronze ring, 1 gold earring and 1 bronze earring.

The hoard was found in a ' copper alloy moneybox in an inhumation grave and contained coins of Claudius II, Tetricus etc.' Taking into account the size of the moneybox, the hoard cannot have comprised more than 20 or 30 coins
133 sestertii studied from a total of 300 found: Trajan - Valerian I and Gallienus (AD 2543-259).
Hoard 141 denarii found with a ceramic vessel: Vespasian - Elagabalus (AD 218-222). Weight: 484.16g.
(8-10 kg) 36 antoniniani (radiates) of Claudius II, Aurelian, Tacitus, Florian, Probus, Carinus, Magna Urbica, Numerian, Diocletian, Numerian (AD 293-294)
67 coins found in the ruins of an ancient building, on "Trajan's road": 66 silver, 1 bronze of Philip II of Macedon: Philip II of Macedon - Trajan Decius (AD 249-251).
Originally there appear to have been 19 antoniniani (radiates) of Claudius II, However, Mattingly only reported on 18.
25 silver coins: 2 denarius, 23 antoniniani: Caracalla - Trajan Decius (AD 249-251).
The hoard comprised 60 antoniniani (radiates) of Tetricus I and Tetricus II.

A hoard 437 coins (?), composed of 1 denarius (Maximinus) and 436 antoniniani (325: Julia Domna - Gallienus; 111: Gallic empire) to AD 263, found in excavations conducted by the curé M. Duchâtel in Noyers. Note that the catalogue only lists 324 antonininiani for the period Julia Domna - Gallienus and 109 for the Gallic Empire (i.e. 434 coins in total, and not 437).
Part of a larger hoard. 50 silver coins: 13 denarii, 37 antoniniani: Domitian - Philip I (AD 247-249); silver weight: 64.6-130.2 g.
disposition: Regional Museum of History, Stara Zagora, Bulgaria; inv.no. 3173-3186

summary: Unknown number of coins found in the 1980's. 4 pieces: 2 denarii, 2 antoniniani entered the museum collection in Targovishte: Julia Domna, Philip I, Gallienus.

49 coins: 2 denarii, 7 antoniniani, 40 provincial bronze coins: Septimius Severus - Trajan Decius (AD 249-251); 28 provincial bronze coins of Marcianopolis and Nicopolis ad Istrum: Septimius Severus - Gordian III; silver weight: 12.1-19.7 g.
(c. 7 kg) 300 silver coins: Hadrian - Maximian I (A284-293); silver weight: 56.7-852.5 g.
The hoard was found in an iron cooking pot or 'marmite' and comprised an uncertain number of silver coins and some jewellery, such as 'large finger rings'.

On 18 March 2018, photos of five Roman provincial bronze coins Prusias ad Hypion: Macrinus - Gordian III (AD 238-244) with countermarks were published on the Ukrainian forum Violity. According to the finder, they were found at the same site on the territory of Khmelnytskyi region. Given the close chronology of the coins and the fact that they were issued by one mint, most likely it was a hoard. Coins: Macrinus (1), Maximunus Trax (2), Maximunus Trax (Maxim) (1), Gordian III (1).

Found by labourers while ploughing a field near Ibikon. The hoard consisted of 10 silver coins and 169 aes coins, in a pot. The written sources name Maximinus Thrax as latest reign represented. Today only 44 aes coins are preserved: 33 coins in the Museum für Urgeschichte(n), Zug, and 11 coins in the Schweizerisches Landesmuseum, Zürich. The latest coin preserved dates from Commodus (SFI 1707-5.1) Another 12 coins, now in the Museum für Urgeschichte(n), Zug, might be part of the same hoard (SFI 1707-5.2). The latest coin of this lot dates from Gordian III.
disposition: Museum für Urgeschichte(n), Zug; Schweizerisches Landesmuseum, Zürich

summary: Six denarii "fairly close together, possibly a small purse hoard. Not possible to obtain details of 2 of these, but the remaining 4 consists of: Hadrian, Antoninus Pius, Marcus Aurelius for Faustina II, Elagabalus (AD 218-222).
Unknown number of provincial bronze coins. 105 pieces entered the museum collection in Popovo and Targovishte: Trajan - Philip I (AD 244-249).
disposition: History Museum, Popovo, Bulgaria; inv.no. 306 (92 coins); History Museum, Targovishte, Bulgaria; inv.no. 689 (13 coins)

summary: IARCH record for scattered hoard of radiates (for full details see DOR-5D3543). Another hoard was previously found on the same field in 2013 (2013 T221 'Holt') with an addenda found in 2014 (2014 T962).
26 antoniniani (radiates) found with traces of textile recipient: Aurelian - Carinus (AD 283-285).
disposition: Laboratory of Restoration of Soprintendenza Speciale per i Beni Archeologici di Roma (inv. nos. 508899-508924)

summary: The hoard comprised a ceramic vessel containing 1,109 coins. They include 1,108 radiates from Valerian to Tetricus and 1 denarius copy of Elagabalus.
176 coins: 3 medallions, 58 sestertii, 115 antoniniani (radiates): Domitian - Gallienus (AD 260); silver weight: 145.4-337.5 g.
disposition: Archaeological Museum, Namur, Belgium (171 coins); private collection (2 coins), in 1961

summary: 7 antoniniani (radiates): Gordian III - Philip I (AD 244-249).
disposition: History Museum, Yambol, Bulgaria; inv. no. ІІ-2129

summary: 1094 antoniani: Valerian I - Diocletian-Maximian I (AD 292). It was found during dredging works in the River Danube. Apparently, the hoard was originally packed as rolls of coins.
IARCH record for a small hoard of 10 radiates. Possibly associated with the Chalgrove II hoard (IARCH-CB9058) but recorded separately due to uncertainty over this association.

The hoard was found in a well under the Roman ramparts and comprised 18 denarii from Septimius Severus to Severus Alexander and 8 antoniniani (radiates) from Philip I to Trebonianus Gallus. All the coins were from the mint of Rome, with the exception of a denarius of Severus Alexander from Antioch and two denarius copies of Caracalla and Severus Alexander.
27 antoniniani (radiates) of Tetricus I of which 23 imitations

The hoard comprised 'approximately 510 ancient coins including Iron Age Gallic coins and approximately 500 denarii and antoniniani (radiates).' The hoard was immediately dispersed in Rouen. The hoard poses some problems of interpretation. The wife and son of the finder claimed that the coins were discovered in an ancient shipwreck, whereas Gaillard saw them as 'a precious collection of Roman coins gathered together by generations of citizens from Juliobona'
At least 50 denarii and antoniniani (radiates), but only 5 are identified: Septimius Severus - Gordian III (AD 238-244).

The hoard was found during the excavation of a Roman villa and comprised three separate deposits of coins from Gallienus to Probus. The first deposit comprised 29 coins of Postumus. The second deposit comprised 19 radiates from Gallienus to Probus and the third, 5 radiates from Gallienus to Victorinus.

Hoard found in a bronze pot during the removal of a fence. It comprised more than 1,100 radiates, mainly from the Gallic Empire (Postumus, at least 763 coins). Bought by J. J. Wilhelm Bachofen-Burckhardt, Basel, but some coins dispersed in trade (ca. 100 coins). In 1925, his heirs sold 472 coins to the Swiss National Museum. Then, in 1941, they sold the container and the remaining coins to the Historisches Museum Basel.
45 silver coins: 3 denarii, 42 antoniniani (radiates): Caracalla - Valerian I (AD 259-260); silver weight: 57.1-113.3 g
Circa 3000 antoniniani (radiates) with portraits of Gordian III, Philip I, Otacilia Severa, Philip II "and other emperors and empresses of the 3rd century".
Unknown initial number of silver coins. 21 were kept in the museum of Elbing: 7 antoniniani (radiates), 14 denarii: Mark Antony - Trebonianus Gallus (AD 251-253).
disposition: Museum of Archaeology and History in Elblag (former Town Museum Elbing) in 1903.

summary: 3 denarii and 31 antoniniani (radiates), but this is not certain. Septimius Severus - Valerian I (AD 253-260).

A hoard of 46 mostly bronze coins (26 provincial and 20 imperial), ranging from Domitian to Trajan Decius, found scattered on the floor of Villa A, in a destruction layer associated with the Sassanid invasion.
The hoard was found in a cut stone vessel and comprised more than 1,800 antoniniani (radiates) of Gordian III, Gallienus and Carinus.
(247) 162 silver coins: 65 denarii, 97 antoniniani: Septimius Severus - Postumus (AD 266-267).
disposition: Musée Curtius, Liège, Belgium (161 coins, 1 fragment of container)

summary: (200) 162 silver coins: denarii, antoniniani: Antoninus Pius - Trajan Decius (AD 249-251); silver weight: c.251.5-548.5 g. Found together with two bronze bracelets.
1867 coins: 1650 antoniniani (radiates), 215 imitation antoniniani (radiates), 1 sestertius, 1 bronze: Antoninus Pius (Faustina I), Valerian I - Aurelian (AD 270-275); silver weight: 504.5-2330.3 g.

822 billon provincial coins of Alexandria: Marcus Aurelius - Diocletian/Maximian I (AD 294-295). Finding spots according to the Arad dealers from whom Milne bought the hoards in Cairo. The two hoards had almost the same composition, got mixed together on the way back to England, therefore have been listed as a single find.
Unknown number of Roman provincial bronze coins were found in unknown circumstances. 38 pieces are kept in the museum collection in Ruse: Septimius Severus - Gordian III (AD 238-244).
disposition: National History Museum, Sofia, Bulgaria; inv. nos. 22168-22205

summary: The hoard was discovered on two separate occasions and it is suggested that it is part of a much bigger deposit. A further 3 coins were found during the laying of a gas pipe for Gaz de France in the same field: Gordian III - Postumus (AD 260-269); silver weight: 5.6-20.3g.

The hoard comprised 15 denarii and radiates from Nerva to Valerian and Gallienus with a tpq of AD 257 to 258. The exact findspot of the hoard is not known, beyond the fact that it was found on the site of Colonia Ulpia Traiana. This ensemble could have been part of a larger hoard. The date of the find is described as several decades before 2010, when the hoard was published by Reuter.
7 aurei: Carinus - Maximian (AD 286-294) and jewelry, bracelets and rings.
disposition: Numismatic Department of the Hungarian National Museum (Inv.no. 62.1946), Budapest, Hungary

summary: The total number of coins found is estimated at approximately 5,000, of which only a small proportion were identified as issues of a particular emperor. The emperors represented were: Gallienus, Claudius II, Severina, Quintillus and Aurelian. The coins were of base silver and were therefore sold.

The hoard comprised a grey ware vessel containing 9,065 small bronzes, weighing 25kg. The coins included issues of Gallienus, Salonina, Claudius II, Quintillus, Aurelian, Postumus, Victorinus, Tetricus I. Several months later, the same finder discovered a second vessel filled with approximately 4,000 coins. According to Etoc-Demazy, 4/5ths of the first hoard was acquired by the Musée du Mans. In 1981, a lot of 181 coins was sold at the Hotel Drouot which may have been part of the second hoard.
The hoard was found by a worker preparing the ground in a vineyard. Silver: 1,328 antoniniani (radiates): Caracalla - Valerian I and Gallienus (AD 258-260); silver weight: 360.9-3450.5 g.
Unknown originally coin number. 5 antoniniani (radiates) and 87 denarii are known: Septimius Severus - Gordian III (AD 238-244).
Originally 460 coins - denarii and antoniniani (radiates), of which 459 were documented: Titus - Valerian I (AD 253-259).
A hoard of six provincial coins minted in Alexandria (Claudius II - Aurelian), found in or near Ipswich in 1922.

At least 18 radiates (Gallienus to Tetricus I) found in the area of Tintern some time around 1872. It is uncertain that these represent the entirety of what might have been a hoard. No further information is available.
The hoard was found in a burial and comprised 8 coins of Balbinus and other contemporary emperors and a small gold chain with double pendant.
336 antoniniani (radiates) found in Szeskszárd at an uncertain location: Valerian I and Gallienus - Claudius II (AD 268-270)..
Unknown initial number of coins. 6 antoniniani of Trebonianus Gallus are kept in the Regional History Museum Vidin (AD 251-253).
disposition: Regional History Museum Vidin, Bulgaria; inv. no. 11759-11764

summary: c. 400 of antoniniani (radiates): Philip I - Postumus (AD 260-269).
disposition: Town museum, Oudenaarde, Belgium (some coins and the vessel); collection C.A. Serrure, in 1861

summary: (102) 101 silver coins: 24 denarii, 65 antoniniani: Antoninus Pius (Faustina I) - Valerian I (AD 253-259); silver weight: 131.2-264.8 g.

In 1904, numerous coins were discovered in Landrais and catalogued by Arnaud and Bourriau. In October 1913, a 'certain number' (perhaps 300 according to Bourriau) of coins were discovered at the same findspot, along with numerous sherds of black coarseware pottery. The coins were dispersed.
166 antoniniani (radiates): Caracalla - Philip I (AD 247-249); silver weight: 208.9-430.2 g.
disposition: Village museum, Slăveni, Romania, 122 coins; Muzeul Olteniei, Craiova, Romania, 44 coins

summary: 20 denarii, 11 studied: Marcus Aurelius (Faustina II) – Severus Alexander (Julia Mammaea) (AD 222-235).
disposition: Museum of Týniště nad Orlicí, inv.nos. 63–73, today missing.

summary: 7 sestertii: Antoninus Pius - Postumus (AD 260-269); together with 3 bronze rings.
The hoard comprised 12 bronze coins: 10 sestertii, 1 dupondius, 1 as: Commodus - Philip I (244-249 AD).

Five coins from the Trajan Decius reign were discovered by treasure hunters in 2011. The exact location and circumstances of the find are unknown. The coins have traces of fire, therefore, they may have been found in a burial (cremation).
(130) 79 coins: 3 denarii, 4 antoniniani, 71 provincial bronze coins: Elagabalus - Trajan Decius (AD 249-251).

The wooden box contained pieces of silverware and various Roman artefacts. The finder sold the jewellery to the Imperial Library, today the National Library. The coins were dispersed; 1,450 denarii and antoniniani (radiates). The hoard consists of: 8 gold necklaces, pearls or semi-precious stones; 5 gold rings; 6 silver rings; 1 ivory styllus; 1 silver ingot; 1 gold roll of wire; hollow gold fingers (plectrum); a stone statuette of Aesculapius; several rings with intaglio; 2 silver hearts and 1 necklace pendant with a gold coin.
Unknown initial number number of coins. T. Gerasimov mentions 12 silver coins: 3 denarii, 9 antoniniani: Septimius Severus - Trajan Decius (AD 249-251). Found in a ceramic vessel
A hoard of three large gold medallions, 23 aurei, 4 gold bars, 2 gold tintinnabula and several amulets of gold and lapis lazuli, probably deposited in the reign of Gordian III or Philip the Arab.
disposition: BNF, Paris (Alexander Medaillions); G. de Demetrio (Gold Objects)

summary: 2 antoniniani (radiates) of Trajan Decius (AD 249-251).
Circa 100 provincial bronze coins minted in Nicopolis ad Istrum, Marcianopolis, Odessus, Tomis, Dionysopolis: Elagabalus - Philip I (AD 244-249).

The hoard comprised a metal vessel containing 43 Roman coins, including 4 bronzes and 39 denarii and radiates from Trajan to Valerian I and Gallienus/Gallienus (sole)(Gallienus) (AD 253-268). The hoard, missing 10 coins, is in the collections of the Musée de Rouen. The silver mirror and vessel are lost. In the Hoard file in the Archives of the Musée des Antiquités is a handwritten note without a date (April 1912) listing 38 coins.
1,168 silver coins - antoniniani (radiates) and denarii found while metal detecting. Probably, ending with coins of Philip I (AD 244-249).

In 1852 a hoard of antoniniani from the middle of the third century was discovered in the neighbourhood of Klugham. 31 specimens from the hoard fell into the possession of the Historischer Verein von Obb. 33 coins are listed in FMRD, including 2 denarii (Caracalla - Valerian).
9 sestertii found within the south-west district: Antoninus Pius - Philip I (AD 247).
12 provincial coins ranging from Commodus to Philip (Dium, Thessalonica, Koinon of Macedononia) found in grave 8 in Methone.
128 provincial bronze coins: Antoninus Pius - Severus Alexander (AD 222-235).
disposition: Archaeological Museum, Veliko Tarnovo, Bulgaria; inv.nos. 1022-1141

summary: 200-300 denarii of the 2nd-3rd centuries AD found in unknown circumstances. No further information.

The hoard comprised 500-600 provincial bronze coins of Byblus, Berytus, and Sidon, found while digging for construction stones, found in a 'cavity' (Höhlung) close to Beirut. Coins range from Macrinus to Severus Alexander, most of which minted in Berytus and Sidon.
70 coins found with a leather bag: 22 denarii, 47 antoniniani, 1 provincial bronze: Commodus - Philip I (AD 244-249).
disposition: Museum of Archaeology, Radnevo, Bulgaria; inv. nos. 28-97

summary: 370 coins: 12 denarii, 358 provincial bronzes: Marcus Aurelius - Severus Alexander (AD 222-235).
The hoard comprised more than 1,500 Roman coins. The Museé de Boulogne bought 100 coins ranging from Septimius Severus to Gallienus.
9042 silver coins: denarii, antoniniani (radiates): Caracalla - Valerian I (AD: 257-259); silver weight: 11297.5 g. Approx. 300 unidentified badly preserved coins.
Unknown number of provincial bronze coins found in a ceramic vessel. 22 coins entered museum collection in Plovdiv: Septimius Severus - Philip I (AD 244-249).
disposition: Museum of Archaeology, Plovdiv, Bulgaria; inv.no. 2168

summary: 6 coins: 4 bronze republican (!), 1 denarius Nero, 1 antoninianus (radiate) Aurelian (AD 270-275).
42 provincial bronze coins found in a ceramic vessel. 12 have been examined: Caracalla - Philip I (AD 244-249).

Found in a gravel pit while digging for gravel, along with potsherds. Located in the area of a Roman villa rustica. Of approximately 1,500 coins, ca. 1,270 are preserved in the Liestal Museum and 756 are issues of the Gallic Empire (Postumus, Victorinus, Tetrici). The coins seem to have been arranged in rolls inside the vessel.
370 Roman provincial bronze coins of the 3rd century AD. No further infiormation.
56 antoniniani (radiates): Gallienus (sole) - Probus (AD 276-282).
During the drainage of a moor several small Roman coins were unearthed. The names of six emperors are mentioned. Some coins seem to be plated.
98 billon tetradrachms of Alexandria found with a ceramic vessel: Probus - Diocletian/Maximian I (AD 291-292). Briefly examined by Martin Price.

353 coins, among 1 aureus of Septimius Severus, found with two bronze vessels: Marcus Aurelius - Valerian I and Gallienus (Valerian I) (AD 253-260). Together were found two gold rings and a silver necklace.
38 coins: 9 antoniniani and 29 provincial bronzes found within the ruins of an ancient building: Macrinus - Claudius II (AD 268-270).
disposition: Regional History museum, Dobrich, Bulgaria; inv.no. I 2761

summary: 115 antoniniani (radiates) ranging from Gordian III to Valerian I and Gallienus.(AD 257-258). Part of a larger hoard.

A hoard of ca. 3220 Roman silver coins (denarii and antoniniani), ranging from Antoninus Pius to Postumus, found in a vessel during works at the Erthalstraße in 1886. Some of the hoard was dispersed. 1872 coins are listed in FMRD.

Chappée and the Vicomte d'Elbenne bought two lots of coins (approximately 2,000) which were sold as part of a hoard weighing 20kg. They were found in a ceramic urn in a field next to the station in Sillé-le-Guillaume or in Rouessé-Vassé or in Mayenne (Voutré or Sainte-Suzanne). The Musée du Mans has preserved a manuscript note related to a lot of 583 coins weighing 1,453g and quantifying these coins by emperor: Valerian I and Gallienus/Gallienus (sole) - Tetricus I (AD 271-274).
The only data published on this hoard indicates that it comprised 800 antoniniani (radiates) dating from the reigns of Gordian III to Gallienus (AD 260-268).

The hoard comprised a greyware vessel containing 275 sestertii and dupondii or asses, arranged in piles from Domitian to Gordian III. Two thirds of the hoard were unidentifable because of a thick layer of corrosion products. The hoard was found in a wood on the Tesnières wood in the roots of an oak tree. Fragments of the ceramic vessel and part of the hoard were acquired by the Musée du Mans
1058 billon provincial coins of Alexandria: Claudius II - Probus (AD 276-282).
113 antoniniani (radiates) - 68 imitations: second half 3rd c., burial: 274 (during or after Tetrici's age)
disposition: Museo Arch. Reg. "P. Orsi", Siracusa, Italy (inv.nos: 80699, 80700, 80701-80703)

summary: 60 large bronze coins (i.e. sestertii) were found in a bowl in Trier, in the suburb St. Barbara inside Roman stonework.

The hoard comprised 1,942 antoniniani (radiates). Three coins (Valerian I, Gallienus, Postumus) were given to the perish care taker, four coins (Gallienus) to the collector who helped the finder, of which 1935 were studied by Bastien and Huvelin. Silver: 1869, 66 coins; Silver weight: 505.6-2335.3g.

The hoard was found in a cave shelter and comprised numerous ancient objects including pottery vessels, hipposandals and a sestertius of Hadrian, a dupondius of Antoninus Pius and a worn coin of another emperor, possibly Macrinus.
(c. 18 kg, 4,062) 1,590 silver coins denarii, antoniniani: Septimius Severus - Trebonianus Gallus (AD 251-253); silver weight: 5078.8-10559.8 g.
The hoard was found in a Roman theatre and comprised 1,065 coins. 12 imitations of antoniniani (radiates) of Tetricus I. 1,053 blanks and 6 rejected blanks.
248 silver coins, denarii and antoniniani: Vespasian - Trajan Decius (AD 249-251).
disposition: History Museum, Razgrad, Bulgaria; inv.no. IF, hoard 14

summary: (+500) provincial bronze coins. 37 pieces entered the museum collection in Targovishte: Septimius Severus - Gordian III (AD 238-244).
21 coins found hidden behind in a wall whole in a Roman villa: 1 antoninianus (radiate), 18 sestertii, 2 asses: Domitian - Philip I (AD 244-249).

The hoard was found in a ceramic vessel and comprised 3,258 antoniniani (radiates): Gordian III - Victorinus (AD 269-271). The coins of Postumus (and some imitations) made up a quarter of all the coins studied. The hoard was found during ground levelling works close to the walls of a farm; silver weight: 880.6-5928.0 g.
A small ceramic vessel with 6 silver coins: 2 denarii, 4 antoniniani: Septimius Severus - Trajan Decius (AD 249-251).
disposition: Museum of Archaeology, Plovdiv, Bulgaria; inv. no. 2601

summary: A small deposit of 10 coins: 9 sestertii, 1 antoninanus (radiate): Vespasian - Carus/Carinus for Magnia Urbica (283-285). The last coin, possible, intruder.

(+485) 472 silver coins: 106 denarii, 366 Septimius Severus - Gallienus with a tpq of AD 257/258. The coins were minted at Antioch (5 coins), Milan, Rome and Viminacium but data concerning the number of coins from each mint was not recorded. Hobbs estimates a silver weight of 598g to 1241.7g. The coins were accompanied by eight pieces of jewellery: a tubulus, part of a chain; a conical tubulus, part of a chain; the fragment of a bracelet; a fragment of a bracelet; three parts of the coil of a bracelet; a piece of semi-circular sheet-metal, part of a chain.

Hoard found during railway construction work, probably from the area of the site of a Roman villa rustica. It comprisesd at least 2114 coins, but no more than 2300. Coins run from Valerian to Aurelian, mainly Gallienus and Claudius II. Reported coins of Tacitus, Probus and Diocletianus (dated 289) seem to be intruders from the Reichenstein hoard (Schaub-Gysin 1930, p. 70).
A small barbarous radiate hoard in the British Museum with the provenance "Beccles, Lowestoft, 1872". No further information.
The hoard comprised 335 antoniniani (radiates) dating between the reigns of Valerian and Claudius II.
disposition: Dispersed in trade. Recorded at the British Museum.

summary: Unknown original number of coins. Only one of 25+ coins has been recorded and is known. All the coins are likely to have been denarii or antoniniani (radiates).
The hoard comprised between 400 and 500 radiates: Valerian I and Gallienus/Gallienus (sole) for Gallienus - Tetricus I (AD 271-274).
The hoard comprised approximately 1,000 denarii and antoniniani (radiates) from Septimius Severus to Philip I.
A hoard containing, thus far, 121 denarii. The first coins were found in the 1950's, and the rest through excavation and metal detectoring until 2017.
488 silver coins: 227 denarii, 1 plated denarius, 260 antoniniani: Commodus - Philip I (AD 244-247).
disposition: Muzeul de Istorie Națională și Arheologie, Constanța, Romania

summary: The hoard comprised a broken ceramic vessel containing approximately 400 Roman sestertii from Nerva or Trajan to Postumus. 77 coins were examined.

The hoard comprised an earthenware vessel containing between 600 and 700 radiates of Gordian III to Postumus. The hoard was immediately dispersed, although subsequently two lots of coins were recovered for study.
A hoard of 428 denarii dating from Antoninus Pius to Maximinus Thrax (235/236) and one Caesarean drachm of Septimius Severus found at Sulakyurt.
disposition: Museum of Anatolian Civilisations, Ankara, Turkez

summary: Forger's hoard of 121 coinsand blanks (only two coins). The finder also found a fragment of copper alloy rod, a sherd of courseware pottery and a brooch. It is possible, but by no means certain that the hoard was secreted in a pot, but the surviving rim comes from a vessel much larger than was needed to contain the coins and other objects.

(c. 180) 31 antoniniani (radiates). Although are mention imperial portraits from Pupienus to Gallienus and Salonina the only more accurate Information on 31 coins is for issuers from Gordian III to Valerian I. The tpq hypothetically can be placed on AD 268; silver weight: 225.0 g.
disposition: Musée Château d'Annec, France (partially); Inv.no. 5352; registre d'entrées, I, p. 184, no. 5352

summary: Unknown initial number of silver coins. 84 coins recovered: Antoninus Pius -Aurelian (AD 270-275); silver weight: 25.0-216.1 g.
A hoard of 387 antoniniani of Probus found during the excavations of the Roman fort of Vemania.

The hoard comprised two copper-alloy urns containing 515 Roman coins (denarii, antoniniani (radiates) and bronzes). The majority of the coins were well preserved. The division of the coins between the two urns was not recorded. The hoard was found while extracting limestone. Vespasian - Tacitus (AD 275-276).
The hoard comprised 8 dupondii from Titus to Gordian III.
539 antoniniani (radiates), ranging from the sole reign of Gallienus to Aurelianus, incl. Vabalathus. Hoard hidden in the debris of an earthquake dating from AD 241, covering the stadium building.
68 antoniniani (radiates): Gordian III - Victorinus (AD 269-271).
This hoard is recorded at the level of the coin: Gordian III - Victorinus (AD 269-271); silver weight: 243.1-1909.4g.

The hoard was found in a ceramic urn which had been placed in a rectangular cavity under a large flat stone. Within the urn, were 100 small gold Roman coins and 200 in silver and bronze, as well as some bones. The hoard was found by a farmer when he lifted a large flat stone in a field which was bothering him. The farmer sold the coins to a collector with the exception of one coin each in gold, silver and bronze.
Unknown originally number of coins found with a ceramic vessel. 156 silver coins: 147 denarii, 9 antoniniani (radiates): Marcus Aurelius - Philip I (AD 247); silver weight: 198.8-366.5 g.

The hoard comprised a red ceramic vessel containing between 1,000 and 1,200 antoniniani (radiates) and one denarius. Pilloy saw approximately 300 of these coins and commented that 5/6ths were of Gallienus (particularly his zoo issue) and of Claudius II or Divus Claudius II. The remainder were of Salonina, Quintillus, Victorinus, Aurelian, Severina and Numerian, with the last three authorities represented by one coin each.
1,204 coins: 4 antoniniani (radiates), 1,199 sestertii, 1 as: Vespasian - Postumus (AD 268).
disposition: Cabinet des Médailles de la Bibliothèque nationale de France, Paris

summary: 108 bronze coins of Postumus: double sestertii, sestertii, imitations (AD 267-269).

in 1917, the museum received a small bronze container without lid that was said to have contained 18 coins (antoniniani, Gallienus to Tetricus), and probably found in Mainz-Kastel. The coins are lost.

The hoard comprised a Samian ware vessel filled with radiates. Although they were immediately dispersed amongst the group of workmen who found them, M. Le Pesant was able to examine 176 of the coins: Caracalla - Trajan Decius (AD 249-251). Sixty of the coins and a fragment of the base of the vessel were acquired by the Musée d'Évreux. Silver weight: 215.2-408.4 g.

A series bronze coins (Vespasian - Maximinus Thrax), found by farm workers close to Landwehr; a further three coins are reported to have been found close to Landwehr or at the Nordostseekanal. Not belonging to the find is a cast provincial coins of Samos (Trajan Decius).
81 provincial bronze coins discovered in a ceramic vessel: Septimius Severus - Philip I (AD 244-249).
disposition: National History Museum, Sofia, Bulgaria; inv. no. 17 096-17 176

summary: The hoard comprised between 800 and 1000 antoniniani/radiates including coins of Valerian I, Gallienus, Salonina, Claudius II and Quintillus (AD 270). The exact size of the hoard is not known as the hoard was not preserved as a whole. Found together with a ceramic vessel.

Around circa 1,000 silver coins, denarii and antoniniani (radiates) from Gallienus to Claudius II (AD 268-270) and some Gallic usurpers. Coins were split between the finder, the field owner, and the local museum.

The hoard comprised an unknown number of Roman coins, which was divided in two by the finder. One part was melted down and used to make buttons, chains and a watch. The other part included 3 sestertii and 5 radiates from Trajan to Trajan Decius. It is possible that this hoard is part of one known as Lusigny A.

The hoard comprised 40 sestertii and dupondii or asses from Trajan to Gordian III. They were accompanied by a small copper-alloy figurine. The hoard was found by a worker in a vineyard in a semi-circular niche hollowed out of the rock.
The hoard comprised 12 coins from Volusian to Salonina, found together in a single mass.
Unknown initial number of coins. 40 silver coins: denarii, antoniniani: Caracalla - Trajan Decius (AD 249-251); silver weight: 51.2-99.8 g.
disposition: Regional History Meseum, Pleven, Bulgaria; inv.nos. 1410-1414

summary: Circa 500 antoniniani. Only 11 pieces were described in the first publication.
(316) 214 silver coins: 23 denarii, 191 antoniniani (radiates): Gordian III - Postumus (AD 261); silver weight: 112.2-779.3 g.
2,944 tetradrachms of Alexandria: Aurelian - Diocletian-Maximian I (AD 295-296) found in an amphora beneath the floor during excavations of a house.
(55) 17 silver coins: 9 denarii, 8 antoniniani: Septimius Severus - Trajan Decius (AD 249-251); silver weight: 21.6-34.1 g.
317 silver coins: 2 denarii, 315 antoniniani (radiates): Septimius Severus - Gallienus (AD 260-268).
The hoard was found in a small wooden box and comprised between 5 and 600 antoniniani (radiates) from Gordian III to Valerian I and Gallienus (AD 253-260).

A large hoard of c. 22,500 gold and silver coins, ranging from Claudius to Maximinus I, found in 1909 during excavation works for the construction of a house on Gertrudenstraße, approx. midway between Wolfstraße and Neumarkt. Of the c. 22,500 coins found, 4513 are identifiable to RIC number. Only part of these coins are preserved today.
161 coins: 19 denarii and antoniniani, 142 provincial bronzes: Septimius Severus - Gordian III (AD 238-244).
disposition: Regional History Museum, Shumen, Bulgaria; inv. no. 4428-4588

summary: Large number of silver coins. Only 14 pieces were identified: Vespasian - Philip I (AD 244-249).

A. Marsden writes:Group of 14 copper alloy radiates of Carausius (7) and Allectus (7). Condition is generally poor (due to corrosion not wear) but the coins were retrieved from a small area and clearly form part of a dispersed hoardAs mentioned, most of the coins are corroded but it can be seen that their condition when they went into the ground was evidently very good. Given this lack of wear it is very tempting to connect the deposition of this coin hoard (assuming we are not dealing with an accidental purse loss) with the reconquest of Britain by Constantius Chlorus in 296. Certainly, given the demonetisation of these radiates in 296, the hoard cannot date to very much later.
The hoard was enclosed or set within a square-cut stone and comprised 11 antoniniani (radiates) from Valerian I and Gallienus to Postumus (including E.384 and E.385).
301 antoniniani (radiates): Postumus - Probus (AD 276-282).
(c. 1200) 122 denarii: Nero - Maximinus I Tharax (AD 235-236); silver weight: c. 1,681.7-3,754.3 g.
The hoard comprised 10,320-10,500 silver denarii and tetradrachms, ranging from Vespasian to Elagabalus, found in a bronze jar.
(110) 15 antoniniani (radiates): Gordian III - ValerianI-Gallienus (AD 253-268); silver weight: 137.5-160.6 g.
disposition: Regional History Museum, Vratsa, Bulgaria; inv.nos. M I 161-176 (15 coins)

summary: Three fused coins, one of which was identifiable as a radiate of Probus and therefore a possible hoard, though the other coins could not be identified.
3,428 antoniniani (radiates) found with a copper alloy pitcher: Trebonianus Gallus - Aurelian (AD 270-275); silver weight: 922.5-4265.3 g.
disposition: Museo Civico «Ala Ponzone» di Cremona, Italy

summary: 26 antoniniani found in the house known as the 'House of Domitian's Diploma' with a small ceramic vessel: Severus Alexander - Quintillus (Divus Claudius II) (AD 270).
A possible hoard (or part of a hoard) of 40 sestertii from Trajan to Valerian I (AD 253-254)?
The hoard originally comprised an undetermined amount of denarii: Domitian - Elagabalus (AD 218-222 ). Only 42 coins are now available.
The find of Adlerterrain in 1903 comprised twelve antoniniani and denarii ranging from Maximinus Thrax to Gallienus.

The hoard comprised 'a bucketful of Roman coins, fused together with corrosion products. Cochet estimated that the total number of coins in the hoard was more than 300. The coins were antoniniani (radiates) of the third century depicting 10 emperors until Tacitus and Probus.
disposition: Musées d’Angers, France; Accession Register III, p. 37, no. 42 (3.11.1876)

summary: c. 1200 silver coins: 1 denarius and antoniniani (radiates): Severus Alexander - Postumus (AD 260-269).
1,456 antoniniani (radiates): Gordian III - Aurelian/Tetricus I (AD 271-274); silver weight: 394.1-1819.1g.

Assemblage of 95 Roman coins (1st century BC to 4th century AD) and eight Roman objects submitted as a potential Treasure case (the objects were considered unrelated to the coin hoard). Those coins and objects were found within 50 yd radius on a possible Roman site beside the projected course of Ermine Street with the aid of a metal detector.V. Drost writes; "Among this assemblage are 66 copper alloy sestertii and sestertius fractions which could possibly be part of a hoard. The coins range from Vespasian (AD 69-79) to Gordian III (AD 238-44) and the composition is very similar to that of the Cowbit Hoard (BM ref.: 2003 T76). Most of the coins are dating to the 2nd century AD and are extremely worn as a result of an extended circulation until the deposition of the hoard well into the 3rd century AD. However, some of the coins struck under the Antonine dynasty are in a fairly good condition and it cannot be assured that all of the coins were originally part of the hoard. Eight silver denarii dating to the 1st and 2nd centuries AD could potentially be part of the hoard as well, even if hoards mixing silver coins and copper-alloy coins are not common. Nevertheless, it is difficult to ascertain that each one of those coins belong to the hoard. Note: a gold aureus of Trajan was previously found nearby.On the other hand, the 20 radiates or nummi dating to the 3rd and 4th centuries AD are very unlikely to be part of the hoard and can reasonably be considered as single finds." (Unpublished catalogue).The denarii of Augustus and Vespasian are plated.
Unknown originally number of coins. Only three antoniniani (radiates) are known: Gordian III, Valerian I and Gallienus/Gallienus (Gallienus), Postumus.
15 provincial bronze coins: Septimius Severus - Gordian III (AD 238-244).
disposition: History Museum, Razgrad, Bulgaria; inv.no. IF, hoard 20

summary: 1 denarius and 903 radiates (Maximinus I to Victorinus) found by a metal detectorist at Craig-y-Saeson Farm. Decayed fragments of a possible pewter container were found alongside the coins. No more precise depositional or contextual information is available. Eight coins are counterfeit. Seven are of Postumus, whose coinage in now recognised to have been promptly imitated. The other, of Philip I, is a competent creation of good weight, but stands out on account of its style
disposition: National Museum Cardiff (103); Newport Museum (40); private collections (761)

summary: The hoard comprised a ceramic vessel containing approximately 250 Roman coins of Gallienus, Saloninus, Postumus, Marius, Victorinus, Tetricus, Claudius II, Quintillus and Aurelian.

The hoard was found inside a vessel, apparently made of iron. The total number of coins found seems to be 90, although some reports detail at least 107. The coins were all bronze issues measuring between 25 and 35mm in diameter: Trajan - Gordian III (AD 238-244).
disposition: Monedas conservadas en el Museo Arqueologico, Etnografico e Historico, Vasco, Spain (5 coins)

summary: 52 silver coins: 51 denarii, 1 antoninianus (radiate) found with a ceramic jug: Trajan - Severus Alexander (AD 222-235); silver weight: 75.9-163.6g.
A suspicious hoard as there is no evidence for the conditions of discovery, except one note in a local newspaper: Vitellius - Septimius Severus (Plautilla (AD 202-205).
The hoard comprised 3 denarii and 610 radiates from Caracalla to Postumus with a tpq of AD 268. Hobbs estimates a silver weight of between 1756.6 and 16896.9 g.
The hoard comprised 2,445 silver coins (denarii and antoniniani-radiates) from Septimius Severus to Valerian I (AD 257) found in a lead container.

33 Alexandrian tetradrachms and a fragment of a bronze-ring. Found in a wooden jar in the courtyard just in front of a door during excavations of a house. Ranking: Aurelian - Diocletian-Maximian I (AD 292-293).

The hoard was discovered in 1933 by a farmer 100 m north of Rembrechts. 88 coins (mostly denarii, with some bronze coins, ranging from the Late Republic to Severus Alexander) were associated with jewellery. Most of the objects found with the coins were of silver.
19 coins of different bronze denominations scattered on an area of 20 sqcm: Claudius I - Gordian III (AD 241-243).
Two hoards not entirely recovered. One contained 7 coins: Salonina, Tacitus, Probus (5).

Three Roman hoards found in Stonea. This hoard comprises 37 denarii ranging up to Gordian III and was found with Iron Age coins seen as a separate group (Stonea Grange I group I). Part of the group was detected from site prior to excavation.
Around 2,500 silver coins found with a ceramic vessel. 1,800 coins were recovered: Vespasian - Gordian III (AD 238-244); silver weight: 859.1-1804.1g.
168 denarii and Antoniniani (radiates) from Septimius Severus to Gallienus (sole) (AD 260-268).

The hoard comprised a greyware vessel containing 600 sestertii from Trajan to Marcus Aurelius. A further sestertius of Marcus Aurelius was overstruck with a double sestertius of Postumus. The coins were arranged in textile bags. Fragments of the bags survived where coins touched the walls of the vessel.
Hoard found in a ceramic vessel consisting of 80 denarii. One denarius of Severus Alexander is known.

The hoard was found in a black ceramic vessel placed within a pit lined with four tiles. It comprised approximately 4,000 antoniniani (radiates) from Gordian III to Tetricus I and II. Issues of Gallienus and Claudius II were the most numerous. A small portion of the hoard including 103 coins were catalogued.
16 bronze coins found in a destruction layer scattered on a very small area: Claudius I - Gordian III (AD 241-244).

The hoard was found at a very shallow depth placed under or on a flat, square stone. It comprised a vessel containing 3,369 coins. J. Chappée bought the hoard and compiled a catalogue of 3,075 antoniniani (radiates) and imitations. M. Amandry undertook a new study of the hoard in 1983 and compiled a catalogue of 3,052 coins. It is this catalogue which is recorded in our database. Silver weight: 784.8-3627.8g.

The hoard was found in the ruins of a small round temple and comprised a tripod cauldron containing 251 Roman sestertii from Domitian to Gordian III. Coins of Hadrian, Marcus Aurelius and Commodus were the most numerous.

1,300 antoniniani (radiates). "Due to the poor state of preservation of the radiates hidden in Varzi, which were completely covered by corrosive elements… The first group of 95 radiates were restored between 2020 and 2021 […] The issuing authorities are Gallienus (3%), Claudius II (64%), Quintillus (8%) and Aurelianus (3%). The remaining part (22%) consists of unidentifiable specimens. Only 43 radiates can be attributed (for now) to a specific mint: the majority to the Siscia one (86%), followed by Rome (11%) and Mediolanum (3%)."
disposition: Soprintendenza Archeologia Belle Arti e Paesaggio, Pavia, Italy

summary: 116 silver coins: 4 denarii, 112 antoniniani: Caracalla-Diocletian (AD 292).

The hoard was found in a cave and comprised 60 Roman coin copies as well as numerous fragments of copper-alloy bar with Roman coin flans stamped on them. The hoard was interpreted as belonging to a forger.
1499 tetradrachms of Alexandria: Aurelian - Diocletian-Maximian I (AD 295-296) in an amphora beneath the floor during excavations of a house.
The hoard comprised a vessel containing 700 'pewter coins imitating denarii of Septimius Severus, Julia Domna, Caracalla and Geta'.

A hoard of 180+ AE provincial coins of Thrace (1), Macedonia (2) and Asia Minor (177, mostly Pamphylia (64), Pisidia (50) and Western Cilicia (10)), dating from the first century AD to the reign of Aurelian.

The hoard was found in a ceramic vessel covered with a copper-alloy plate and comprised approximately 10,000 radiates of Tetricus I, Victorinus, Gallienus, Claudius II, Aurelian, Tacitus and Probus. Only 18 coins were preserved.
27 sestertii found together in a room from a Roman building considered to shave served as a warehouse.
201 sestertii from Domitian to Valerian I and Gallienus (AD 254-255).
103 coins, range: Valerian I and Gallienus to Probus. No further details.
1,545 coins: 1 denarius, 1544 antoniniani (radiates): Trajan - Tetricus I (AD 271-273).
7 antoniniani (4 copies) Tetricus I (AD 271-274).
disposition: Archaeological Museum, Namur, Belgium (11 coins); collection Vandermaelen (2 coins and the shards from vessel), in 1851

summary: 269 bronze coins found in a ceramic vessel during metal detecting: 252 sestertii, 4 dupondii, 13 asses: Domitian - Postumus (AD 260-261).
15 coins: 3 heavily worn out denarii, 12 provincial bronze coins found in a sacred area (sanctuary) in a small dish: Marcus Aurelius - Philip I (AD 244-249).
1170 silver coins: M. Aurelius - Philip I; Silver weight: 1463.8-3029.0 g.
Four kilos of silver coins - 2,457 denarii and 2 drachms ranging from Mark Antony to Septimius Severus (AD .
32 silver coins discovered in a small ceramic vessel: 7 antoniniani, 25 denarii: Commodus - Philip I (AD 244-249).
disposition: Museum of Archaeology, Plovdiv, Bulgaria; inv.no. 2574

summary: Unknown orignal number of coins. 72 antoniniani (radiates) were available for study. The hoard was found in two large ceramic vessels.
88 silver coins: 7 denarii, 81 antoniniani (radiates): Septimius Severus - Postumus (AD 263); silver weight: 45.7-319.1 g.
disposition: Musées royaux des Beaux-Arts de Belgique (88 coins)

summary: The hoard comprised 50 antoniniani (radiates) from Victorinus, Tetricus I and Tetricus II.
ca. 1500 to 2000 coins, but only 528 are identified: Valerian I - Tetricus I (AD 271-274).
The hoard comprised 21 denarii from Vitellius to Septimius Severus with a tpq of AD 201 to 206. Hobbs estimates a silver weight of 39.6-60.8 g.

The hoard comprised a copper-alloy vessel filled with 15 Roman silver coins and 600 small bronzes of the same module (radiates). The reverse of one coin is given as MARTI PACIFERO, A/-. It appears to be an issue of Gallienus (RIC V/1 236?)

The hoard comprised an enormous pot containing a very large quantity of Gallo-Roman coins. Although some of the coins were stolen soon after their discovery, the number of coins found totaled more than 2,000. Only 85 of these were described. After its discovery, the pot was left in the middle of the field overnight and some coins from the hoard went missing then: Valerian I - Tetricus I (AD 271-274); silver weight: 541.0-2499.1g.

The assemblage comprised a) a copper-alloy box containing 2 aurei, items of jewellery and a fragment of silk; b) a further earthenware vessel containing a large quantity (10 kilos in total) of small module coins (radiates). 250 of these coins were examined by F. Rever, with the most recent being an issue of Quietus; c) 50 'large bronze' coins were scattered on the surface; d) some iron tools including pruning equipment. It is not clear whether all the constituent parts of the find should be considered to represent a single hoard deposit or at least two separate hoards. Found in a field belonging to M. Denesle (or Denêle) in the course of digging.
236 coins: 6 denarii, 224 antoniniani (radiates), 6 sestertii: Trajan - Valerian I and Gallienus (AD 259-260). Found together with jewellery: 1 gold ring, 1 glass ring, 1 bronze brooch.

56 bronzes of Postumus. Only 26 were considered worth preserving. The coins were acquired by the musée de Douai under inventory no. 6271. The dating in AD 270-271 is based on the abbreviation PIAV (vonius), nomen of Victorinus, on one of the coins.
(+100) 122 silver coins: Septimius Severus - Trajan Decius (AD 250-251); silver weight: 34.5-314.1g.
Bronze pitcher with 957 coins: 952 antoniniani (radiates), 1 double antoninianus, 4 denarii: Severus Alexander - Carinus (AD 283-285).
758 coins from Augustus to Gallienus (sole) (AD 260-268).
disposition: Medagliere del Museo Nazionale Romano, Roma, Italy

summary: The hoard was found 50 metres from a Gallo-Roman villa during excavation and comprised 40 coins including sestertii, denarii and radiates from Hadrian to Philip I.
The coins (44 denarii, Vespasian - Severus Alexander) were discovered during excavation in room D of building I of a mansio close to Sigmaringen.

7,000 coins were found in a pot, consisting of only three types (2 of Tetricus, 1 of Claudius II Gothicus). At the time, they believed that they were set aside to serve as Charon's obol for fallen soldiers.
Before 1889, 8 coins were found in a garden in Campbon. These included one radiate of Tacitus and 2 of Probus. They may represent a portion of a larger hoard.
47 silver coins: 4 denarii, 4 antoniniani: Caracalla-Trajan Decius (AD 249-251); silver weight: 70.4-108.5 g.

An aureus of Trebonianus Gallus and a gold barbarous imitation of a Roman coin were bought in 1855 by the Coin Cabinet of the Museum in Berlin from a local from Jelenia Góra. No certainity whether the coins were actually found in this town.
disposition: Sammlung des Münzkabinetts in Berlin (17551-[1] coin und 17552-[2] Barbarous imitation. Unknown nowadays location.

summary: A hoard of 25 aurei (Faustina I - Trajan Decius), one medallion of Gallienus and 16 articles of jewellery, found at Octavian Augustus Street in the ancient Jewish quarter in Alexandria.
7 silver coins: 6 denarii, 1 antoninianus (radiate): Republic - Valerianus/Gallienus (Salonina) (AD 253-268); silver weight: 11.8-22.8 g.
disposition: Musée Archéologique de Namur, Belgium (7 coins)

summary: 3,598 antoniniani (radiates) of which 3,032 are imitations: Valerian I and Gallienus - Probus (AD 276-282).

The hoard comprised a large quantity of coins, although only 11 were identified. They included issues of Gordian III, Gallienus and Salonina. It seems likely that this is the same hoard as one mentioned by M. Faujas de Saint-Fond in 1810 which comprised 'a very large number of medium and small bronze Roman coins from Gallienus to the House of Constantine'.
Around 100 bronze coins of 'large and medium size' from Trajan to Postumus (?) (AD 260-268).
29 antoniniani (radiates): Gordian III - Tetricus I (AD 271-274).
272 antoniniani (radiates) ranging from Caracalla to Trajan Decius (AD 249-251). 6 coins have been lost.
146 coins: 1 denarius, 91 antoniniani (radiates), 49 antoniniani (radiates) imitations, 3 sestertii, 2 dupondii/asses: Marcus Aurelius - Tetricus I (AD 271-274).
762 tetradrachms of Alexandria: Aurelian - Diocletian-Maximian I (AD 295-296) found in a jar in underground room H during excavations of a house.
The hoard comprised approximately 150 antoniniani (radiates). Only 12 were identified, all being of Valerian I.
A hoard of 13 provincial coins of Athens (period VI), excavated in 1934 near a late wall, north of the Tholos. Their burial has been ascribed to the sack of Athens by the Herulians.
Bizeul described 5 antoniniani (radiates) found in Quénet which may be part of a larger hoard or perhaps the contents of a purse.

A group of 13 antoniniani (Gallienus - Tetricus), found in Wehde, which is the location of a Saxon urn burial ground (2nd - 5th c. AD). It is uncertain whether the coins lay together in an urn or whether they were spread out in different urns. In 1886 the coins were purchased by LM Han. from a private owner. Addressed as Hoard?/Gave find? in FMRD.
Unknown number of antoniniani. 27 coins entered museum collection in Haskovo: Gordian - Trajan Decius (AD 249-251).
disposition: History Museum, Haskovo, Bulgaria; inv.nos. N 656, N 1039

summary: About 100 antoniniani up to the 3rd century AD.
The hoard was found in two vessels by workers. For the city master, it comprised c. 8,000 antoniniani (radiates). Among these coins, 796 from Valerian to Diocletian were identified.
NMR record of 6 coins of Probus found in a field at Seaham and given to the Newcastle Society of Antiquaries. No further details.

The hoard was found during the excavation of 21 'puits funéraire' at Troussepoil and comprised 231 brass coins (sestertii?). Close to the hoard, 3 broken black ceramic jugs were excavated, two of which were filled with ashes and funeral pyre debris. Baudry thought that the coins had originally been placed in the jugs, but that hypothesis is not certain. The hoard was discovered during the excavation of 21 'puits funéraire' of Troussepoil.
The hoard comprised 84 tetradrachms dated between AD 211-217/8.
727 denarii and antoniniani found in a ceramic vessel: Nero - Gordian III (AD 238-244).
disposition: Regional History Museum, Shumen, Bulgaria; inv. no.8442-9165

summary: HER record of an unrecorded late third-century hoard found by a metal-detectorist along with pottery sherds, a bracelet and a finger ring "with opposed dolphins".

The hoard was found in a copper-alloy vessel covered with a silver plate and comprised 73 denarii and antoniniani (radiates) vfrom Vespasian to Valerian I. Hobbs estimates a silver weight of between 55.4g and 208.8g.
The hoard was found mixed in with earth, without an obvious container. The excavators suggested an organic bag.

Hoard of 14 kilos of antoniniani (radiates) found during the construction of the overpass on the Corso Ivrea. 601 coins were transferred from the Regional Museum of Torino to the Soprintendenza della Valle d'Aosta: Trebonianus Gallus - Valerian I and Gallienus/Gallienus (AD 253-268).
The hoard comprised 4 coins of Severus Alexander (AD 222-235) and 2 unidentified coins.

583 antoniniani (radiates). The precise location is unknown. Based on the high frequency of coins minted in Antioch has been considered a site near this city. Coins: Elagabalus - Aurelian (AD 270-275).
4957 radiates to Probus (AD 279), found in a jar, 10 miles south of Oxford. The hoard contained a second specimen of a coin of Domitianus (Domitian II), a Gallic usurper under Aurelian.

The hoard was found in a large iron pot and comprised approximately 29 kilos (close to 120 marcs) of Roman silver coins. The coins were denarii and antoniniani (radiates) from the reign of Septimius Severus to Gallienus and Postumus. Cochet suggested purely hypothetically that this hoard was found in Saint-André-Sur-Cailly.
The hoard comprised 120 sestertii from Vespasian to Philip I (AD 244-249).

Depression F2409. Contained 12 re-deposited (curated?) Palaeolithic flint handaxes in gravel at bottom of feature, also 3 3rd C. coins. Then an octagonal stone font inserted. After font fell out of use, depression filled with series of black upper fills, poss. derived from midden material, containing large quantities of animal bone, oyster shell & pottery; but also objects incl. a silver pin, a copper alloy enamelled fitting, decorative strips & frags. of finger & ear rings & bracelets (some chopped up), pins, copper beads, door fittings, and an iron latch lifter, hand saw, auger & trowel, an iron wool carding comb, a stone cult figure, & 32 4th C. coins

1918 antoniniani (radiates) found with a ceramic vessel: Valerian - Victorinus (AD 271); mints: 1006 Rome, 787 Mediolanum, 122 Cologne, 1 Siscia, 1 Viminacium, 1 Antioch: Valerian I and Gallienus - Cludius II/Victorinus (AD 268-271); silver weight: 518.8-2396.6 g.
Approximately 130 silver coins, the majority of which were denarii, of which only a small proportion were identified.
Over 2,000 aurei found with a ceramic vessel: Tiberius - Severus Alexander (AD 222-235); gold weight: c. 12801.4-15598.6g.
The hoard comprised two black ceramic vessels containing approximately 20,000 coins from Gallienus to Carinus (AD 283-285).
NA
30 provincial bronze coins: Septimius Severus - Trajan Decius (AD 249-251).
disposition: National Archaeological Institute with Museum, Sofia, Bulgaria; inv. no. 17

summary: Unknown number of silver coins. 31 pieces were noticed: Septimius Severus - Trajan Decius (AD 249-251).
The hoard comprised close to 20,000 coins of which 490 were seen. These included issues of Saloninus, Gallienus and Postumus.
The hoard was found with several fragments of a red-orange ceramic vessel which presumably was its original container.
Recorded by the Somerset Levels Project. Hoard comprised just 3 radiates, found during peat digging. No archaeological context.
10 silver coins: 9 denarii, 1 antoniniani(radiate) (AD 251-253).

A hoard of 907 coins, found in a broken clay pot during building work carried out with a bulldozer: one Parthian drachm (Orodes I), 771 didrachms and 4 drachms of Caesarea in Cappadocia up to Geta, and 131 Roman denarii up to Alexander Severus, as well as one drachm of Caracalla attributed to Petra and dated to AD 211-12 (listed as a coin of Elagabalus from Caesarea by Dundua 2008).
c. 50 antoniniani (radiates): Postumus (AD 260-269).
(c. 2,898) 1,902 silver coins: Marcus Aurelius - Valerian I/Gallienus (AD 253-268).
disposition: Museum of Vratsa, Bulgaria; inv.nos. M III 6406 - M IV 7503 (1098 coins); M IV 7507-8345 (839); History Museum, Vratsa; inv.nos. 8750-8839

summary: 2611 coins, 2594 recovered: Vespasian - Valerian to Gallienus with some intruders (Divus Claudius II, Constantinopolis). Silver weight: 9,270 kg.
Unknown number of silver coins. 42 pieces entered the museum collection in Kardzhali: Septimius Severus - Philip I (AD 244-249).
disposition: Regional Museum of History, Kardzhali, Bulgaria

summary: A hoard of 39 antoniniani (Gordian III and Philip I) was discovered by a treasure hunter in the middle of November 2017 in Khmelnytskyi region. Information about the hoard and photos of the coins were published on the Ukrainian treasure hunter forum Violity on November 14, 2017. There is no additional information about the conditions of hoard find. The further fate of the coins is unknown.
200 silver coins found with a ceramic vessel. 100 pieces were recovered: 92 denarii, 8 antoniniani (radiates): Vespasian – Philip I (AD 244-247).
disposition: History Museum, Caracal (17 coins); Museum of Oltenia, Craiova (83 coins), Romania

summary: In 1958 a small collective find of 18 antoniniani ranging from Aurelian to Carinus Caesar was unearthed in a ditch during excavations conducted by the commission for archaeological exploration of late antique Raetia.

A small hoard of 9 antoniniani: Gordian III to Trebonianus Gallus (AD 251-253) was discovered by a treasure hunter in early September 2022 possibly near the town of Bar in the Vinnitsa region. Information about the find and photos of the coins were published on the Ukrainian treasure hunter forum Violity September 16, 2022. The conditions of discovery of the hoard are unknown. At the end of September 2022, five of the nine coins were sold at a Violity auction. The further fate of the other coins is unknown.
The hoard was found in a broken ceramic vessel and comprised at least 1183 radiates from Gordian III to Saloninus with a tpq. of AD 260.
The hoard comprised 27 coins from Gallienus to Postumus and Tetricus I and one gold ring. Hobbs estimates a silver weight of between 8.7 and 31.5 g.

The 15 (lost) coins, "mostly poorly preserved middle bronzes from Augustus to Trebonianus Gallus", were found in 1913/14 during earthworks on the edge of a ravine near the Bühren estate. "The coins were scattered over 100 m, 1 m deep."
2 coins: 1 bronze Marcus Aurelius (Faustina II/ Diva Faustina II), 1 antoninianus (radiate) Claudius II (AD 268-270)

The hoard comprised 14 Roman Provincial coins, found in grave 11 in Methone: Dion (1 Elagabalus), Edessa (1 Caracalla, 1 Julia Domna), Thessalonica (1 Geta, 1 Commodus, 2 Elagabalus, 1 Julia Maesa, 1 Philip I), Pella (1 Julia Mamaia, 4 Gordian III).
Few kilograms of silver coins found within the ruins of an ancient settlement. 15 silver coins were seen: Antoninus Pius - Trebonianus Gallus (AD 251-253).
During archaeological excavations, 11 burned bronze coins were found on the south-east corner of the basilica: 1 Rome, 10 provincial: Claudius I - Gordian III (AD 238-244)

407 silver coins found in two glass bottles. One bottle contained 130 coins, the other 277 pieces: 86 denarii, 321 antoniniani (radiates): Domitian - Victorinus (AD 269-271). In one of the bottles were also found a pendant medallion (with a denarius of Antoninus Pius) and a silver finger ring.
disposition: Service Régional de l’Archéologie, Ile-de- Franceté; Centre Michel de Boüard – Centre de recherches archéologiques et historiques anciennes et médiévales, Caen

summary: 15 probably antoniniani (radiates). According to NUMIS they are dated around AD 270. No further information.

The surviving part of a larger hoard includes 16 denari and 6 antoniniani (radiates) from Mark Antony to Philip I (32 BC-247 AD) kept in a private collection. The original amount of the hoard remains unknown. Given the very little distance between the two findspots, Masi I and Masi II should be two sections of the same hoard deposited in different places by its owner.

In 1837 six silver coins and one copper coin were unearthed in an arable field between Dambach and Hammerschmiede, in the vicinity of the Dambach Roman fort. The six silver coins were denarii, ranging from Vespasian to Julia Mamaea. The copper coin was an antoninianus of Carinus, that was probably not part of the hoard and has not been listed here.

A hoard comprising 5 sestertii from Domitian to Macrinus. It has been interpreted as a purse or a small votive deposit. It was found on a hilltop above a cliff during metal detectorist's surveys (2002 and 2004).
1 as, 1 sestertius, 1 denarius and 7555 radiates and a bronze ring to AD 274.

The hoard comprised a vessel containing approximately 150 antoniniani (radiates) from Valerian I to Galerius (Caesar) with a tpq of AD 293 to 294. It was found during the excavation of the Roman amphitheatre.
Eighteen aurei were found in a local earthenware pot. Some of them were pierced.
The hoard comprised a ceramic vessel containing 2,600 antoniniani (radiates) from Caracalla to Postumus with a tpq of AD 263.

A hoard of provincial coins (Samos, Pergamum, Smyrna, Clazomenae, Metropolis and Nysa; Gordian III - Gallienus), seen in commerce in Athens, coming from Samos. 16 coins are listed, but 21+ are mentioned in the heading.
The hoard comprised a vessel containing 550 3rd century ADcoins including issues of Gordian III and Philip I.

Unknown number of silver coins found in a ceramic vessel. 105 pieces entered the museum collection in Plovdiv: 100 denarii, 5 antoniniani: Trajan - Gordian III (AD 243-244); silver weight: 148.6-305.1 g.
disposition: Museum of Archaeology, Plovdiv, Bulgaria; inv. no. 2226, 105 coins

summary: 11 bronze coins: Hadrian - Gordian III (AD 241-244).
32 antoniniani (radiates) belonging to a purse: Gallienus (sole) - Quintillus (AD 270).
disposition: Museum Lauriacum - Museum der Stadt Enns, Austria

summary: 54 antoniniani (radiates) found in a wall with a ceramic vessel: Gallienus (sole) - Aurelian (AD 270-275).

The coins listed here are those reported and declared Treasure at various inquests in the late 1970s and early 1980s. The findspot became public and coins were being regularly found at the site. Their findspot was no longer reported accurately and so the coins should probably be considered together (with caution) as a scattered hoard. It is possible that some of these coins are addenda to hoards 496 and 2634. These two hoards do appear to have been spatially separate, found above and below the Crags respectively, but it has been suggested that a hoard may have been disturbed and spilled over the Crags.
(?) 112 silver coins: 17 denarii, 95 antoniniani (radiates): Septimius Severus - Valerian I (AD 257-258); silver weight: c. 875.6-1818.9 g
disposition: Town Museum Marienmont, Morlanwelz-Marienmont, Belgium (109 coins)

summary: 12,000 denarii and antoniniani (radiates) - 33 Kilos - found with ceramic vessel: Antoninus Pius - Gallienus (sole) (AD 260-268).
1,013 silver coins: 1 plated denarius, 1,012 antoniniani (radiates): Antoninus Pius (Faustina I) - Aurelian (AD 270-275). The table of hoard structure indicate 1,010 coins.
In a bronze vessel, 1,272 antoniniani (radiates): Philip I to Carinus (AD 283-284), also Gallic Empire coins from Postumus to Tetricus I and imitations; silver weight: 230.0-1588.9 g.
140 bronze coins: 130 sestertii, 10 dupondii: Vespasian - Macrinus (AD 217-218).
76 coins: 48 antoniniani (radiates), 28 provincial bronzes: Septimius Severus - Philip I (AD 244-249).
disposition: Museum of History, Stara Zagora, Bulgaria; inv. no. 1938. Stolen

summary: The hoard comprised 105 antoniniani (radiates) and 3 bronze issues and was apparently deposited c. AD 263. No reasons are given for this date for deposition.
21 antoniniani. T. Gerasimov saw 2 of Gordian III
1040 (996) antoniniani (radiates): Trebonianus Gallus - Tetricus I (Ad 271-274); silver weight: 281.8-1299.1g.

The hoard comprised a finger ring with an intaglio depicting Mercury, a worn dupondius, 64 denarii and 75 antoniniani (radiates) from Septimius Severus to Trebonianus Gallus. The objects and coins were enclosed in a leather bag which had been placed in a small recess in the foundations of a third-century building.
Over 20 denarii. No further information.
Unknown number of silver coins found in a ceramic vessel. 102 coins entered the museum collection in Kazanlak: 1 denarius, 101 antoniniani: Septimius Severus - Philip I (AD 244-249).
43 antoniniani: Gordian III - Postumus (AD 260-269); silver weight: 12.6-52.8 g.
A hoard of 751 AE radiates, & 1 AE denarius and pottery to AD 286 in a black burnished ware jar. Unpublished coin report by R. Abdy.
The hoard comprised a coarseware vessel containing 196 bronze coins from Trajan to Valerian and Gallienus and a small silver bracelet.

The hoard comprised a coarseware vessel containing silver and billon coins (denarii and antoniniani (radiates). Although the hoard was immediately dispersed, 183 coins were examined by M. Le Pesant: Antoninus Pius - Postumus (AD 260-269)

7 antoniniani (radiates), all of Postumus from a single collection. The coins could be part of a hoard, or form a hoard in themselves. No information regarding the circumstances of their discovery are known.
50 antoniniani (radiates): Gallienus - Claudius II (Divus) (AD 270).

A possible small hoard of 30 coins given to Alton Museum in 1953. An accompanying label stated that they were dug up "more than a century ago" at Hartley Mauditt. HER record states that they "include 9 of Claudius II, 20 of Gallienus and 1 of Valerian".
Unknown originally number of coins. 138 silver coins: 45 denarii, 93 antoniniani (radiates); silver weight: 181.2-323.9 g.; Septimius Severus -Philip I (AD 246-248).
disposition: National History Museum, Bucharest, Romania (file 1951) (130 coins)

summary: The hoard comprised an amphora containing more than 33 kilos of coins, estimated as representing more than 8,000 examples. Vallier examined 'a suitcase full' of coins which included issues of Gallienus, Claudius II (rare), Aurelian, Severina, Tacitus, Florian, Probus and Numerian. It appears that there were also some earlier coins dating to the first or second centuries AD but the information is vague.
The hoard comprised a wine amphora containing 953 coins, including 937 sestertii, 6 dupondii and 10 asses from Vespasian to Maximinus I Thrax (AD 235-238).
122 antoniniani (radiates)found with a purse and in a wooden casket together with other objects: Caracalla - Valerian I (AD 253-260).

Unnown number of Roman coins found duing the construction clay station. Among them: Antoninus Pius/Marcus Aurelius dupondius, Marcus Aurelius sestertius, Gordian III dupondius, Philip I (Otacilia Severa) sestertius, Gallienus (Salonina) antoninianus (radiate).
1258 silver coins: Vespasian - Trajan Decius (AD 249-251); silver weight: 1623.4-3383.4 g.
Rescue excavation undertaken by the archaeological service. 20 antoniniani and 3 denarii, ranging from Caracalla to Gallienus (sole reign) were found.
(16-20 kg) (8-900) 501 bronze coins: 459 sestertii, 2 dupondii: Vespasian - Maximinus I Thrax (AD 235-238).
disposition: Town museum, Kortrijk, Belgium (240 coins); Collection Heritiers Adriaen (212 coins); Collection Ms. Depoorter (5 coins)

summary: The hoard comprised 300 coins of Claudius II, along with finger rings and intaglios intended for finger rings. Found in a sewer.
disposition: Museu Nacional de Arqueologia, Lisboa, Portugal

summary: 2,266 antoniniani (radiates) found in a bronze vessel: Septimius Severus - Probus (AD 277).
The hoard comprised a ceramic vessel containing 572 worn sestertii of the second century to Gordian III.
Unknown initial number of coins. 3 provincial bronze coins are known: 2 Caracalla, 1 Philip I
It comprised 187 sestertii found with a ceramic vessel: Nerva - Severus Alexander (AD 222-235).

108 kg found in a large ceramic jar and, probably, a box or, rather, of a canvas bag or leather, according to the rectangular shape of the second heap of coins: 41,200 antoniniani (radiates) and 1 denarius. Among issuers Valerian I, Gallienus, Quintillus, Aurelian, Claudius II, Postumus, Laelianus, Marius, Victorinus, Tetricus I, Tetricus II. Notably Gallienus and Claudius II (27%), the Gallo-Roman emperors Victorinus, Tetricus I and Tetricus II in particular (56%), and local imitations. A rare denarius of Tetricus I.
195 Roman imperial bronze coins: 192 sestertii, 3 dupondii/asses: Trajan - Gallienus (AD 260-268).
Around 25 kg = 7,656 antoniniani (radiates): Elagabalus - Aurelian (AD 270-275).
(?) 39 antoniniani: Claudius II -Diocletian (AD 293-294); silver weight: 7.1-12.5 g.
216 silver coins found with a ceramic vessel: 215 denarii, 1 antoninianus: Commodus - Gordian III (AD 242-244); silver weight: 303.1-491.4 g.

The hoard comprised a jar containing more than 7,000 denarii and some radiates. Some contemporary reports suggest that there were as many as 12,000 coins. Hugon suggested that the gaps in types and paucity of the latest issues and the presence almost exclusively of denarii indicated that the hoard was sorted by type and denomination and that originally there may have been further jars. Indeed, in 1943, a further vessel containing 28 denarii was found at the same findspot and is considered to be part of the same hoard.
572 silver coins: 2 denarii, 570 antoniniani: Macrinus - Valerian I (AD 253 -259); Silver weight: 1143.8-2361.7g
88 silver coins: 1 denarius, 87 antoniniani (radiates): Elagabalus - Quintillus (AD 270).
(116) 101 provincial bronze coins: Septimius Severus - Gordian III (AD 241).
disposition: National Archaeological Institute with Museum, Sofia, Bulgaria; inv. no. CXXIV

summary: 24 large bronze cooins (sestertii and double sestertii?): Domitian - Postumus (AD 260-268).
Large number of silver coins. 14 pieces were noticed: Septimius Severus - Philip I (AD 244-249).
(30) 7 silver and bronze coins: 2 denarii, 1 antoniniani; 1 provincial bronze; 3 bronze unid. denom: Commodus - Philip I (AD 244-249).
disposition: Private collection Andrei Pănoiu - architect, Bucharest, Romania

summary: The hoard comprised 13 bronze coins, dated between AD 244-253.
21 coins coming from a donation: 20 antoniniani (radiates), 1 sestertius Gallienus (sole) - Diocletian. The sestertius of Antoninus Pius for Marcus Aurelius (Caesar), most likely, and intruder.
disposition: Museo Interdisciplinare Reg. di Messina: Fondo Naz. 866-887

summary: 116 provincial bronze coins: Septimius Severus - Trajan Decius (AD 249-251). The issues are from the mints from Moesia and Thracia, mainly Marcianopolis, Nicopolis ad Istrum and Viminacium
1269 silver and bronze coins: 1251 denarii; 7 plated denarii; 9 antoniniani; 1 drachm; 1 bronze: Mark Antony - Severus Alexander (AD 222-235); Silver weight: 1777.1-4207.8g
disposition: National History Museum of Transylvania, Cluj-Napoca, Romania

summary: The hoard was found on the site of a Roman villa and comprised 4 vessels containing 4,399 coins. 156 were denarii from Antoninus Pius to Gordian III and 4,245 were radiates from Gordian III to Gallienus' sole reign and Postumus. Vessel 1 contained a single denarius of Severus Alexander and 1057 antoniniani (radiates) from Gordian III to Postumus with a tpq of AD 264-265. Vessel 2 contained 986 antoniniani (radiates) from Elagabalus to Postumus with a tpq of AD 268. Vessel 3 contained 155 denarii from Antoninus Pius to Maximinus I and 575 antoniniani (radiates) from Gordian III to Postumus with a tpq of AD 268. Vessel 4 contained 1,627 antoniniani (radiates) from Gordian III to Postumus.
320 denarii and antoniniani found in a building from the ancient settlement. 22 coins were reviewed: Gordian - Trajan Decius (AD 249-251).

A hoard of 11 provincial coins (Thessalonica, Pella, Dium, the koinon of Macedonia) ranging from Marcus Aurelius to Gordian III, found in a grave, part of a vast necropolis in the eastern part of Veroia.

15 coins in a pot, found on Podington Wold in the early 19th century, including coins of Gallienus (AD 253-268) and Philippus Augustus (AD 244-249), a stone described as of circular form with a hole for a winch, which sounds like a rotary quern, and fragments of pottery.
190 antoniniani, probably, part of Sushina 2: Gordian III - Claudius II (AD 268-270).

116 coins found in 1870 close to Moneybury Hill, with articles of metal, animal remains, and broken Roman pottery. The coins range from the first half of the 1st century AD to ca. AD 270 and included 2 denarii, 8 antoniniani, 78 bronze and 28 cast coins. These coins could have formed two separate hoards (one consisting of AE up to ca. AD 249; the other ranging down to AD 270).
1,312 antoniniani (radiates) ending with coins of Tetricus I (AD 271-274); silver weight: 249.3g.
105 provincial bronze coins: Septimius Severus - Philip I (AD 244-249).
disposition: Regional History Museum, Targovishte, Bulgaria; inv.nos. 31173-31277

summary: 22 Syrian tetradrachms, ranging from Elagabalus to Trebonianus Gallus, found in destruction deposits of Room 9J.
4 coins of Gordian III: 2 antoniniani (radiates), 2 sestertii P M S COL VIM (AD 238-244).
15 sestertii found close to each other on a narrow space in the eastern necropolis of the Augusta Emerita: Domitian
disposition: Consorcio de la Ciudad Monumental de Mérida, Spain

summary: A mixed hoard of circa 250 denarii and antoniniani (radiates) dating from Septimus Severus to Valerian I (AD 253-259).
The hoard comprised 135 sestertii from Vespasian to Postumus with a tpq of AD 260.

A mixed hoard of denarii, some sestertii and a few antoniniani, ranging from Hadrian to Trajan Decius. It was found in soil dug out during building work in Niederlahnstein (Weiherstraße). The hoard, which was partly dispersed, might have comprised 200 coins or more, but a description of only 142 exists.
The hoard comprised 43 sestertii from Commodus to Gordian III (AD 241-243).
508 silver coins: 19 denarii, 489 denarii: Septimius Severus - Trebonianus Gallus (AD 251-253).
127 silver coins: 86 denarii, 41 antoniniani: Trajan - Philip I (AD 244-249); silver weight: 174.4-359 g.

The hoard was found in a coarseware vessel which was broken. It comprised a block of Roman silver and bronze coins which had been stuck together with corrosion products. Hobbs estimates a silver weight of 249.6-505.0 g.
The hoard comprised Roman coins dating to the third century AD.
54 coins found spread close to each other in a layer of ashes: Domitian - Tetricus I (AD 271-274).
Breakdown of mints is given suggesting that full breakdown is given in articles. Silver: 1406 coins; Silver weight: 40.1g

The hoard comprised a copper-alloy jug containing more than 1,800 coins, mostly of Diocletian and Maximian.
