According to Derriaz, there were a few issues from the mint of Rome, with the remainder being mint of Lyon issues. The jug was acquired by the Musée de la Civilisation gallo-romaine, Lyon (Inv. Br. 208)
It comprised 42 denarii from Antoninus Pius to Maximinus I Thrax (AD 235-238).
Around 600 silver coins, of which 432 were seen: Vespasian - Gordian III (AD 238-244).

The hoard comprised 23 bronze coins dated between AD 141 and AD 251-253. "The hoard contains a mixture of imperial asses and sestertii, with bronzes from regional 'provincial' mints (Gaza, Ascalon, Caesarea Maritima, Aelia Capitolina, and Nysa-Scythopolis), many of which are countermarked." (Kool, 41).
The hoard comprised more than 36,000 coins, probably all antoniniani (radiates) from Valerian I and Gallienus to Aurelian (AD 270-275).
108 antoniniani (radiates)Ș Gallienus (sole) - Quintillus (AD 270).
The hoard comprised 283 tetradrachms dated between the reigns of Septimius Severus (AD 193-211) and Trebonianus Gallus (AD 251-253).
A hoard of 10 antoniniani (Valerian I - Gallienus) found in a destruction deposit of a Roman villa 500 metres from Chaeronea.
55 antoniniani (radiates): Pupienus - Valerian I (AD 253-260); silver weight: 69.9-128.8 g.
Hoard of around 150 denarii: Vespasian - Severus Alexander (Julia Mamaea) (AD 222-235).
disposition: Statistical commission, Penza (in 1889); the high-school, Penza, Russia; old collection D. Ya. Samkvasov

summary: Approx. 80 small bronze coins, of which 13 are imitations of Tetricus I, found on a brickyard located between the Lehmstrasse and Am Schlütershof. Apparently, they were contained in a small metal box.
4811 denarii and antoniniani, found in one (or two?) urns, in the garden of the school. Coins range from Caracalla to Postumus.
84 antoniniani (radiates) from the area of Lisbon: Gallienus (sole) - Tetricus I (AD 271-274).
disposition: The British Museum (?), London, United Kingdom

summary: On July 28, 1937, a hoard of 1478 silver and 2 copper coins was found in Rochester Road, St. Anne's, Bristol, in a pit that was being dug for a garage. No trace of any container could be found, though careful search was made. The silver coins were 1476 denarii (Mark Antony to Septimius Severus) and two drachms (Caesarea in Cappadocia and Lycia). Please note that Pearce and Mattingly's coin summary lists 128 denarii of Hadrian and 66 of Faustina I, but the catalogue includes 126 Hadrianic denarii, and 68 denarii of Faustina I.
disposition: British Museum (part); City of Bristol Museum and Art Gallery (part)

summary: 73 coins (44 denarii, 3 aurei and 23 bronze coins), ranging from Mark Antony to Severus Alexander, found together over time within the foundation walls of a Roman building located in the vicus surrounding the Roman fort of Eining. The earlier finds had been dispersed, but most of them could be traced in FMRD.
There is debate over the number of coins found. Jennepin states the total as being 100; Bernier 300: Gordian III - Postumus (AD 260-269); silver weight: c.41.5-186.5g.

Unknown number of coins found in the vineyard, on an ancient settlement area. 30 coins of Gordian III are known: 15 antoniniani for Gordian III, 15 provincial bronzes minted in Deultum for Tranquilina.
The hoard comprised several thousand coins, mostly of Postumus. It is possibly a hoard described as being found in a copper-alloy basin.
6 bronze coins: 1 sestertius, 5 provincial: Hadrian - Septimius Severus/Caracalla (AD 209-212 Found on a shipwreck
Small group of denarii and radiates and a finger ring found together, possible purse hoard.

Hoard of circa 1,200 'large bronzes' found with a large ceramic vessel: Trajan - Aemilian (AD 253). The largest number of coins belonged to Severus Alexander, Gordian III, Philip I and Philip II. Rare issues of the emperors Pertinax, Clodius Albinus, Gordian I and II,
A large ceramic vessel containing 15 kg of silver coins. 4453 antoniniani were published (Moushmov 1936): Aemilian - Carinus (AD 283-285).
disposition: National Archaeological Institute with Museum, Sofia, Bulgaria; inv. no. LXIX (in 1925); 1,231 coins

summary: 26 silver coins: 17 denarii, 9 antoniniani (radiates): Septimius Severus - Trajan Decius (AD 251); silver weight: 35.5-53.2 g.

The hoard comprised 606 radiates from Balbinus to Postumus with a tpq of approximately AD 263. The hoard contains official issues up until Postumus' Issue 1c (AD 261) but there are two radiates which copy coins of AD 263. Hobbs estimates a silver weight of between 141.2 and 1222.6g.
The composition of this hoard was reconstructed by Paul Reinecke. The coins (10 denarii, ranging from Galba to Maximinus) were found in a wood belonging to the abbey at Metten, soon after 1800.
55 antoniniani (radiates) : Gallienus - Diocletian (AD 284-293).
The hoard comprised 4 denarii from Antoninus Pius to Severus Alexander with a tpq of AD 228 to 234.
4,000 antoniniani (radiates). 1967 were available to identify the issuers: Valerian I and Gallienus - Aurelian (AD 270-275).
14 uncertain denominations: Republic - Philip I (AD 244-249).
253 bronze coins: 252 sestertii, 1 dupondius: Vespasian - Severus alexander (AD 222-235).
Unknown number of denarii. 56 coins entered the museum collection in Plovdiv: Nero - Caracalla (AD 211-217).
disposition: Museum of Archaeology, Plovdiv, Bulgaria; inv.no. 2590

summary: More than 1,500 coins were discovered in a bowl. However, only 77 pieces are known in any detail, 5% of the original hoard: Caracalla - Valerian I and Gallienus (AD 258-259).
IARCH record for a group of 4 silver radiates found fused together. For further details and images see NMS-865B3E. Two of the coins could not be identified due to their condition.
29 antoniniani (radiates) found buried under the floor and covered with a tegula: Gallienus (sole) - Divus Claudius II (AD 270).

Mint totals are given but not linked with coins. This indicates that a full listing of coins must exist. The hoard was found not far from a Roman villa, next to the ancient road (cf. Gallia 20 (1962) p. 429) The hoard was deposited in the Cabinet des Médailles de la BN. Silver: 1098, 3602 coins; Silver weight: 2577.8-6108.2

summary: Four provincial coins (Pella, Cassandrea) found in a grave in Potidaia in 1973.
15 coins: 3 denarii, 5 antoniniani. 7 provincial bronze coins: Septimius Severus - Philip I (AD 244-249); silver weight: 10.9-17.1 g.

A hoard of 30 coins (2 uncertain, 1 Imperial Roman; 27 provincial coins: Dion, Odessa, Pella, Koinon of Macedonia, Thessalonica, Cassandrea), found in a grave in Sindos in 1981, ending with coins of Philip.
Unknown originally number of coins found with a ceramic vessel. Only 63 antoniniani (radiates ) are known: Gordian III - Aurelian (AD 270-275).

The hoard was scattered by the plough, but 124 coins were recovered. They comprised 2 denarii and 122 antoniniani (radiates) from Septimius Severus to Gallienus and Postumus with a tpq of AD 263. Hobbs estimates a silver weight of 37.6g to 154.7g.
575 denarii: Nero – Gordian III (AD 238-244).

The hoard comprised a ceramic vessel containing between 1,500 and 2,000 third century bronzes. 105 of these coins were identified. All were radiates, although it was noted that originally there were a 'certain number' of denarii of Postumus. 100 coins from the hoard were acquired by the Musée de Poitiers. Silver: c.1500-2000 (105) coins; Silver weight: 473.5-2186.5
disposition: Museum of Poitiers; private collections (2 coins); some coins lost

summary: 61 silver coins: Septimius Severus - Trebonianus Gallus (AD 251-253).
2 aurei of Carausius, found in spoil after the construction of a building near Ashbourne.
23 silver coins found in a ceramic vessel: 10 denarii, 11 antoniniani: Septimius Severus - Philip I (AD 244-249).

summary: The hoard consists of 73 coins found with a patera: 5 imperial denarii, 6 antoniniani (radiates), 62 Roman provincial bronzes: Trajan - Trebonianus Gallus (AD 251-253). Most of the provincial coins presents early 3rd century AD countermarks.
190 bronze coins: 1 sestertius, 170 provincials: Antoninus Pius (Faustina I) - Philip I (AD 244-249).

summary: The hoard comprised coins from Gallienus to Probus. There are some doubts on the real number of coins from this hoard!
1889 antoniniani, 43 imitations, 6 forgeries and some fragments: Elagabalus - Probus (AD 276-282).

3000 antoniniani (ranging from Trajan Decius to Tetricus, several of which are imitations) fund in a vessel close to Nieder-Ingelheim. 1174 specimens reached the museum Wiesbaden, the other coins are lost.

M. Poilly donated a lot of 173 denarii and antoniniani (radiates) to the Societé archéologique de l'Orléanais' which were found 'in the environs of Dieppe': Maximinus I Thrax - Postumus (AD 260-269); silver weight: 44.4-232.4 g.
51H includes the coins which were found in front of the temple, in the court by an urn.
+1000 silver coins, according to Gerov, B. 640 studied: Elagabalus - Trajan Decius (AD 249-251); silver weight: 800.6-1662.9 g.

summary: 250 silver coins: Vespasian - Gordian III (AD 238-244); silver weight: 314.2-735.8g
40 billon tetradrachms of Alexandria: Hadrian - VAlerian I and Gallienus (AD 257-258) found at floor level of a room during excavations of a house.

summary: The hoard comprised a greyware vessel containing approximately 1,100 antoniani (radiates) from Valerian to Diocletian and Maximian I. Those of Saloninus, Salonina, Tacitus, Numerian, Carinus and Constantius I were quite numerous; those of Postumus, Victorinus, Tetricus I. Aurelian, Probus, Maximian I and Diocletian were quite abundant; those of Gallienus and Claudius II were the most numerous. Hobbs estimates a silver weight of between 131.1g and 1248.9g.
(700) 170 silver coins, denarii and antoniniani: Trajan - Valerian I/Gallienus (AD 253-268).
1,489 tetradrachms of Alexandria: Aurelian - Diocletian-Maximian I (AD 295-296) found in a heap on the floor of the underground room N during excavations of a house.
The hoard (8 denarii and antoniniani, Elagabalus - Philip I) was found at the bottom of a container during construction work at Heilbronn street.
A bunch of 12 antoniniani: Claudius II - Probus (AD 276-282).
17 coins: 16 denarii, 1 dupondius: Hadrian - Gordian III (AD 241); silver weight: 23.9-44.2 g.

2,236 silver coins: 415 denarii, 1,821 antoniniani (radiates): Commodus - Trebonianus Gallus (AD 251-253).

25 antoniniani (radiates): Gallienus - Maximianus I (AD 285-286); silver weight: 4.6-6.8g.

summary: Antoniniani (radiates): Gallienus - Aurelian (AD 270-275).

summary: 148 Roman coins and silver and brass jewelry. 126 coins: 6 silver coins, 116 sestertii and 4 dupondii/asses: Domitian - Philip I (AD 244-249)
It comprised 23 coins found in "un grand mortier de pierre" (mortarium). Only 3 were identified: Augustus, Marcus Aurelius, Aurelian.
The hoard was found in a funerary urn and apparently comprised 50 'small bronzes' or radiates of Gallienus.

Metal hoard/deposition, silver, bronze, iron, carefully stored in a cavity, in a small room close to the southern porticus. Bronze vessels, iron tools, jewellery and coins stored together between two bronze vessels. The hoard comprised 59 (62 ?) coins including 4 sestertii, 4 dupondii, 50 asses and 1 dupondius or as terminating in issues of AD 249-51 and including many pre-103 AD coins: these were not taken from normal coin circulation in mid-3rd cent., but carefully selected.
49 denarii: Vespasian - Septimius Severus (AD 193-211). Found together with a gold pendant.
Unknown initial number of coins. 69 bronze coins: Augustus - Philip I (AD 244-249).

Coins run from Mark Antony to Trajan Decius, although it has been argued that the last coins could be intrusive. In that case, the hoard would end with issues of Gordian III. 81,096 (and not 81,044!) coins were published in 1934 by Mouchmov, after a further 20,000+ coins had been dispersed. The total number of coins therefore exceeds 101,096 specimens. The difference between our comput and the 81,044 coins mentioned in the original publication resides in an error in counting the number of coins of Commodus (3146, whereas 3191 is correct) and reporting the correct number of coins of Caracalla in the table p. 6 of Mouchmov's publication. Note that further errors have occurred for Trajan (p. 21, last three entries, where numbers do not add up).
disposition: National Museum, Sofia (ca. 68,783 coins). Archaeology Museum, Varna, Bulgaria: inv.nos. 2807-2829, 4301-16363 (12,261 coins: Nero - Gordian III)

summary: 315 denarii: Vespasian - Maximinus I Thrax (AD 236).
disposition: National History Museum, Sofia, Bulgaria; inv. no. 2319/1-315

summary: Few hundreds imitations of antoniniani (radiates), between 500-2,000 pieces of Tetricus I (AD 271-274), 400 studied.

Hoard of 21 coins - 6 denarii and 15 counterfeits. Pit also contained broken samian & coarseware pottery and an iron hook, possibly a mount for a purse. Pit found during southern vicus excavs. S of River Tees, to W of the N-S road (Holme House 71-2).

14 aureii (13 mounted): Trajan - Septimius Severus (AD 204); gold weight 110 g. Found with a bronze pitcher. The content: two crosses; three chains; a brooch; sixty-eight pendants and sixty-four grains of necklace; fourteen coins of Roman emperors of the second-third century, the Antonines mainly, and two bracteates.

(1213) 1209 silver coins: 10 denarii, 1199 antoniniani: Caracalla - Gallienus (AD 259-268); silver weight: 1752.4-2218.6 g. The hoard was foun within the ruins of a Roman building placed in a bronze vessel
disposition: Muzeul Na'ional al Unirii Alba Iulia, Romania

summary: 43 silver and bronze coins, plated denarii: 41 denarii (19 plated), 1 sestertius, 1 as: Vespasian - Severus Alexander (AD 228-231). Found in the Principia building of the 5th Macedonica Legion fort.

The hoard comprised an amphora containing approximately 5,400 Roman coins, weighing 143 kilos in total. They were mostly sestertii with some 'middle bronzes' (asses, according to Hollard 1992, 99). Blanchet catalogued a selection of 132 from the collections of the Musée Carnavalet from Gordian III to Postumus Silver: 1, 50 coins; silver weight: 17.4-63.0g.
disposition: Musée Carnavalet, Paris (132 coins); Sanatorium Nestor Pirotte Angicourt (120 coins, possible lost)

summary: 361 antoniniani/radiate: Gallienus - Tetrachy (AD 292-293)

The hoard comprised a ceramic vessel containing approximately 300 coins, of which 196 were identified by A. Fillioux. The rest of the coins were small bronzes (radiates) of Gallienus, Salonina, Valerian-Saloninus and of Postumus, for the most part worn or copies. The latest coin of Postumus (E. 593) dating to AD 269. Silver: 1, 193+ coins; Silver weight: 54.9-502.2+
18 antoniniani (radiates) found stuck together on the elbow of a skeleton in a grave: Gallienus - Tetricus I (AD 271-274).

The hoard comprised 64 barbarous radiates of Postumus, Victorinus and Tetricus I and 26 unstruck flans. They were found during the excavation of a cave, not far from Berdorf. The presence of several identical coins and unstruck flans suggests that there was a forger's mint somewhere in the vicinity.
disposition: Cabinet des Médailles du Musée d'Histoire et d'Art, Luxembourg (84 coins); private collection (5 coins)

summary: 1,606 silver coins: 604 denarii, 1,002 antoniniani of the 1st-3rd centuries AD.
1,500 tetradrachms of Alexandria: Claudius II - Diocletian-Maximian I (AD 292-293) found in two small pots in an underground room during excavations of a house.

Gallwey described 29,886 coins which he considered to represent 2/3rds or 3/4s of the total found. Originally, the latest coin in the hoard was stated to be an issue of Gallienus' Zoo dating to the period AD 267 to 268. However, a revision states that it is actually an issue of Gallienus from the mint of Siscia dating to AD 268 Silver: c.40,000 (29,858) coins.
147 antoniniani (radiates): Gordian III - Victorinus (AD 269).

Four aurei and jewelrey: Trajan Decius - Gallienus (sole) found with a copper vessel. Some of the objects were taken by the finder. According to the finder, Near the vessel was a stone in a vertical position.
disposition: Institut d'Archéologie de Bucarest; Musée National d'Histoire de Bucarest; dispersed

summary: 127 tetradrachms of Alexandria: Claudius II - Carus (AD 282-283) found on the floor of an underground room during excavations of a house.
disposition: 102 coins in Ann Arbor, the rest in Cairo

summary: Only 303 antoniniani (radiates) are identified. The exact findspot is not known, but it is possible that it comes from Oudenburg, Gistel or Torhout: Gordian III - Postumus (AD 260-269).
Hoard of denarii and antoniniani (radiates), 7,206 coins: Septimius Severus - Postumus (AD 260-269). The largest number of coins belonging to Gordian III
The hoard was comprised a black pot containing 356 denarii and antoniniani (radiates)
1089 silver coins: 14 denarii, 1076 antoniniani: Antoninus Pius - Valerian I (AD 259)
A hoard of 107 provincial bronze coins (of which 74 were identifiable), found in the Roman barracks at Dura Europos.
(30 kg) 10,700 silver coins, denarii and antoniniani: Caracalla - Probus (AD 276-282); silver weight: 1919.3-27660.6g
disposition: Académie florimontane, Annecy, France; Musée d'Annecy, inv.no. 3058; Schwizerisches Landesmuseum, Zürich, Switzerland (187 coins)

summary: The hoard comprised 70 antoniniani (radiates) imitations of Tetricus I and II.

A third century hoard of 99 antoniniani (radiates) interpreted as a savings hoard. Found during development control excavation in advance of building new housing estate: Gordian - Valerian I and Gallienus (AD 258-259).
1,173 antoniniani (radiates) found with a ceramic vessel: Valerian I and Gallienus - Tetricus I (AD 271-274); silver weight: 317.7-1465.3g.

The hoard comprised 2,769 coins including a plated copy of a denarius of Severus Alexander and radiates from Valerian to Probus. It was found concealed in a broken ceramic vessel covered with a schist slab in a cavity in the southern wall of Building E (V) of a Gallo-Roman villa. Elements of the hoard were found on two occasions. First, in August 1983 and then in 1984 when further excavation of the site took place. Severus Alexander (plated denarius); Valerian I and Gallienus - Probus (AD 276-282).
disposition: Cabinet des Médailles du Musée National d'Histoire et d'Art, Luxembourg, Luxembourg; inv.no. 1984-72

summary: In a ceramic vessel were found antoniniani from Gordian III to Trebonianus Gallus (AD 251-253). 1,153 coins are kept in the History Museum in Lom. 886 antoniniani belong to Volusian.
disposition: History Museum, Lom Bulgaria; inv.no. 2470 (1153 coins)

summary: The hoard comprised 654 coins of which a total of 444 were recorded. These included 442 denarii from the Republic to Severus Alexander and 2 antoniniani of Caracalla and Elagabalus.

A hoard of 71 Pamphylian bronze coins, mostly from Perge (64) and a few other cities, as well as one coin from Selge in Pisidia that ranges in date from Caracalla to Aurelian. These coins were purchased by John Mossop, which the ticket 'Perge hoard, Dec. 66'. It is unclear whether 'Perge' refers to the find spot, or to the fact that most coins came from that city.

The hoard comprised 10.6kg of coins. Mints represented are Rome (3195); Milan (135); Viminiacium (1); Siscia (151), Sirmium (2), Antioch (1); Cyzicus (10); Cologne (13); Trier (11); uncertain (53) Found during the construction of a vault. Silver: 28, 3590, 47 coins; Silver weight: 1008.5-4527.4

The hoard was discovered during antiquarian exploration of a Gallo-Roman site. It appeared to have been originally stored in a cabinet measuring 6 feet square and comprised more than 300 base-silver coins. According to the finder, villagers who knew the findspot continued to find coins in abundance there. 300 silver coins: Severus Alexander - Valerian I and Gallienus/Gallienus (sole) (AD 253-268); silver weight: 76.1-710.8+g.
Part of a larger hoard. 17 provincial bronze coins: Hadrian - Severus Alexander (AD 222-235).
disposition: Museum of Archaeology, Plovdiv, Bulgaria; inv.nos. 1701-1718

summary: The hoard comprised 114 sestertii: Trajan-Gordian III (98-243 AD).
67 antoniniani (radiates): Gordian III to Diocletian (AD 284-293).
The hoard comprised a vessel containing a gold finger ring, a silver bracelet and 28 coins from Marcus Aurelius to Valerian I.
